Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: indemnity costs

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: calderbank letter

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: refusal of offer

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: whether refusal unreasonable

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: variety of factors relevant to assessment of unreasonableness

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: indemnity costs refused

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: costs

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 1 On 17 April 2008 the application brought by the University of Western Australia (UWA) against Dr Bruce Gray and Sirtex Medical Ltd (Sirtex) was dismissed.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA was ordered to pay the costs of Dr Gray and Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: A cross-claim brought by Sirtex against UWA was dismissed and Sirtex ordered to pay UWA's costs of that cross-claim.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Sirtex succeeded in its cross-claim against Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 2 Paragraphs 14 and 15 of the Orders made on 17 April 2008 provided:    14.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Any party in respect of whom an order for costs has been made in the preceding orders is at liberty to file and serve written submissions on or before 8 May 2008 seeking a variation of the costs order.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Any party who wishes to respond to a written submission filed pursuant to the preceding order is to do so by filing and serving a written submission by 29 May 2008.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 3 On 12 May 2008 Sirtex filed a motion seeking the following orders:    1.1 that Order 2 of his Honour Justice French, made on 17 April 2008, be amended to read as follows:   "Applicant pay the first and second respondent's costs of the application and the applicant pay the second respondents' costs of the application on an indemnity basis from 19 March 2007.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: " [sic]  1.2 Applicant pay the second respondent's costs of this motion on an indemnity basis.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 1.3 Any other order that the Court sees fit.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In support of its motion, Sirtex filed an affidavit of Timothy Randle Price sworn 12 May 2008.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That affidavit concerned settlement negotiations between UWA and Sirtex which had occurred in 2007 prior to the commencement of the hearing.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 4 By way of background the solicitors for UWA had sent an open settlement offer to Sirtex on 5 September 2006.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The letter of offer was exhibit 243A at trial.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In substance the letter proposed that UWA would licence Sirtex, on a world-wide basis, to exploit the patents in contention, the licence to be retroactive to 29 April 1997.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: A discounted licence fee would be payable.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA would be recorded as owner of the patents.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: A 4% royalty on the net price of products using or embodying any claim of any one or more of the patents was proposed.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The UWA proceedings against Sirtex would be discontinued with no order as to costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA required that Sirtex cooperate with it in the further conduct of the proceedings against Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The offer was accompanied by contentions that the directors of Sirtex were aware at all material times of UWA's interest in the intellectual property.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The offer was not accepted.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 5 The trial was scheduled to begin in the week commencing Monday, 12 March 2007.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: On Saturday, 10 March 2007, the solicitors for UWA again wrote to the solicitors for Sirtex making an "Open Offer".

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The offer was in the following terms:  The University offers to fully and finally settle with Sirtex Medical Limited (Sirtex) the above named proceedings on the following basis:   1.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Within 14 days of the date of settlement, Sirtex to pay the University the sum of AUD$1.25 million dollars; [sic] and   2.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Within 30 days of settlement, Sirtex to allot and issue to the University fully paid ordinary shares in Sirtex ranking pari passu with all existing fully paid shares to the value of AUD$3 million dollars [sic] based upon the VWAP selling price for Sirtex shares for 14 trading days immediately prior to completion of the allotment and issue, which allotment is to provide a fund for the establishment of a scholarship within the University sufficient for an annual award at University Postgraduate Award rates for the purpose of encouraging students to undertake research in an area of biomedical science ( the Sirtex Scholarship );   ...  The offer went on to set out the conditions upon which the Sirtex scholarship would be awarded.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It then continued:   4.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The proceedings in WAD 292 of 2004 in so far as they subsist between the University and Sirtex to be discontinued with no order as to costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: A Deed of Release to be executed by the University and Sirtex under which both parties will irrevocably release each other from all claims made against each other in the Proceedings.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It is a condition precedent to settlement in accordance with this offer that Sirtex withdraws its opposition to the implementation of the settlement between the University and the Cancer Research Institute Inc, which was approved by the Federal Court of Australia on 9 March 2007.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: This offer is an open offer and may be withdrawn at any time prior to acceptance by notice in writing served by the University upon Sirtex or its legal representatives in the proceedings.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The letter, like its predecessor in September 2006, alleged that, although investors in Sirtex had been innocent of UWA's interest in its intellectual property, the directors were aware of that interest.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 6 Sirtex responded to UWA's offer through its solicitors by a letter dated 14 March 2007, the day prior to the actual commencement of the trial.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In that letter Sirtex responded to the allegations about the awareness of its directors which UWA had made in its letter of 10 March 2007.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Sirtex said, in its letter, that it was inappropriate for UWA to make such allegations as there was no evidence to support them.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Sirtex nevertheless indicated that it was prepared to resolve the dispute on the terms set out in an attached Deed of Settlement.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It also stated that it was content to consider any reasonable amendments to the Deed proposed by UWA provided that they were designed to clarify or perfect its terms, but not otherwise impact on its substance.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: If the offer were accepted it would no longer be necessary for Sirtex to pursue its cross-claim against CRI.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The letter continued:    7.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Sirtex notes UWA's interest in a Scholarship to be funded by Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: We are instructed that Sirtex would be happy to consider such a proposal (or a proposal to sponsor research undertaken at UWA) following the resolution of these proceedings.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The offer contained in the letter remained open until 10am on 19 March 2007 at which time it would be withdrawn.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Sirtex reserved all of its rights and stated it would rely upon the letter to claim indemnity costs from that date.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 7 The Deed of Settlement attached to the letter provided for a mutual release by UWA and Sirtex of each other and their associated entities from all claims made against each other in the proceeding or arising from or in connection with its subject matter including all claims for transfer of ownership of the patents in contention.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It also provided for UWA to acknowledge Sirtex's ownership of the patents and undertake not to challenge Sirtex's entitlement to remain their registered owner.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA would undertake to take all reasonably necessary steps to ratify, perfect and/or defend Sirtex's registration and/or ownership of the patents as requested by Sirtex in writing.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: These provisions were stated to be without prejudice to UWA's right to claim against Dr Gray that it had a beneficial interest in the patents for the purposes of its claim to his shareholding in Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 8 Clause 3 of the Deed provided:    3.1 If UWA has Substantial Success against Gray in the Proceeding, Sirtex shall (at Sirtex's election) within 28 days of the date of Substantial Success:   3.1.1 provide UWA with the Share Allotment; or  3.1.2 pay UWA the Settlement Amount.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 3.2 Sirtex shall not be liable to provide UWA with the Share Allotment or the Settlement Amount in accordance with clause 3.1 of this Deed if UWA does not have Substantial Success against Gray in the Proceeding.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 9 The term "Substantial Success" was defined in clause 8.1 thus:  Substantial Success means   (i) a final Court order in the Proceeding (including and subject to any appeal) dealing with the question of ownership of the Patents as between UWA and Gray (and such order will be deemed not final unless and until the period for filing an appeal against such order as prescribed in the relevant court rules has expired, and such expiry date shall be treated as the date of the final order for the purposes of this Deed); or   (ii) any written settlement agreement executed between UWA and Gray dealing with the question of ownership of the Patents as between UWA and Gray and served upon Sirtex,   which has the effect of:   (iii) declaring that UWA has been at 17 April 1997 or any later time a beneficial owner of any of the Patents;   (iv) transferring more than 10% of Gray's Shareholding in Sirtex to UWA; and/or  (v) Gray having a liability to pay UWA an amount of more than 10% of the value of Gray's Shareholding in Sirtex as at the Settlement Date to be agreed by the Parties immediately before the execution of this Deed or counterparts to this Deed.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 10 The Settlement Amount was defined as "AUD$1.5 million".

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The "Share Allotment" was defined as "an issue of shares in Sirtex to the value of $1.5m (rounded up)".

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The value of the shares was to be calculated by reference to the Volume Weighted Average Price for the five business days commencing two days after the Settlement Date.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The Settlement Date was defined as "the date of exchange of the duly executed counterparts of this Deed".

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 11 Mr Price said in his initial affidavit that no response was received to the offer from UWA.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That statement was erroneous as he acknowledged in a second affidavit.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: On 15 March 2007 the solicitors for UWA wrote back to the solicitors for Sirtex in the following terms:    1.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: We refer to your letter dated 14 March 2007 with respect to an offer to settle by Sirtex Medical Limited.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The offer of settlement is unacceptable to our client.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The effect of your offer of 14 March 2007 is to reject our client's offer of 10 March 2007.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That is, it is no longer open to your client to accept it.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 12 In the course of closing submissions at the end of the substantive hearing, UWA indicated the orders it would seek to have made against Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The orders it sought in its closing submissions were in the following terms:  The Court: 1.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Makes the declarations sought in Order 7 of the second substituted application filed 1 March 2007 ("the Application").

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Subject to the undertaking by the applicant in paragraph 3 hereof, makes orders 8 to 10 sought in the application.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Notes the undertaking of the applicant to the Court that it will not seek to enforce the above order 2 upon the entry by Sirtex into a deed whereby the applicant will be entitled to royalties with respect to the intellectual property identified in the attached schedule in an amount as agreed between the parties within 14 days or as ordered by the Court upon the appointment and report of an expert pursuant to FCR Order 34 rule 2.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Order the second respondent to pay the applicant royalties in the amount set in accordance with order 3 above for the period 1 May 1997 to the date of judgment together with interest thereon.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 13 A proposed deed in accordance with the proposed order 3 was annexed to the submissions.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The Deed provided for Sirtex to pay a royalty in respect of the exploitation of products using or incorporating a claim under any of the patents and patent applications specified in Schedule 1 to the Deed including any Confidential Information comprised in or relating to the inventions the subject of the patents.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The Deed would have contained an acknowledgment by UWA that nothing in it transferred title to the patents to UWA.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA would have ratified, with effect from the date of execution of the Deed, each of the assignments to Sirtex pleaded in its statement of claim.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The Deed included an undertaking by UWA not to challenge or question Sirtex's title to or interest in each of the patents, the validity of any of the patents or any application by Sirtex to register a trade mark in connection with any of the patents.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It is not necessary to go further into the details of the deed, the substance of it is clear enough from the preceding outline.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 14 On 2 May 2008 the solicitors for Sirtex wrote to the solicitors for UWA seeking its consent to an order for indemnity costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It referred, in particular, to paragraph 1569 and 1570 of the primary judgment in which it was said:  The case against Sirtex for knowing involvement in Dr Gray's alleged breaches of fiduciary duty and knowing assistance depends crucially upon the primary case against Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That case having failed, the claim against Sirtex cannot succeed and will be dismissed.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: I should add as I have already found that Sirtex was not at any time on notice of a potential claim by UWA through any of its directors other than Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The application of any cause of action based on knowing involvement in his alleged breaches of fiduciary duty would have depended entirely upon his role as a director of Sirtex and whether his knowledge could be attributed to the company.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 15 On 8 May 2008, the time for filing an appeal from the primary judgment of 17 April 2008 expired.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA filed a notice of appeal in respect of the dismissal of its application against Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It has not appealed against the dismissal of its application against Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Submissions  16 Sirtex's primary submission on the hearing of the motion was that UWA acted unreasonably and imprudently in refusing the Sirtex offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Sirtex acknowledged that its success in the cross-claim against Dr Gray left it open to seek from him, by way of damages, the difference between the costs it would recover from UWA on a party and party basis and the costs it had actually incurred in these proceedings.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It submitted that having regard to UWA's conduct in refusing its offer justice required that the difference in costs be borne by UWA.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Dr Gray had no control over the conduct of UWA in responding to the Sirtex offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 17 Counsel for Sirtex submitted that it was clear at the time that UWA refused the offer that it was seeking to maintain an untenable position under which it would have everything from everybody.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 18 In its written outline of submissions, Sirtex acknowledged that the power to award indemnity costs is in the Court's discretion and would be exercised "when the justice of the case so requires": Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth) s 43(2).

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: As Sirtex put it the question for determination was whether it was unreasonable for UWA to reject its offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The reasonableness of the rejection was to be assessed:  (a) as at the date of the offer and on the basis of the evidence available at the time of the offer; but (b) with the benefit of hindsight as to the matters decided in the judgment.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: A conditional offer to settle was properly the subject of consideration by the Court.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 19 Sirtex set out a number of factors in favour of an award of indemnity costs:  (a) It would have been reasonable to expect UWA to accept Sirtex's offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: (b) UWA is in a significantly worse position as a result of running its trial against Sirtex than it would have been had it accepted the offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: (c) Assessed at the time of the offer, but with the benefit of hindsight (and even without the benefit of hindsight), UWA was highly unlikely to succeed in its claim.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: (d) It was entirely unnecessary for UWA to pursue a claim against Sirtex when it had two other respondents with very substantial assets available to them which would have satisfied the claims of UWA realistically put at their highest.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: (e) UWA initiated the "open offer" regime as a means of seeking to gain an advantage in relation to any award of costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 20 Sirtex, after referring to the absence of merit in the UWA case, submitted that the condition contained in its offer that UWA achieve "Substantial Success" against Dr Gray was, for two reasons, reasonable and prudent on the part of the board of a publicly listed company protecting innocent shareholders.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The case against Sirtex was contingent upon UWA's succeeding against Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That was self-evident on the pleadings.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Secondly, UWA had maintained at all times that the conditions of Substantial Success would be satisfied.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 21 Sirtex was a public company.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: There was no question of its solvency at the time the open offer was made nor any need for security to be provided to support its offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Sirtex submitted that in substance it was offering UWA a very substantial sum to resolve the matter as between them on a condition that UWA have Substantial Success against the alleged primary wrong doer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: This was in circumstances where UWA had secured the potential fruits of any judgment against Gray and CRI.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 22 Sirtex referred to the dates at which affidavits of evidence were filed.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA's affidavits in chief were filed on 5 December 2006.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Dr Gray's affidavit in chief was filed on 31 January 2007 and Sirtex's affidavits on 20 and 21 December 2006.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA, it said, had nearly three months to consider Sirtex's evidence and six weeks to consider Dr Gray's evidence before the Sirtex offer was made.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The evidence referred to, it was said, should clearly have indicated to UWA that its case against Sirtex was hopeless.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It was said to be clear on the evidence that:  1.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: There was no implied contractual term conferring an interest on UWA in respect of intellectual property developed by Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Although Dr Gray was conducting research for the benefit of some entity other than UWA there was no claim against him for breach of fiduciary duty on that account.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA had no capacity to alienate or interfere with substantive property rights by regulation.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The Intellectual Property Regulations were not promulgated at the relevant time.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA had repeatedly failed to make a timely claim against Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Professor Barber's reply to the Gorn letter was written in his capacity as Acting Vice Chancellor.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA adopted a deliberate strategy of withholding knowledge of a potential claim.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Sirtex was not put on notice of the claim until October 2004.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The claim, when finally made, was misleading.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA advanced for the first time in its closing submissions the contention that Sirtex was a volunteer but then decided not to press the submission.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA could not rely on Dr Gray's knowledge to claim against Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: This factor depends upon submissions on which no finding was made.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: There was no answer to Sirtex's defences based on estoppel, laches and delay.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The relief sought by UWA was untenable.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 23 The preceding considerations were in part derived from findings made in the judgment.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Some aspects involving UWA's reliance upon Dr Gray's knowledge to support its claim against Sirtex and the absence of any "answer" to defences based on estoppel, laches and delay reflect an assumption that Sirtex would have succeeded in relation to those matters.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That is not to say they would not have succeeded.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: However there was no determination of those matters in the judgment.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 24 Sirtex submitted that to the extent that it had incurred costs on and after the closure of its open offer on 19 March 2007 commensurately Dr Gray's exposure under the cross-claim had increased.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: If the Court were to accept its submissions that UWA's refusal to accept its offer was unreasonable, then it only seemed appropriate that the extra costs fall at the feet of UWA rather than Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 25 In justification of its conduct in refusing to accept the Sirtex offer, UWA made the following points:  1.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The sum offered was inclusive of costs and made shortly prior to the commencement of the trial at which time the parties had already incurred very substantial costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It was difficult for UWA to ascertain what, if any, amount was attributed in the offer to the value of its claims and what amount, if any, attributed to costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: There was a real difficulty in ascertaining the value of the offer so as to compare it to the value of the relief claimed against Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: A calculation of the value of the offer required UWA to assign values to the amount offered and the likelihood of various contingencies.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The sum offered did not vary according to the extent of UWA's success.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The sum offered was contingent upon UWA succeeding in its claims against Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In the circumstances that have arisen where UWA failed against Dr Gray and Sirtex failed in its cross-claim against UWA, UWA is only worse off than it would have been if it had accepted the offer in that it has now been ordered to pay Sirtex's costs of the trial except insofar as they are referable to the costs of Sirtex's cross-claim against Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Regardless of whether the offer was accepted by UWA, Sirtex would still have been an active participant in the trial by reason of its cross-claim against Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The time for payment did not arise until after the conclusion of any appeal or time for appeal.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The Court had not had occasion to consider the relief to which UWA would have been entitled if it had succeeded in establishing liability.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The offer was made on the eve of the trial and was expressed to be open for acceptance for a period of five days, representing in total three business days.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 26 Sirtex's submissions in reply, filed on 1 July 2008, referred to various cases for the proposition that in assessing the reasonableness of an offer the Court should have regard to the ultimate analysis by the Court of uncontroversial facts.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The finding that there was an implication of law in Dr Gray's employment was based on essentially uncontroversial facts.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 27 In relation to the contingency attached to the offer, Sirtex observed that UWA's case against it was necessarily a contingent one.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The offer, if accepted, would have involved a real compromise on both sides:  (a) In a trial the size of the trial in these proceedings, the costs would be very substantial.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It would have been a major compromise for Sirtex to forego its right to costs to that date from UWA.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: (b) UWA was plainly materially worse off for having rejected Sirtex's offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It is liable for Sirtex's costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It has no chance of obtaining a payment of $1.5 million or an equivalent value of Sirtex shares.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It has appealed against the dismissal of its application against Dr Gray and regards itself as entitled to succeed against him.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In those circumstances, it was submitted UWA could not say it was not worse off.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA had argued that it improved its position by running the trial because it succeeded against Sirtex in respect of Sirtex's cross-claims.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: But that cross-claim only arose if UWA succeeded in any of its claims.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 28 Sirtex submitted there was no uncertainty as to the meaning of "Substantial Success" in the proposed Deed.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The suggestion of uncertainty was only raised by UWA for the first time on 3 June 2008.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It did not suggest in March 2007 that it had any difficulty understanding the offer that had been put.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: As to the date from which indemnity costs should be ordered, and in the light of Mr Price's correcting affidavit of 3 June 2008, that UWA rejected Sirtex's offer on 15 March 2007, it was submitted that UWA should pay indemnity costs from that date.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Whether indemnity costs should be awarded  29 There have been a considerable number of decisions in the Federal Court and other courts about when indemnity costs will be awarded following the rejection of an open offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Many of these cases turn on their own facts.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The starting point for consideration of the motion is the discretion in relation to costs conferred upon the Court by s 43 of the Federal Court Act.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 30 Ordinarily that discretion will be exercised so that costs follow the event and are awarded on a party and party basis.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: A departure from normal practice to award indemnity costs requires some special or unusual feature in the case: Alpine Hardwood (Aust) Pty Ltd v Hardys Pty Ltd (No 2) [2002] FCA 224 ; (2002) 190 ALR 121 at [11] (Weinberg J) citing Colgate Palmolive Co v Cussons Pty Ltd (1993) 46 FCR 225 at 233 (Sheppard J).

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 31 Order 23 provides for offers of compromise.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In this case it was not suggested that the Sirtex offer complied with the requirements of O 23.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In any event that Order is not a code.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 32 The general principles governing the exercise of the discretion to award indemnity costs after rejection by an unsuccessful party of a so called Calderbank letter were set out in the judgment of the Full Court in Black v Lipovac [1998] FCA 699 ; (1998) 217 ALR 386.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In summary those principles are:  1.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Mere refusal of a "Calderbank offer" does not itself warrant an order for indemnity costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In this connection it may be noted that Jessup J in Dais Studio Pty Ltd v Bullet Creative Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 42 said that (at [6]):    if the rejection of such an offer is to ground a claim for indemnity costs, it must be by reason of some circumstance other than that the offer happened to comply with the Calderbank principle.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: To obtain an order for indemnity costs the offeror must show that the refusal to accept it was unreasonable.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The reasonableness of the conduct of the offeree is to be viewed in the light of the circumstances that existed when the offer was rejected.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 33 The preceding general principles inform the exercise of the discretion.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That discretion is not to be fettered by transformation of approaches and practices developed through the cases into quasi statutory rules.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In John S Hayes amp; Associates Pty Ltd v Kimberly-Clark Australia Pty Ltd (1994) 52 FCR 201 , Hill J said (at 203):  care must be taken not to circumscribe the discretion by reference to closed categories.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It is not a necessary condition of the power to award costs that a collateral purpose be shown.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The categories warranting the exercise of the discretion are not closed ... See also Goldberg J in Dr Martens Australia Pty Ltd v Figgins Holdings Pty Ltd (No 2) [2000] FCA 602 at [15] .

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 34 I accept that the making of a rolled up offer inclusive of costs and interest may detract from the weight to be given to its refusal in the exercise of the discretion.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Finn J referred to authorities on the point in GEC Marconi Systems Pty Ltd v BHP Information Technology Pty Ltd [2003] FCA 688 ; (2003) 201 ALR 55 at [34] .

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: His Honour cited single judge decisions to the effect that such offers ought not to be a relevant consideration on the question of costs and would not be considered in the same way as a Calderbank letter.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: His Honour was invited to depart from that line of first instance authority.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: However he was not prepared to say it was clearly wrong.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Notwithstanding that, in the circumstances of the case he had to decide, his Honour found that:  The fact that the offer gave no indication at all of the breakdown ... between the claim, interest and costs blunts significantly the weight to be given the offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 35 While respecting the general approach to rolled up offers reflected in the cases to which Finn J referred, such approaches cannot be calcified into rules of law which fetter a general discretion.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: They simply reflect a common sense proposition that generally speaking such an offer is not unreasonably refused.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: There may, however, be circumstances where a rolled up offer, refused by an applicant who is unsuccessful, may support a claim for indemnity costs.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 36 On the question of the level of unreasonableness necessary to attract the discretion, I respectfully agree with the comment of Sackville J in Seven Network Limited v News Limited (2007) 244 ALR 374 at [62] questioning the utility of substituting a requirement that rejection be "plainly unreasonable" for the requirement that it be "unreasonable".

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Given the evaluative character of the judgment involved the addition of the word "plainly" which is itself evaluative, has no useful function.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 37 At the time that Sirtex made its offer to UWA the prospect of UWA succeeding against Sirtex depended critically upon:  1.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA establishing its case against Dr Gray and, in particular, that he had breached his fiduciary duty.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: UWA establishing that Sirtex was accessorially liable in relation to that breach, a position that depended upon establishing that Sirtex was aware of facts constituting (and which would have indicated to a reasonable person) the breach of fiduciary duties owed by Dr Gray to UWA.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 38 It cannot be said that UWA acted unreasonably in proceeding on the basis that it had a reasonable cause of action against Dr Gray.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: True it is that the case as framed and presented depended upon an important proposition of law as to the existence of an implied term in the contract of Dr Gray's employment with UWA.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: But the correctness of that proposition had not previously been tested in Australia in circumstances of the kind which arose in this case.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: This is not a case, in my opinion, in which it is appropriate to take a hindsight test to the facts known to UWA at the time of Sirtex's offer and conclude that it ought to have known that the law was against it.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 39 There were of course other hazards in the way of UWA's path to success against Dr Gray and therefore against Sirtex.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The question whether the relevant inventions were made while Dr Gray was an employee of UWA was one issue upon which findings adverse to UWA were made on all but the DOX-Spheres technology.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: There was also a finding adverse to UWA that none of the Sirtex directors, apart from Dr Gray, were on notice of a potential claim.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: To establish any cause of action against Sirtex based on knowing involvement in his alleged breaches of fiduciary duty would have depended entirely upon his role as a director of Sirtex and whether his knowledge could be attributed to that company.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In addition, UWA faced substantial defences by Sirtex based on UWA's delay in commencing proceedings after it first became aware of the facts relevant to its claimed causes of action.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 40 The preceding factors may be seen as weighing to some degree in favour of the Sirtex motion.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: On the other hand the offer came as the trial commenced.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That is a factor, given the focus on the trial process which would then have existed, that militates against a finding of unreasonableness on the part of UWA in refusing the offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: That conclusion is not affected by the fact that Sirtex was making a counter-offer.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The counter-offer was not a variation on a theme opened by UWA's offers.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: It was quite different and could have been proposed earlier.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 41 It is also relevant that the offer made no break-up between recovery and costs and interest.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: To that extent its refusal is less readily able to be characterised as unreasonable.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 42 UWA was entering into a complex piece of commercial litigation.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The initial letter of demand to Sirtex indicated a level of confidence which was unrealistic given those complexities.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: But that unrealistic level of confidence does not mean that it did not have an arguable case.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: 43 There is a mix of factors in this case which are related to the exercise of the discretion which Sirtex seeks to invoke.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Some point one way, some another.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: In the end I am not persuaded that the refusal of the Sirtex offer by UWA was so unreasonable in the circumstances that I ought to award indemnity costs against it.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: The motion for indemnity costs will be dismissed.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: I certify that the preceding forty-three (43) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice French.

Name: University of Western Australia v Gray (No 21) [2008] FCA 1056 (16 July 2008)
text: Associate:Dated: 16 July 2008 Counsel for the Applicant: Mr M Zilko SC with Mr D Pratt   Solicitor for the Applicant: Jackson McDonald Counsel for the First Respondent: Mr M Bennett Solicitor for the First Respondent: Lavan Legal   Counsel for the Second Respondent: Mr JD Elliott SC with Mr EJC Heerey and Mr JS Emmett   Solicitor for the Second Respondent: Yeldham Price O'Brien Lusk  Date of Hearing: 3 and 23 June 2008   Date of Judgment: 16 July 2008     AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2008/1056.html

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: judicial review

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: application brought pursuant to administrative decisions (judicial review) act 1977 (adjr act) to review decision of respondent

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: objection to competency of application

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: whether decision open to review

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: meaning of 'decision' under adjr act

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: whether substantive determination

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: whether applicant has standing to bring application

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: administrative law

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: INTRODUCTION  The applicant seeks review of the respondent's decision under s 5 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (Cth) (ADJR Act).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The decision in question is that of the respondent, an employee of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The applicant has issued four other sets of proceedings against individual officers of the ATO.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The events with which each proceeding is concerned are related.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The reasoning on determination of each proceeding is also similar.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The respondent objects to the competency of the application on the basis that the decision the subject of the application was a decision making or forming part of the process of making assessments under the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999 (Cth) (GST Act) and is excluded by Sch 1 of the ADJR Act.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: GROUNDS OF REVIEW  The grounds upon which the applicant seeks review are numerous and reflect those appearing under s 5 of the ADJR Act.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: They are as follows:  (a) that a breach of the rules of natural justice occurred in connection with the making of the decision; (b) that procedures that were required by law to be observed in connection with the making of the decision were not observed; (c) that the decision was not authorized by the enactment in pursuance of which it was purported to be made; (d) that the making of the decision was an improper exercise of the power conferred by the enactment in pursuance of which it was purported to be made; (e) that the decision involved an error of law, whether or not the error appears on the record of the decision; (f) that there was no evidence or other material to justify the making of the decision; (g) that the decision was otherwise contrary to law.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: BACKGROUND  The applicant is the director, public officer and shareholder of the company Ivyside Pty Ltd (Ivyside).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Ivyside claimed GST input tax credits with respect to various purchases in relation to the company.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: On 22 May 2007, the respondent advised the applicant that the claims at 'label G11' on his activity statement for the period July to September 2006 would be disallowed because valid tax invoices were not produced to substantiate the amount of GST credits claimed.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The ATO subsequently issued the applicant notices pursuant to s 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (Cth) (ITAA 1936) and s 353- 10 of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 (Cth) (TAA).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: On or around 3 October 2007, the ATO issued the applicant an amended assessment and penalties for the July to September quarter of 2006.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: COMPLAINT  In this matter, the complaint raised is as to the disallowance of the GST entitlements for the July-September quarter of 2006 'such entitlements being bona fide ones that should be allowed'.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The applicant asserts that the decision of the respondent included 'purposeful mental and emotional pain and suffering the respondent is inflicting on the applicant; the applicant seeks relief from this harassment; oppression; and unlawful activities of the respondent'.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: However, in the affidavit in support of the application, the applicant clarifies that the decision of which he is seeking review was the decision by the respondent to deny and refuse him the right to an informal review of a GST issue relating to Ivyside.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: He stresses in his affidavit that it is not the original decision made by the respondent to disallow the GST entitlements but rather the decision to deny and refuse him an informal review.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In support of that claim he annexes a document entitled 'Having your GST issue reviewed'.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: That document under the heading 'Informal Reviews' reads:  You can request an informal review of the GST decision we made or GST advice we provided, including private rulings.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Generally, an informal review is conducted by an officer who is not involved in the original decision.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: We will advise you of the outcome of the review, which could include changing the decision or advice, or confirming it.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: If you'd like to request an informal review, you should contact the person handling your case or the office where the decision was made.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The applicant also annexes a document apparently comprising a notification on behalf of Ivyside that it is seeking an order for review of the joint decision of the respondent and other officers of the ATO not to provide the company with an informal review of the audit which had been conducted.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: This communication was apparently sent by email on 2 January 2008.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The applicant also annexes a much earlier letter from the ATO (23 August 1999) in which an apology is extended for distress and inconvenience which had been caused to the applicant and his wife in previous dealings.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Assuming that the basis on which review is sought in this matter is a refusal to grant an informal review, the respondent complains that there is no evidence of a request for an informal review and there had been no agreement to conduct an informal review.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: More importantly, even if there had been such an agreement, a failure to do so would not constitute a decision as defined in s 3(1) and s 3(2) of the ADJR Act as no substantive rights would be affected by such a decision.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The annexure appears to relate to refusal to provide an informal review of 'the audit ... conducted', again of which there is no evidence.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: APPROACH TO COMPETENCY CHALLENGE  The Court has jurisdiction to determine that it has no jurisdiction in respect of a proceeding instituted in the Court and to dismiss the proceeding accordingly ( Residual Assco Group Ltd v Spalvins [2000] HCA 33 ; (2000) 202 CLR 629 at [14] ).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: As observed in Mirvac Homes (NSW) Pty Limited v Airservices Australia (No 1) [2004] FCA 109 by Branson J, the provision in the Federal Court Rules for the filing and service of a notice of objection to competency is intended to encourage a respondent to inform the applicant promptly that the jurisdiction of the Court is in issue.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The filing of a notice of objection to competency also places the Court on notice that its jurisdiction to make the orders sought by the applicant in the proceeding is challenged.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The Court must then decide, before it makes the orders sought by the applicant or any substantive orders, whether it has jurisdiction to proceed ( R v Federal Court of Australia; Ex parte WA National Football League [1979] HCA 6 ; (1979) 143 CLR 190).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In Bray v F Hoffman-La Roche Ltd (2003) 130 FCR 317 , Finkelstein J at [239] expressed the view that, where an issue which is properly characterised as jurisdictional is raised, it should be dealt with at the outset although a different approach was taken in Khatri v Price [1999] FCA 1289 ; (1999) 95 FCR 287 per Katz J at [14]).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Whether or not it is necessary to resolve the jurisdictional issue at the outset, it appears to me that the current jurisdictional argument is succinct and independent in the sense that it can be resolved without any other evidentiary enquiry.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: If the argument is correct, there seems no obvious reason in this case why consideration of the jurisdictional challenge should be further deferred.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Deferral has not been sought by the applicant.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: (As distinct from raising opposition to the objection).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The applicant complains that for a period of 9 years between 1990 and 1999 the Commissioner of Taxation (the Commissioner) caused distress to him and his wife by failing to meet the requirements of the ATO Taxpayer's Charter.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The applicant relied upon a written apology from the Commissioner dated 23 August 1999.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: That communication thanks the applicant for taking the time to contact the 'Problem Resolution Service' about legal action being taken against the applicant and his wife.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It continues:  I am satisfied that the ATO failed to meet this requirement and I sincerely apologise for the distress and inconvenience this has caused you and your wife.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Details relating to specific ATO officers have been referred to their manager for appropriate action.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In addition, I have recommended the ATO procedures that brought about the legal action in your case be reviewed to ensure this type of problem does not occur again in the future.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The applicant complains that had the respondent acted pursuant to the Taxpayers' Charter towards him and in accordance with the assurance given in the Commissioner's written apology that he would not be aggrieved by the oppressive actions of the respondent continuing to act in breach of the Charter and abusing his power.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: STATUTORY FRAMEWORK  Section 5 of the ADJR Act relevantly provides as follows:  5 Applications for review of decisions   (1) A person who is aggrieved by a decision to which this Act applies that is made after the commencement of this Act may apply to the Federal Court or the Federal Magistrates Court for an order of review in respect of the decision on any one or more of the following grounds: (a) that a breach of the rules of natural justice occurred in connection with the making of the decision; (b) that procedures that were required by law to be observed in connection with the making of the decision were not observed; (c) that the person who purported to make the decision did not have jurisdiction to make the decision; (d) that the decision was not authorized by the enactment in pursuance of which it was purported to be made; (e) that the making of the decision was an improper exercise of the power conferred by the enactment in pursuance of which it was purported to be made; (f) that the decision involved an error of law, whether or not the error appears on the record of the decision; (g) that the decision was induced or affected by fraud; (h) that there was no evidence or other material to justify the making of the decision; (j) that the decision was otherwise contrary to law.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: (2) The reference in paragraph (1)(e) to an improper exercise of a power shall be construed as including a reference to: (a) taking an irrelevant consideration into account in the exercise of a power; (b) failing to take a relevant consideration into account in the exercise of a power; (c) an exercise of a power for a purpose other than a purpose for which the power is conferred; (d) an exercise of a discretionary power in bad faith; (e) an exercise of a personal discretionary power at the direction or behest of another person; (f) an exercise of a discretionary power in accordance with a rule or policy without regard to the merits of the particular case; (g) an exercise of a power that is so unreasonable that no reasonable person could have so exercised the power; (h) an exercise of a power in such a way that the result of the exercise of the power is uncertain; and (j) any other exercise of a power in a way that constitutes abuse of the power.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: (3) The ground specified in paragraph (1)(h) shall not be taken to be made out unless: (a) the person who made the decision was required by law to reach that decision only if a particular matter was established, and there was no evidence or other material (including facts of which he or she was entitled to take notice) from which he or she could reasonably be satisfied that the matter was established; or (b) the person who made the decision based the decision on the existence of a particular fact, and that fact did not exist.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Relevantly, s 3 of the ADJR Act identifies the decisions to which the Act applies as a 'decision of an administrative character made, proposed to be made, or required to be made (whether in the exercise of a discretion or not and whether before or after the commencement of this definition)':  (a) under an enactment referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c) or (d) of the definition of enactment; or (b) by a Commonwealth authority or an officer of the Commonwealth under an enactment referred to in paragraph (ca) or (cb) of the definition of enactment; other than: (c) a decision by the Governor-General; or (d) a decision included in any of the classes of decisions set out in Schedule 1.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: By s 3(d) the definition of 'decision to which this Act applies' is narrowed by the exclusion of decisions included in any of the class of decisions set out in Sch 1.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Schedule 1 of the ADJR Act relevantly provides:  Schedule 1---Classes of decisions that are not decisions to which this Act applies  ... (e) decisions making, or forming part of the process of making, or leading up to the making of, assessments or calculations of tax, charge or duty, or decisions disallowing objections to assessments or calculations of tax, charge or duty, or decisions amending, or refusing to amend, assessments or calculations of tax, charge or duty, under any of the following Acts:   A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999   A New Tax System (Luxury Car Tax) Act 1999   A New Tax System (Wine Equalisation Tax) Act 1999   Customs Act 1901   Customs Tariff Act 1995   Excise Act 1901   Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986   Fuel Tax Act 2006   Income Tax Assessment Act 1936   Income Tax Assessment Act 1997   Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987   Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992   Taxation Administration Act 1953 , but only so far as the decisions are made under Part 3 - 10 in Schedule 1 to that Act  Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990   Trust Recoupment Tax Assessment Act 1985 ;    ...   Note: Subdivision B deals with the making, reduction and revocation of estimates of certain liabilities.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: (f) decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation under subsection 3E(1), 3G(1) or 3H(1) of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 ;   (g) decisions under Part IV of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 ;   (ga) decisions under section 14ZY of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 disallowing objections to assessments or calculations of tax, charge or duty; ...  CONTENTIONS  The Respondent The respondent originally contended that the decision complained of by the applicant formed part of the process of making, or refusing to amend a calculation of tax under the GST Act.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Therefore, the decision by the Commissioner to disallow GST input credits claimed by Ivyside would be excluded pursuant to Sch 1(e) of the ADJR Act.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Accordingly the substituted ground of the alleged refusal to conduct an informal review would not be a 'decision' at all.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The Applicant The applicant asserts that the Court does have jurisdiction to hear the matter.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: He contends that the respondent's decision or conduct is reviewable in this Court and it falls within the class of decisions to which the ADJR Act applies.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: RELEVANT PRINCIPLES  Pursuant to s 8 of the ADJR Act, the Court has jurisdiction to hear and determine applications made under the ADJR Act.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Section 5 of the ADJR Act provides that a person aggrieved by a decision to which the Act applies may apply to the Court for an order of review on certain grounds.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Section 6 of the ADJR Act provides for review of conduct, engaged in, being engaged in or proposed to be engaged in for the purpose of making a decision to which the ADJR Act applies.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It is apparent from the definition of 'decision to which this Act applies' in s 3 of the ADJR Act that the Act only applies where there is a making of, proposal to make or requirement to make a decision, the decision is of an administrative character, and the decision is made under an enactment.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In Australian Broadcasting Tribunal v Bond [1990] HCA 33 ; (1990) 170 CLR 321 (at 335), Mason CJ discussed the meaning of 'decision' under s 3 of the ADJR Act and held (relevantly) (citations omitted):  (1) Meaning of "Decision"   The definition in s.3(1) does not elucidate significantly the meaning of the word "decision" as it is used in the A.D.(J.R.) Act.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It is clear that a "decision to which this Act applies" must be a decision of an administrative character, that it may be made in the exercise of a discretion, and that it must be made under an enactment.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: But these characteristics provide little guidance as to the meaning of the word "decision" upon which the definition in s.3(1) is based.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: ...   Nonetheless other considerations point to the word having a relatively limited field of operation .

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: First, the reference in the definition in s.3(1) to "a decision of an administrative character made ... under an enactment" indicates that a reviewable decision is a decision which a statute requires or authorizes rather than merely a step taken in the course of reasoning on the way to the making of the ultimate decision.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Secondly, the examples of decision listed in the extended definition contained in s.3(2) are also indicative of a decision having the character or quality of finality, an outcome reflecting something in the nature of a determination of an application, inquiry or dispute or, in the words of Deane J., "a determination effectively resolving an actual substantive issue ".

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Thirdly, s.3(3), in extending the concept of "decision" to include "the making of a report or recommendation before a decision is made in the exercise of a power", to that extent qualifies the characteristic of finality.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Such a provision would have been unnecessary had the Parliament intended that "decision" comprehend every decision, or every substantive decision, made in the course of reaching a conclusive determination.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Finally, s.3(5) suggests that acts done preparatory to the making of a "decision" are not to be regarded as constituting "decisions" for, if they were, there would be little, if any, point in providing for judicial review of "conduct" as well as of a "decision ".

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The relevant policy considerations are competing.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: On the one hand, the purposes of the A.D.(J.R.) Act are to allow persons aggrieved by the administrative decision-making processes of government a convenient and effective means of redress and to enhance those processes.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: On the other hand, in so far as the ambit of the concept of "decision" is extended, there is a greater risk that the efficient administration of government will be impaired.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Although Bowen C.J. and Lockhart J. appeared to emphasize the first of these considerations in Australian National University v. Burns , there comes a point when the second must prevail, as their Honours implicitly acknowledged.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: To interpret "decision" in a way that would involve a departure from the quality of finality would lead to a fragmentation of the processes of administrative decision-making and set at risk the efficiency of the administrative process.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: ...   Another essential quality of a reviewable decision is that it be a substantive determination .

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: With the exception of s.3(2)(g), the instances of decision mentioned in s.3(2) are all substantive in character.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Moreover, the provisions in sub-ss.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: (1), (2), (3) and (5) of s.3 point to a substantive determination.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In this context the reference in s.3(2)(g) to "doing or refusing to do any other act or thing " (emphasis added) should be read as referring to the exercise or refusal to exercise a substantive power.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: I do not perceive in s.16(1)(b) or in par.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: (e) of Sched.1 or par.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: (a) of Sched.2 to the A.D.(J.R.) Act any contrary implication.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: These exclusions from the A.D.(J.R.) Act or from s.13 appear to have been introduced for more abundant caution and it would be unwise to take too much from them.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: (emphasis added)  Despite the clarity of the passage from the learned Chief Justice, application of the principles has not been without difficulty.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
