text: Views on whether or not particular decisions or conduct constitutes a reviewable decision have not always been unanimous (for example, Guss v Federal Commissioner of Taxation [2006] FCAFC 88 ; (2006) 152 FCR 88).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Not only are there questions as to whether conduct constitutes a decision but also whether it is a decision taken under an enactment.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: For a decision to be reviewable it must be one 'for which provision is made by or under a statute', the provision should be more specific than general (for example, Hutchins v Commissioner of Taxationn (1996) 65 FCR 269 and Electricity Supply Assn of Australia Ltd v Australian Competition amp; Consumer Commission [2001] FCA 1296 ; (2001) 113 FCR 230).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: A general authorisation for a body to act in a certain way is not usually regarded as being sufficient to qualify a decision as being one made under an enactment: Salerno v National Crime Authority (1997) 75 FCR 133.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Dealing with the enactment aspect, the majority of the High Court in Griffith University v Tang [2005] HCA 7 ; (2005) 221 CLR 99 held (at [89]) that:  The determination of whether a decision is "made ... under an enactment" involves two criteria: first, the decision must be expressly or impliedly required or authorised by the enactment; and, secondly, the decision must itself confer, alter or otherwise affect legal rights or obligations, and in that sense the decision must derive from the enactment.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: A decision will only be "made ... under an enactment" if both these criteria are met.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It should be emphasised that this construction of the statutory definition does not require the relevant decision to affect or alter existing rights or obligations, and it will be sufficient that the enactment requires or authorises decisions from which new rights or obligations arise.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Similarly, it is not necessary that the relevantly affected legal rights owe their existence to the enactment in question.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Affection of rights or obligations derived from the general law or statute will suffice.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Indeed the High Court went on to observe that even though a decision taken may have a critical effect for the operation of the federal statute, if it is a decision made 'dehors' the federal statute, it would be un-reviewable.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: CONSIDERATION  In the present circumstances, although the decision of which complaint was originally made was carried out pursuant to statutory power, it does not constitute, in my view, a decision in the sense contemplated in s 3 of the ADJR Act or as explained by the Chief Justice in Bond [1990] HCA 33 ; 170 CLR 321.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Nor does the alleged refusal to informally review.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In the language of Fox ACJ in Evans v Friemann (1981) 35 ALR 428 at 431 the relevant decision or conduct did not constitute a decision which was final and conclusive for immediate purposes at least.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It was not the ultimate or operative determination of an issue as distinct from the determination of issues arising in the course of making such an ultimate decision ( Social Services, Director-General of v Chaney [1980] FCA 87 ; (1980) 31 ALR 571).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The best guidance for this is the clear language of Mason CJ in Bond [1990] HCA 33 ; 170 CLR 321 that the decision will generally but not always entail a decision which is final or operative and determinative, at least in a practical sense and a conclusion reached that is a step along the way in the course of reasoning leading to an ultimate decision would not ordinarily amount to a reviewable decision unless the statute provided for the making of a finding or ruling on that point so that the decision, though an indeterminate decision, might accurately be described as a decision under an enactment.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: When it comes to the consideration of policy, the competing policies on the one hand of permitting aggrieved persons to challenge administrative decisions and on the other, enabling efficient administration of government processes provides some guidance.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: If the legislation has provided other means of challenging decisions rather than judicial review under the ADJR Act, at least insofar as policy is concerned, availability of a right of challenge is not withheld.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In Century Yuasa Batteries Pty Ltd v Commissioner of Taxation (1997) 73 FCR 528 it was held that the Commissioner's decision to seek to recover an amount equal to withholding tax and penalty for late payment due by the applicant and the demand for payment of those sums was not reviewable because it did not constitute a substantive determination.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: This was because it lacked the necessary element of finality as liability for payment of those sums arose from the operation of the ITAA 1936 and not in consequence of any reviewable decision of the Commissioner.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: His Honour said (at 540-541):  Section 221YR(1) (the Commissioner's power to sue for the money as a debt due to the Commonwealth) and s 8 (the Commissioner's power of general administration of the ITAA) do not of themselves give force or effect to the decision to demand payment of a sum of money which the Commissioner claims is payable under the ITAA and as such it is not a decision made under an enactment ( Hutchins v Commissioner of Taxation (1996) 65 FCR 269 at 273 per Black CJ and at 278-279 per Spender J).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Even if the view of Lockhart J in Hutchins v Commissioner of Taxation is adopted, namely that the power of the Commissioner to sue for the recovery of the amount due as a debt to the Commonwealth authorises the Commissioner to do all things reasonably necessary to recover the amount and thereby characterises the demand as a decision of an administrative character made under an enactment (at 276-277), that does not of itself make the demand a reviewable decision.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The decision to seek to recover an amount equal to the withholding tax and penalty for late payment from the applicant, and the demand for payment of the same within 14 days, is not a substantive determination.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It determines nothing.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: As such the decision lacks a necessary characteristic of a reviewable decision ( Bond at 337; Hutchins at 274, 277).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Nor does the demand have any practical effect on the applicant.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: If the demand is not met by the applicant because of an erroneous view that it is not liable to make the payment, any liability for additional tax for late payment arises from the operation of the ITAA and not in consequence of any reviewable decision of the Commissioner.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: And as held in Ruddy v Commissioner of Taxation (1998) 82 FCR 337 , the decision to sue for recovery was not a decision on an important substantive issue which was the essence of an ultimate decision which would have far-reaching consequences.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It is not final or determinative because it does not remove a benefit or expose an applicant to detriment to which it is not already subject.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Equally, Cooper J held in Golden City Car amp; Truck Centre Pty Ltd v Deputy Federal Commissioner of Taxation (1999) 56 ALD 177 , a decision to commence proceedings for recovery of tax due under the ITAA 1936 is not a reviewable decision.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: See also Madera v Commissioner of Taxation [2004] FCA 1616 ; (2004) 141 FCR 95 at [21] per Stone J (at [18]-[22]).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In relation to the alternative ground advanced for the respondent, it is contended that what is sought is a review of the decision which formed part of the process of making or refusing to amend the calculation of tax under the GST Act and as such, it is a decision not capable of review under the ADJR Act being excluded by the provisions of Sch 1(e).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The respondent contends that to the extent reliance is placed on the decision of the disallowance of claimed GST input credits, any decision taken in that regard (by the Commissioner rather than the respondent) would fall within the exclusion provisions due to the course of dealings between the parties) ( Bennett Honda Pty Ltd v Deputy Commissioner of Taxation [1984] FCA 414 ; (1984) 4 FCR 99 per Morling J).

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The respondent stresses that Ivyside (as distinct from the applicant) has appellate procedures available to it in respect of the decision made by or on behalf of the Commissioner to disallow GST input tax credits claimed.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It is for that reason that all components of the decisions by the officers of the ATO charged with making that decision are not susceptible to review under the ADJR Act as they fall within the parameters of par e to Sch 1.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: CONCLUSION  The original complaint was the purported infliction of pain on the applicant by disallowing GST entitlements.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The revised complaint is as to the refusal of the internal review to discuss the issue.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: In my view, the alleged actions or conduct of which complaint has been raised by the applicant did not constitute a decision of a reviewable nature within the meaning of the ADJR Act and the authorities.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: There was no substantive determination.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: There was no decision having the character or quality of finality and the actions taken, even accepting for purposes that they had the quality asserted by the applicant, simply formed part of a process of leading up to the making of a decision by the Commissioner to disallow the claimed GST input credits claimed by Ivyside.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: It was not a decision which affected in any way or in any direct sense the applicant's legal rights and obligations.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Further and as a distinct ground, even if there were an appropriate basis for review, it could be advanced only by the company, Ivyside not by the applicant.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: However, if this were the only issue standing in the way of the competency of this application, I may have granted any application to amend the identity of the applicant, or for that matter, the respondent.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The difficulty with the competency of the application however, in my view, is much more fundamental, going to jurisdiction.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The respondent's jurisdictional objection to competency must be upheld and the claim dismissed.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: The applicant is to pay the costs of the respondent to be taxed if not agreed.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: I certify that the preceding thirty-nine (39) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice McKerracher.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Associate:  Dated: 25 August 2009  The Applicant represented himself.

Name: Parker v Parker [2009] FCA 930 (25 August 2009)
text: Counsel for the Respondent: TP Burrows   Solicitor for the Respondent: Australian Government Solicitor  Date of Hearing: 25 March 2009   Date of Last Written Submissions: 6 May 2009   Date of Judgment: 25 August 2009    AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2009/930.html

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: interlocutory injunction

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: quia timet injunction

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: whether serious question to be tried

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: whether applicant likely to suffer injury for which damages will not be an adequate remedy

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: whether balance of convenience favours the granting of injunction

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: alleged contravention of s 52 of trade practices act 1974 (cth)

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: practice and procedure

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 1 The applicant, CSL Limited ("CSL"), seeks an interlocutory injunction to restrain the respondent, GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd ("GSKA"), from making certain representations concerning GARDASIL, a vaccine marketed by CSL, and CERVARIX, a vaccine which GSKA hopes to market in Australia in the near future.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 2 CSL carries on business developing, manufacturing, selling and supplying in Australia plasma products, antivenoms and human vaccines.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: GSKA markets throughout Australia a range of pharmaceutical products including vaccines.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 3 The products at the centre of this dispute are vaccines used for the prevention of infection caused by Human Papillomavirus ("HPV").

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: More particularly, they are vaccines which are administered to prevent certain types of cancer.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The background facts   4 GARDASIL is the world's first cervical cancer vaccine.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is, at present, the only such vaccine approved in Australia.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It prevents cervical cancer and other HPV related cancers and diseases caused by HPV types 6, 11, 16 and 18.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It was developed following collaboration between CSL and Professor Ian Frazer, who is well-known for his groundbreaking research in this area, and was named Australian of the Year in 2006.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The vaccine has achieved widespread recognition.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 5 In 1995, CSL granted an exclusive worldwide licence of its proprietary technology to Merck amp; Co., Inc. which conducted substantial research leading to the development of GARDASIL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: On 14 December 2005, Merck Sharp amp; Dohme (Australia) Pty Ltd lodged an application with the Therapeutic Goods Authority ("the TGA") for marketing approval for GARDASIL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: On 16 June 2006, the TGA granted that approval.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The TGA also granted CSL approval to use what is described as the "GARDASIL Product Information Sheet", a document containing technical information regarding the nature and effect of the vaccine.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 6 The Product Information Sheet describes GARDASIL as a recombinant, quadrivalent vaccine:   "The quadrivalent Human Papillomavirus Virus-Like Particle vaccine (HPV VLP vaccine) is a sterile liquid suspension prepared from the highly purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the recombinant major capsid (L1) protein of HPV Types 6, 11, 16 and 18.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The L1 proteins are produced by separate fermentations in recombinant Saccharomyces cerevisiae CANADE 3C-5 (Strain 1895) and self-assembled into VLPs.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The VLPs for each type are purified and adsorbed on aluminum-containing adjuvant (amorphous aluminum hydroxyphosphate sulfate).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The quadrivalent HPV VLP vaccine is prepared by combining the adsorbed VLPs of each HPV type, the aluminum-containing adjuvant formulation, and a buffer.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: GARDASIL is a sterile preparation for intramuscular administration.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Each 0.5-mL dose contains approximately 20 mcg of HPV 6 L1 protein, 40 mcg of HPV 11 L1 protein, 40 mcg of HPV 16 L1 protein, and 20 mcg of HPV 18 L1 protein.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Each 0.5-mL dose of the vaccine contains approximately 225 mcg of aluminum (as amorphous aluminum hydroxyphosphate sulfate adjuvant), 9.56 mg of sodium chloride, 0.78 mg of L-histidine, 50 mcg of polysorbate 80, 35 mcg of sodium borate, and water for injection.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The product does not contain a preservative or antibiotics.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: "    7 GARDASIL is "indicated" in females aged 9 to 26 years for the prevention of cervical, vulvar, and vaginal cancer, precancerous or dysplastic lesions, genital warts, and infection caused by HPV types 6, 11, 16 and 18 (which are included in the vaccine).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is also indicated in males aged 9 to 15 years for the prevention of infection caused by HPV types 6, 11, 16 and 18.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is administered intramuscularly in three separate doses over a period of some months, and a subsequent booster is required some years later.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 8 By an agreement effective on 1 May 2006, Merck amp; Co., Inc. appointed CSL as its exclusive distributor of GARDASIL in Australia.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL launched GARDASIL officially on 28 August 2006.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The launch was accompanied by substantial marketing activity which included advertising in medical journals, mail-outs to healthcare practitioners, media releases and conference presentations.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The evidence is that the market in Australia for a vaccine of this nature is substantial.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 9 In or about March 2006, GSKA applied to the TGA for approval to market its vaccine for the prevention of cervical cancer.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: However, to date that vaccine, CERVARIX, has not been approved by the TGA for any indication.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It appears that marketing approval is not imminent, but GSKA's application is likely to be reviewed "within the first half of 2007".

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 10 It is necessary to say something briefly about HPV and cervical cancer.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is common ground between the parties that HPV is both a common and contagious virus which is usually transmitted by sexual contact and is a cause of, amongst other things, cervical cancer in women.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Approximately 75 per cent of the adult population, male and female, will be infected by HPV at some stage during their lifetime.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In most cases, the human immune system will eliminate the infection.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: However, if it persists over time, it has the potential to cause precancerous cervical lesions and ultimately cervical cancer.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 11 Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer in women worldwide.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In Australia it accounts for some 230 deaths and 800 new cases per year notwithstanding Papanicolaou (pap) smear screening programs.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 12 HPV is also said to be responsible for less common cancers, including up to 50 per cent of cases of vulvar cancer and 60 to 65 per cent of vaginal cancer, as well as approximately 90 per cent of cases of genital warts.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 13 There are more than 100 strains of HPV.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Several of those cause cervical cancer or precancerous lesions.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The strains of HPV principally implicated in cervical cancer are HPV types 16 and 18.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: These types are responsible for approximately 70 per cent of all cervical cancer in women worldwide.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 14 HPV types 31 and 45 are also associated with cervical cancer.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 15 HPV types 6 and 11 are responsible for 90 per cent of cases of genital warts.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 16 Pharmaceutical products, including vaccines, may not be imported into, manufactured or supplied in Australia unless they have been entered in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods ("the ARTG").

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: An application for regulatory approval must include a dossier of chemical, pre-clinical and clinical data relating to the production, safety and efficacy of the product.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: This data is reviewed by the TGA and the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee ("the ADEC").

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That review determines the proposed "indications" for use.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 17 In order to gain marketing approval a product information sheet, which defines the indications for the pharmaceutical product, must also be approved.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Section 21B(3) of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 (Cth) prohibits a person from representing that therapeutic goods that are not included in the ARTG are so included.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Although CSL at one point alleged that GSKA had contravened this provision, it did not rely upon any such contention in support of its application for interlocutory relief.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The GSKA Information Sheet   18 In June and July 2006, GSKA engaged in what it described as a "market research project".

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That activity, which was undertaken by a market research organisation known as Australian Fieldwork Solutions, consisted of contacting general practitioners by telephone to ascertain whether they were interested in participating, for a fee, in market research on cervical cancer vaccines, and if so sending by facsimile an information sheet containing comparative information on GARDASIL and CERVARIX ("the GSKA Information Sheet").

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Subsequently the general practitioner would again be contacted by telephone, and interviewed.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 19 The GSKA Information Sheet was a two page document containing some background information describing the impact and cause of cervical cancer, and particularly its links with HPV.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It emphasised the importance of regular pap smears as early detection tools, and the need for regular screening.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: None of this was in any way contentious.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 20 However, the GSKA Information Sheet went on to deal, in a comparative way, with GARDASIL and CERVARIX.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It stated that there were two companies developing a vaccine that would offer protection against HPV types 16 and 18 -- the two key cervical cancer causing types.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It said that women would be able to choose which of the two vaccines they preferred.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It observed that it was anticipated that the government would fund a free vaccination program for girls at school while for other women there would be two vaccines available from their general practitioner to be paid for privately, each costing around $400 per course of three injections.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It added that both vaccines were expected to give at least 10 years protection before any boosters were required.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 21 It is necessary to set out in detail the nature of the comparative information provided in the GSKA Information Sheet:   " Vaccine A --- Gardasil   #8226; Will be launched first to market later this year.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; This vaccine is based on work by Professor Ian Frazer, Australian of the Year.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; This vaccine is manufactured by CSL, a well established Australian company.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; This vaccine is indicated for females aged 9 - 26 years.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Gardasil offers protection against cervical cancer caused by HPV types 16 and 18 (These two HPV types cause 70% of cervical cancers).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Gardasil is the only vaccine to provide protection against two further non cervical cancer causing HPV types responsible for genital warts.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Gardasil may offer further protection against some vaginal and vulval cancers (Caused by HPV types 16 and 18).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Gardasil has been formulated with an aluminium adjuvant.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: This adjuvant has been used in the formulation of many vaccines and has been proven to be effective and well tolerated.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Research has demonstrated that Gardasil formulated with an aluminium adjuvant produces a long lasting immune response in women aged 9-26 years.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Clinical trials demonstrate that Gardasil is well tolerated.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Gardasil administration results in general symptoms which were comparable to the control group.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The most common reactions observed after vaccine administration were injection site reactions including pain, redness, swelling and fatigue.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Gardasil will be available as a single dose vial and a retractable pre-filled syringe.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Vaccine B --- Cervarix   #8226; Will be launched second to the market after Gardasil.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; The vaccine is based on work by Professor Frazer, one of several researchers who developed the vaccine technology.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; This vaccine is manufactured by Australia's leading supplier of vaccines --- GlaxoSmithKline.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Indicated for females from 10 - 55 years.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Cervarix offers protection against cervical cancer caused by HPV types 16 and 18 (These two HPV types cause 70% of cervical cancers).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Cervarix is the only vaccine to have shown evidence of additional cervical cancer coverage due to protection against two other cancer-causing HPV type infections (HPV 31 and 45) (Harper et al, 2006).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Due to the protection against these 2 additional strains of HPV, Cervarix could potentially increase protection against cervical cancer from 70% to protecting against 80% of all cervical cancers (Munoz et al 2004).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Cervarix has been formulated using next generation vaccine technology (adjuvant AS04), to generate a strong and sustained immune response in all women aged 10-55 years (Giannini, 2005, Schwarz, 2006 and Dubin, 2005).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Research has demonstrated that the AS04 adjuvant induces a stronger immune response than the same vaccine formulated in the traditional way with an aluminium adjuvant (Giannini, 2005).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; The safety of the AS04 adjuvant has been demonstrated in studies involving over 30,000 people worldwide receiving at least one dose of an AS04 containing vaccine.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Clinical trials demonstrate that Cervarix TM is well tolerated.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Cervarix administration results in general symptoms which were comparable to the control group.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The most common reactions observed after vaccine administration were injection site reactions including pain, redness, swelling and fatigue.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Cervarix will be available as a single dose vial and a pre-filled syringe.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: #8226; Ongoing clinical trials are underway involving more than 30,000 women worldwide which will provide further data on the safety of Cervarix.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: "    22 It is also necessary to set out the preface to the GSKA Information Sheet:   "Please note that the following information about the vaccines to prevent cervical cancer does not represent an official statement by any company.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It also does not provide a full or final representation relating to these vaccines and their features.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: This is, however, all true and accurate information.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: "   CSL's claims   23 CSL claims that, when read as a whole, the GSKA Information Sheet makes a selective and incomplete comparison between GARDASIL and CERVARIX so as to present an inaccurate and unfair profile of its product.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL further claims that those general practitioners who received the GSKA Information Sheet would understand it to be saying that CERVARIX was a superior vaccine to GARDASIL because it offered greater benefits.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 24 The evidence is that the GSKA Information Sheet was distributed to at least 300 general practitioners.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: There is also evidence that some time after these information sheets were provided, the general practitioners were interviewed by telephone.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: They were asked whether, on the basis of the GSKA Information Sheet provided, they would be prepared to prescribe one vaccine in preference to the other, and what price differential they would be prepared to pay in order to secure the benefits that one vaccine offered over the other.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL claims that the questions were "loaded" in such a way as to suggest that CERVARIX offered clinical benefits that GARDASIL did not.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 25 In particular, CSL contends that the information sheet in combination with the loaded interview would be likely to have left general practitioners with the impression that CERVARIX provided a longer period of protection than GARDASIL, and that it provided what CSL described as "cross-protection".

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL also complains that the general practitioners were not told that GARDASIL had been approved for the vaccination of males aged 9 to 15 years, a feature that CERVARIX did not share.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 26 More specifically, CSL pleads in paragraph 10 of its Statement of Claim that GSKA, in the GSKA Information Sheet, and in the course of the telephone interviews conducted after the information sheet had been sent out, made the following representations in trade or commerce, in breach of s 52 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth):   "(a) the Information Sheet was prepared independently of the Respondent;   (b) CERVARIX is registered under the TG Act;  (c) CERVARIX has been approved by the TGA for sale and supply in Australia;  (d) CERVARIX is indicated for females aged ten to fifty-five years;  (e) CERVARIX has been approved by the TGA for protection against cervical cancer caused by HPV types 16 and 18;  (f) CERVARIX has been proven to provide protection against cancer caused by HPV type infections 31 and 45;  (g) CERVARIX is the only vaccine to have shown evidence of cervical cancer coverage additional to HPV type 16 and 18 infections due to protection against two other cancer causing HPV infections being types HPV 31 and HPV 45.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: (h) CERVARIX can increase protection against cervical cancer from 70% to 80% of all cervical cancers.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: (i) CERVARIX, formulated with an AS04 adjuvant, induces longer lasting and stronger immune responses than GARDASIL, formulated with an aluminium adjuvant.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: (j) GARDASIL may offer further protection against some vaginal and vulval cancers caused by HPV types 16 and 18.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: (k) GARDASIL has not been approved by the TGA for the prevention of infection caused by HPV types 6, 11, 16 and 18 in males aged nine to fifteen years.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: PARTICULARS    The representations referred to in paragraphs (a) to (k) were expressly stated in the Information Sheet or by the Respondent's agents when interviewing the general practitioners or were implied from the Information Sheet and the statements made and the nature of the inquiries conducted by the Respondent's agents when conducting the general practitioner interviews.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: "    27 CSL pleads in paragraph 11 of its Statement of Claim that each of the representations set out in paragraph 10 was untrue in that:    "(a) the Information Sheet was prepared by, or with the sponsorship, authority and approval of, the Respondent.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: (b) CERVARIX is not registered under the TG Act;  (c) the TGA has not approved CERVARIX for sale and supply in Australia;  (d) CERVARIX is not registered under the TG Act and the TGA has not approved CERVARIX for any indications in Australia;  (e) CERVARIX is not registered under the TG Act and the TGA has not approved CERVARIX for any indications in Australia;  (f) there is no or insufficient evidence that CERVARIX provides protection against cancer caused by HPV infections types 31 and 45;  (g) there is no or insufficient evidence that CERVARIX provides protection against cancer causing HPV infections types HPV 31 and 45 and, further, CERVARIX is not the only vaccine to have shown evidence of potential cross-protection against other cancer causing HPV types such as HPV 31 and 45;  (h) there is no or insufficient evidence to claim that CERVARIX will provide up to 80% protection against all cervical cancers;  (i) there is no or insufficient evidence to show that CERVARIX, formulated with adjuvant AS04, induces longer lasting and stronger immune responses than GARDASIL, formulated with its aluminium adjuvant;  (j) as stated in the Product Information Sheet, GARDASIL has been approved by the TGA as indicated for the prevention of vulval and vaginal cancers; and  (k) GARDASIL has been approved by the TGA for use in boys aged 9-15 years as stated in the Product Information Sheet approved by the TGA.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: "     GSKA's proffered undertakings   28 GSKA has offered undertakings that until trial, or order of the Court, it will not make any representation in Australia in trade or commerce that:   #8226; CERVARIX is registered under the Therapeutic Goods Act ; and #8226; CERVARIX has been approved by the TGA for sale and supply in Australia, unless or until CERVARIX is approved by the TGA and/or registered under the Therapeutic Goods Act .

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 29 GSKA has also offered to undertake that until trial, or order of the Court, it will not further distribute the GSKA Information Sheet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 30 The effect of these undertakings is, as CSL acknowledged, to obviate the need to consider the representations pleaded in paragraphs 10(b), (c) and (e) of the Statement of Claim.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: However, there remains an issue as to whether there is a serious question to be tried with regard to the misleading or deceptive nature of the representations pleaded in paragraphs 10(a), (d), (f), (g), (h), (i), (j) and (k).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Is there a serious question to be tried?

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Representation 10(a)   31 CSL contends that the preface to the GSKA Information Sheet (set out at [ 22 ] above) contains a representation that the information sheet was independently prepared, and that it represented a balanced, objective account of the features of the two vaccines.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL further contends that the information sheet failed to disclose GSKA's involvement in its preparation.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: To the extent that it asserted that it did "not represent an official statement by any company", but contained "all true and accurate information" it implied that it was not GSKA's document.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That representation, CSL contends, was false.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 32 GSKA contends that there is no serious question to be tried in relation to representation 10(a).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It denies that any representation of the kind pleaded was made.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 33 I am prepared to accept that there is a serious question to be tried in relation to this representation.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: However, I think it unlikely that any general practitioner, who read the GSKA Information Sheet with care, would conclude that it was independently prepared, rather than being prepared by or on behalf of GSKA.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The GSKA Information Sheet must be read as a whole, and against the background of it having been provided in response to an approach by a market research organisation that was prepared to pay general practitioners a fee for reading it, and participating in an interview.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: This had all the hallmarks of an advertising exercise, and the comparison drawn in favour of CERVARIX made it likely that the information sheet was part of that exercise.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Representation 10(d)   34 CSL contends that the representation that CERVARIX is "indicated for females from 10-55 years", which appears in the GSKA Information Sheet was false.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It argues that the term "indicated" has a special meaning in relation to pharmaceutical products, suggesting that any product to which it applies has received TGA approval.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It submits that general practitioners would understand the term in that way.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 35 GSKA submits that the term "indicates" has a broader meaning, and is not to be understood as suggesting that a product has TGA approval.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: GSKA refers to the medical dictionary definition of the term which encompasses this broader meaning, and suggests simply that that product is apt for the particular use.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 36 I am satisfied that there is a serious question to be tried as to whether the particular representation pleaded is contained in the GSKA Information Sheet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: I am also satisfied that there is a serious question to be tried as to whether that representation is false.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Representations 10(f), (g) and (h)   37 CSL contends that these three representations, taken together, imply that CERVARIX is the only vaccine which has been proven to provide protection against cancer caused by HPV type infections 31 and 45.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It notes that the GSKA Information Sheet states that CERVARIX is the only vaccine to have shown evidence of additional cervical cancer coverage due to protection against two other cancer-causing HPV type infections (HPV 31 and 45).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The GSKA Information Sheet goes on to say that due to the protection against these two additional strains of HPV, CERVARIX could potentially increase protection against cervical cancer from 70 per cent to 80 per cent of all cervical cancers.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 38 CSL argues that the GSKA Information Sheet conveys three things:   #8226; CERVARIX has been shown by reliable evidence to provide protection against not only HPV type 16 and 18 infections, but also HPV type 31 and 45 infections; #8226; CERVARIX is the only vaccine to have been shown by reliable evidence to provide such "additional" protection; and #8226; because CERVARIX provides such additional protection, it offers protection against 80 per cent of all cervical cancers.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 39 CSL submits that the representations pleaded suggest that the "evidence" of this additional coverage was generated in a robust scientific clinical study.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The inclusion of the academic reference "Harper et al, 2006" is intended to reinforce that claim.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 40 However, CSL contends that there is no proper scientific basis for these representations.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It says that GSKA's methodology for measuring the efficacy of its vaccine overlooks the role that the human body's immune system plays in the self-elimination of the HPV infection.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: This is because 70 to 90 per cent of HPV infections are cleared spontaneously by the body's immune system within 36 months.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: HPV infection does not progress to cervical cancer unless the infection persists.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Because most HPV infections are transient, a reduction in incident infection cannot be equated with additional cancer protection.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Incident infection is therefore an inadequate endpoint against which to test HPV vaccine efficacy.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 41 CSL further contends that the Harper paper does not support the claim made in the GSKA Information Sheet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The argument is somewhat technical, and need not be addressed at this stage.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 42 Finally, CSL contends that GARDASIL has shown evidence of cross-protection against cervical cancers induced by HPV types 31 and 45.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: However, CSL, acting responsibly, has not made any claims in relation to these HPV strains because they require further assessment which must be based on disease endpoints.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 43 GSKA submits that the representations in question were true, or at least based upon sound scientific opinion.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It relied upon expert evidence of its own to support that contention.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 44 In my view, there is a serious question to be tried as to whether representations 10(f), (g) and (h) are misleading or deceptive.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The dispute between the scientists on this point cannot be resolved on an application for interlocutory relief in which no deponent was cross-examined, and no proper analysis of the scientific opinions expressed in the various affidavits filed was undertaken.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That task must await the final hearing of this matter.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Representation 10(i)   45 CSL notes that the GSKA Information Sheet refers to GARDASIL as having been formulated with an aluminium adjuvant.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CERVARIX, on the other hand, is described as having been formulated using "next generation vaccine technology (adjuvant AS04)" which "induces a stronger immune response than the same vaccine formulated in the traditional way with an aluminium way with an aluminium adjuvant".

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 46 CSL comments that it is unusual for adjuvants to be discussed with general practitioners or referred to in promotional materials.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The use of terms such as "next generation" in contrast to "traditional way" was calculated to leave doctors in no doubt as to the greater strength and longer lasting immune response of CERVARIX in comparison to GARDASIL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In addition, the GSKA Information Sheet refers to a study by "Giannini, 2005" in support of its claim regarding the superiority of its adjuvant.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The plain implication of all this is said to be that CERVARIX provides longer protection than GARDASIL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 47 CSL contends that the comparative statements regarding the adjuvants used in each product are misleading because the aluminium adjuvant used in GARDASIL is quite different to what is commonly regarded as the traditional aluminium adjuvant reported in the Giannini paper.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Without going too deeply into scientific issues, CSL says that the adjuvant used in the Giannini study was aluminium hydroxide.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: GARDASIL, on the other hand, is said to use an amorphous aluminium hydroxyphosphate sulphate adjuvant.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 48 It is impossible, on an interlocutory application, to resolve a scientific dispute of this nature.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is sufficient simply to say that there are conflicting views about the accuracy of the representation contained in paragraph 10(i) of the Statement of Claim.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That means there is a serious question to be tried regarding this issue.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: However, without further evidence, the Court is not in a position to determine how strong that serious question might be.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Representation 10(j)   49 CSL complains that the GSKA Information Sheet says that GARDASIL " may offer further protection against some vaginal and vulval cancers (Caused by HPV types 16 and 18)" (emphasis added).

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It refers to the GARDASIL Product Information Sheet, which contained TGA approval of the statement that GARDASIL was indicated in females aged 9 to 26 years for the prevention of vulvar and vaginal cancer caused by HPV types 6, 11, 16 and 18.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The clinical studies on which that indication was based established that GARDASIL was 100 per cent effective against HPV types 16 and 18 infections, and therefore the word "may" ought not to have been used in the GSKA Information Sheet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 50 GSKA submits that CSL itself used the term "may" on its website in reference to the protection available against these infections.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 51 There is a serious question to be tried regarding this issue.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Representation 10(k)   52 CSL complains that the GSKA Information Sheet does not include any reference to the fact that GARDASIL is indicated in males aged 9 to 15 years for the prevention of HPV types 6, 11, 16 and 18.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That fact is important both clinically and commercially because HPV infects both males and females.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is sexually transmitted and so vaccination protects males from infections and subsequent transmission to their sexual partners.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Vaccination also protects males from genital warts, and some rarer cases of penile and anal cancers.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In addition, there were no clinical trials published that could support CERVARIX being granted marketing approval for use to prevent HPV infection in boys.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 53 In substance, CSL contends that the GSKA Information Sheet, and the interviews conducted with the general practitioners were designed to establish the comparative attractiveness of CERVARIX over GARDASIL, and the price differential that doctors would be prepared to pay to secure the benefits of one vaccine over another.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In that comparative context, CSL contends that it was misleading for GSKA to omit any reference to the fact that GARDASIL was indicated for use in boys.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 54 GSKA submits in reply that the evidence raises doubts as to whether vaccinating males would be as effective in preventing HPV infection as it is in females, and that it is not clear that male vaccination would reduce transmission of HPV infection from males to females.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 55 There must be some doubt as to whether GSKA, in preparing a comparative analysis of the two vaccines, was required to espouse a particular attribute of GARDASIL that CERVARIX may not possess.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Nonetheless, I am satisfied that there is a serious question to be tried as to the misleading or deceptive nature of GSKA's omission in the GSKA Information Sheet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Are damages an adequate remedy?

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 56 It is often said that where an interlocutory injunction is sought an applicant must prove that it is likely to suffer injury for which damages will not be an adequate remedy.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In R Meagher, D Heydon and M Leeming, Meagher, Gummow amp; Lehane's Equity Doctrines amp; Remedies (2002, 4 th ed), the learned authors suggest (at [21-345]) that this requirement applies only where an interlocutory injunction is sought in the auxiliary jurisdiction of a court of equity, and not if the injunction is sought in the exclusive jurisdiction.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is further suggested that injunctions in the common law jurisdiction need not be saddled with this requirement.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 57 There has been some debate among commentators as to whether an applicant for an interlocutory injunction is required to establish not merely that there is a serious question to be tried and that the balance of convenience favours the grant of such relief, the two conditions that are universally accepted, but also that, without an injunction, he or she will suffer injury for which damages will not be adequate compensation.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In other words, the question is whether an applicant must overcome three separate hurdles rather than two.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 58 The recent decision of the High Court in Australian Broadcasting Corporation v O'Neill [2006] HCA 46 clarifies this issue.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Gleeson CJ and Crennan J (at [19]), after referring to various cases dealing with the grant of interlocutory injunctions in cases of defamation, formulated the general principles governing the grant of such relief in the following terms:   "in all applications for an interlocutory injunction, a court will ask whether the plaintiff has shown that there is a serious question to be tried as to the plaintiff's entitlement to relief, has shown that the plaintiff is likely to suffer injury for which damages will not be an adequate remedy, and has shown that the balance of convenience favours the granting of an injunction.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: "    59 In Hexal Australia Pty Ltd v Roche Therapeutics Inc (2005) 66 IPR 325, the likelihood of irreparable harm was regarded by Stone J as, indeed, a separate element that had to be established by an applicant for an interlocutory injunction.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Her Honour cited the well-known passage from the judgment of Mason ACJ in Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd v South Australia [1986] HCA 58 ; (1986) 161 CLR 148 (at 153) as support for that proposition.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 60 GSKA submitted that CSL had not shown that it would suffer injury for which damages would not be an adequate remedy if interlocutory relief were refused.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It noted that the "market research project" for which the GSKA Information Sheet was prepared had been completed.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 61 CSL responded by noting that, although GSKA had proffered an undertaking not to further distribute the GSKA Information Sheet, it had not undertaken to cease "market research" per se in relation to CERVARIX.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: This meant that CSL had no protection against the risk that the representations contained in the GSKA Information Sheet would not be repeated in circumstances that were outside the "market research project".

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It also meant that unless an interlocutory injunction were granted, CSL would not be protected against representations designed to convey to general practitioners and other health professionals that CERVARIX is a superior vaccine to GARDASIL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 62 CSL also relied upon evidence that GSKA was making damaging and, it was submitted, inaccurate comparisons regarding the two vaccines which did not form part of any "market research project".

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: A number of medical practices around Australia had reported to CSL that GSKA was engaged in marketing CERVARIX by representing that it was more comprehensive in its coverage than GARDASIL, covering 80 per cent of cervical cancer while GARDASIL covered only 70 per cent, and that GARDASIL's indication for genital warts was "inconsequential".

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL claimed that GSKA representatives would, in all likelihood, approach tender coordinators for the respective State purchasing boards responsible for implementing any public immunisation scheme.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It also claimed that GSKA had made it clear that it proposed to engage in a variety of pre-launch activities, as well as communications with the TGA.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 63 According to CSL this meant that there was an unacceptable risk that GSKA would continue to engage in direct comparisons between GARDASIL and CERVARIX which involved representations which were wrong and not supported by scientific evidence.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL had requested GSKA to desist from the conduct in relation to which CSL complained.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: GSKA had refused to do so.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 64 GSKA, in its written submissions, did not deal directly with the issue of irreparable harm.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It addressed that question more generally under the ambit of balance of convenience.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Balance of convenience --- the evidence   65 The evidence regarding balance of convenience comes essentially from two sources.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: On behalf of CSL, Dr John Anderson, its Director, Sales amp; Marketing of its Pharmaceuticals Division swore two affidavits dated 11 September 2006 and 18 September 2006 respectively.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In an affidavit sworn on 21 September 2006, David Herd, GSKA's Director, Regulatory Affairs and Health Outcomes amp; Pricing responded to Dr Anderson's affidavits.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 66 Put simply, Dr Anderson claimed that the GSKA Information Sheet, and follow-up interviews, represented CERVARIX was superior to GARDASIL, and did so in a manner that was misleading or deceptive.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He said that, based upon his experience of the conduct of genuine market research, and the numerous errors in the information distributed by GSKA, he considered that GSKA had attempted to create "fear, uncertainty and doubt" about GARDASIL in order to reduce market confidence in that product.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He said that this was a well-known marketing tactic known as "FUD".

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 67 Dr Anderson observed that as GARDASIL was the only vaccine currently approved by the TGA, it was the only vaccine that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee ("the PBAC") could presently assess for the proposed mass immunisation program for prevention of cervical cancer.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He spoke of the potential size of the market for GARDASIL in Australia, and the maximum sales that might be realised if every eligible female and male received the full three course dosage at the full price.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The figure equated to a staggering $1.2 billion.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 68 Dr Anderson noted that the PBAC was currently considering CSL's proposal to conduct annual national vaccination of 12 year old girls, and a catch-up program for girls and women aged 13 to 26 years.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He said that he was concerned that if the conduct complained of was not stopped immediately, and steps taken to correct the misinformation previously put out by GSKA, that misinformation could be conveyed to members of the PBAC and influence its decision.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He said the misleading information could also influence federal cabinet to delay funding of GARDASIL until CERVARIX became available if they believed GSKA's claims that CERVARIX might be a better vaccine.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He said that he was also concerned that State and Territory decision-makers, with inadequate scientific knowledge or experience, might be influenced in relation to the assessment of tenders by the dissemination of such information.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 69 Dr Anderson said that it was highly likely that misinformation of this nature could spread rapidly within the medical community.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He noted that the issue had also received substantial media coverage as a result of the GARDASIL launch activities and the high profile of Professor Frazer's work.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He said that he believed that the only way the damage being suffered by CSL could be reduced is if GSKA were immediately restrained from repeating the representations that are the subject of this proceeding.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 70 In his second affidavit, Dr Anderson elaborated upon the short-term damage to CSL from GSKA's conduct.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He pointed out that CSL's sales representatives were encountering difficulty in their dealings with general practitioners because they were being diverted from speaking about GARDASIL, and compelled to respond to the misleading claims made about CERVARIX.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He gave some examples of this.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 71 Mr Herd replied by noting firstly that GSKA had, since March 2006, been engaged in dealing with the TGA in support of its application for registration of CERVARIX.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He understood that that application would be reviewed at a meeting of the ADEC in the first half of 2007.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 72 Mr Herd said that he was responsible for developing GSKA's reimbursement strategy for submission to the PBAC.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He rejected Dr Anderson's claim that the PBAC would be influenced by representations of the kind contained in the GSKA Information Sheet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He noted the PBAC was an independent body set up by statute, and that its members included medical practitioners and pharmacists.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He referred to the PBAC's guidelines on preparation of submissions and said that it was well understood that the PBAC made its decisions independently of any external influences, and on the basis of scientific and medical data presented to it by applicants.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He noted that it was recognised within the pharmaceutical industry that it was improper for pharmaceutical companies to approach individual members of the PBAC and its various sub-committees to seek to influence its decision making process with regard to specific applications.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He said that GSKA was careful to ensure that it complied strictly with these guidelines when making any application to the PBAC.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 73 Mr Herd also challenged Dr Anderson's claims regarding the harm that CSL might suffer with regard to CSL's application for public funding of GARDASIL on the National Immunisation Program ("the NIP").

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He noted that funding was allocated to States and Territories to manage the implementation of that program, and that each State ran separate tenders through a specially appointed tender board to determine which vaccine should be selected for provision through the NIP.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He said that the GSKA Information Sheet, and the representations contained therein would have no impact or affect on CSL's application for such funding.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 74 Mr Herd said that GSKA would itself suffer irreparable harm if interlocutory relief were granted to CSL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He emphasised the need for GSKA to be able to communicate with the TGA fully regarding CERVARIX while the review process was being conducted.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: He noted that if the TGA came to the view that there were significant clinical advantages offered by CERVARIX, compared to GARDASIL, GSKA would be inhibited in being able to communicate or otherwise discuss such matters.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: These would delay GSKA's ability to apply for public funding of CERVARIX through the NIP, and its ability to supply CERVARIX to that section of the Australian population for which the TGA might decide to indicate the product.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In particular, if the data submitted by GSKA to the TGA were accepted, Australian women over 26 years of age would be denied the opportunity to obtain access to CERVARIX.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: GARDASIL would be unavailable to this section of the population as it was only indicated for women aged 9 to 26 years.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Balance of convenience --- the contentions   75 CSL contended that the harm that it would suffer if GSKA's conduct was not restrained fell into three categories.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 76 First, its marketing launch of GARDASIL is being, and would continue to be, substantially disrupted.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: GSKA's conduct was said to be diluting CSL's marketing advantage arising out of the "head start" it had achieved through being the first to market its unique vaccine.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL claimed that it was being forced to divert its sales resources in order to correct the misinformation being disseminated by GSKA.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 77 Second, CSL would lose sales of GARDASIL that would otherwise be made as general practitioners put off their decision to prescribe vaccine until CERVARIX came onto the market.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In that context it was important to remember that these products were vaccines, and not treatments for existing illnesses.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: According to CSL it would be impossible to tell whether sales which had been lost or postponed were lost or postponed as a result of GSKA's representations, or for other reasons.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 78 Third, there was a risk that tender coordinators, who would be responsible for very large orders if a public immunisation program were implemented, would be unfairly prejudiced against GARDASIL on the basis of inaccurate or incomplete information.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
