text: CSL argued that the tender coordinators, their public servant assistants and the members of any purchasing boards would not be well placed to analyse detailed scientific submissions.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Many of them may not even be medically qualified.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 79 According to CSL the damage that it would suffer from each of these types of harm would not be calculable.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Such irreparable harm would be suffered even if the time between the hearing of this interlocutory application and the final trial were truncated.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL noted that apart from the 300 or so general practitioners who had participated in the "market research project" there were approximately 18,000 general practitioners in Australia of whom 12,000 or so actively worked in clinical practice.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Misinformation of the kind sought to be enjoined was likely to spread quickly within the medical community.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 80 CSL argued that there would be no harm to GSKA if it were restrained until trial from making any representation in Australia that CERVARIX offered or possessed cross-protection against cervical cancer, or that it was more effective and offered longer protection than GARDASIL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That was because until such time as the TGA approved the marketing of CERVARIX, GSKA could not sell or supply its product.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In any event, GSKA was free to legitimately "market" CERVARIX in Australia.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL sought only to restrain GSKA from unfairly and inaccurately comparing CERVARIX to GARDASIL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 81 CSL expressly disavowed any intention of restraining GSKA from communicating with the TGA about CERVARIX in relation to matters that might arise during the prosecution of GSKA's application for marketing approval.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 82 GSKA noted that the undertakings sought by CSL, in place of those proffered by GSKA, were in far broader terms even than the interlocutory and final relief sought in CSL's application.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: GSKA noted that the "market research project" about which CSL complained had been completed by mid-July 2006.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It submitted that it was highly unlikely that the GSKA Information Sheet had been retained, or disseminated by the general practitioners to whom it was provided.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Moreover, GSKA had undertaken, until trial or further order, not to further distribute the GSKA Information Sheet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 83 GSKA submitted that interlocutory relief should be refused by reason of delay.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It noted that a period of 10 weeks had elapsed from the time that CSL first learned of the GSKA conduct of which it now complained until it commenced this proceeding.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 84 GSKA next submitted that it was an important factor when considering the balance of convenience that the trial of this matter could be heard within a very short time.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In fact, the Court indicated that the application for final relief could be heard in mid-November 2006, a delay of less than two months.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: According to GSKA, the fact that a speedy trial could be held meant that there was less justification for the grant of interlocutory relief.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 85 GSKA further submitted that CSL had grossly overstated the damage that it claimed it would suffer if no interlocutory relief were granted.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL's assertion that its sales force was "not able to function optimally or effectively" in the absence of injunctive relief was not supported by the evidence.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Only a handful of CSL sales representatives engaged in promoting GARDASIL had had any contact with doctors who had spoken to GSKA representatives about CERVARIX.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: There was nothing to suggest that any irreparable harm had been done by anything said to any doctor by a GSKA representative.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 86 GSKA challenged CSL's contention that the members of the PBAC were likely to be swayed in their decision whether to recommend the inclusion of GARDASIL in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme by a two page information sheet used in a telephone survey of general practitioners.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The same was said to apply to members of the State tender bodies for the NIP.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 87 GSKA also noted that CSL had engaged in a massive marketing campaign in relation to GARDASIL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: This included two separate mail-outs to almost 20,000 general practitioners in Australia, advertisements in various journals, presentations at conferences and press releases.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It submitted that it was inconceivable that a publicity exercise of this magnitude could be irreparably harmed in the few weeks prior to the trial of this matter given the cessation of the conduct complained of, and the negligible evidence of short-term harm that CSL had provided.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 88 Finally, GSKA contended that it would suffer significant and irreparable harm if it were restrained from carrying out the preparatory work leading up to the marketing of CERVARIX pending the trial of this matter.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It submitted that both CSL and GSKA engaged in extensive activities gearing up to the approval and launch of a new drug product.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: These included corresponding with various regulatory bodies, such as the TGA, the PBAC and various State tender bodies for immunisation programs, attending conferences and symposia, preparing for distribution post-approval educational material, and responding to inquiries from interested persons.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 89 GSKA noted that its application for registration for CERVARIX was currently before the TGA.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Following the extensive publicity that had been given to GARDASIL since its launch, GSKA had received a number of queries regarding CERVARIX.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It had representatives attending three medical conferences in the period between mid-October and mid-November 2006.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 90 According to GSKA, if it were prevented from discussing the characteristics and attributes of CERVARIX it would be unable to:   #8226; communicate with the TGA about its application for the registration of CERVARIX; #8226; participate in scientific debate or engage in meaningful discussions with attendees at any of the three upcoming medical conferences; #8226; communicate with the PBAC or State tender bodies; or #8226; respond to queries from interested persons.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 91 GSKA submitted that its inability to do any of the above would severely hamper it in its preparation for the launch of CERVARIX in Australia and place it at a disadvantage to CSL in the Australian HPV vaccine market, over and above that which it already faced simply by being second to market.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It submitted that CSL, by bringing this proceeding, was seeking to secure a monopoly in Australia for the supply and sale of GARDASIL to which it was not entitled by excluding GSKA from the relevant market for as long as possible.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It submitted that in circumstances where it had proffered undertakings and agreed to a speedy trial and where there was no evidence of any real irreparable harm to CSL, the balance of convenience favoured the refusal of interlocutory relief.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Conclusion   92 The interlocutory relief sought by CSL is in the nature of a quia timet injunction.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That is, what CSL seeks is an injunction to prevent or restrain an apprehended or threatened wrong which would result in substantial damage if committed.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 93 In quia timet proceedings, the court will have regard to the degree of probability of the apprehended injury, the degree of the seriousness of the injury, and the requirements of justice between the parties.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In R v McFarlane; Ex parte O'Flannagan and O'Kelly [1923] HCA 39 ; (1923) 32 CLR 518 Isaacs J observed (at 539):   "The Court is not entitled to apply the obstacle of injunction to the contemplated action of a co-ordinate branch of the Government unless not only a clear case of illegality, proved to be calculated to result in a clear injury, is established, but also it is shown that by no other means can injury be averted or sufficiently compensated for.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: "    94 Dr I C F Spry, in Equitable Remedies (2001, 6 th ed), comments (at 378) that quia timet injunctions are not granted unless the imminence of the act to be prohibited is sufficiently clearly established to justify the court's intervention.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The fact that there is no breach presently occurring may make it more difficult, as a matter of evidence, to establish that there is a sufficient risk of a future injury to justify the immediate grant of an injunction.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: If, in all the circumstances, the likelihood that an injury will take place is not sufficiently high, quia timet relief will be refused.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The applicant will be left either to avail him or herself of such other remedies as may be open, or else to renew his or her application should the likelihood of an injury subsequently increase sufficiently to render equitable intervention appropriate.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 95 There is some debate as to whether a greater degree of proof is required in a case involving interlocutory quia timet relief than in a case involving a different kind of injunction.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The issue is discussed in Meagher, Gummow amp; Lehane (at [21-395]), and need not be further canvassed here.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is sufficient to note that, in many cases, it may be more difficult to prove that an apprehended injury will occur than it is to prove that an existing injury will continue.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 96 I have already indicated that I am satisfied that there is a serious question to be tried in relation to representations 10(a), (d), (f), (g), (h), (i), (j) and (k) as pleaded in CSL's Statement of Claim.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The allegations relating to some of those representations appear to me to be stronger than those relating to others.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: However, nothing of any consequence turns upon this for the purposes of this interlocutory application.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 97 I am prepared to proceed upon the basis that CSL will suffer some harm if these representations, assuming they are false, are repeated between now and mid-November, when the final hearing of this matter will take place.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It may be, as CSL contends, that damages will not be an adequate remedy for such harm.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That means that CSL has overcome the first two hurdles that it must meet in order to obtain the interlocutory relief that it seeks.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 98 However, CSL must still overcome the third hurdle, and demonstrate that the balance of convenience favours the grant of the injunction sought.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: It is common ground that CSL carries the onus on this issue.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 99 The real question in this proceeding, as in many similar cases, is where does the balance of convenience lie?

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: In that regard, I am inclined to the view that each side has overstated its case in relation to this matter.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 100 CSL's evidence that its sales representatives are being diverted from extolling the virtues of GARDASIL to general practitioners by being forced to defend that product from GSKA's claims regarding CERVARIX seems to me to have been extremely tenuous.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The fact that CERVARIX may be available for sale in 2007 would be likely, of itself, to raise questions in the minds of general practitioners about the respective merits of the two products.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That is so irrespective of the representations contained in the GSKA Information Sheet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 101 With regard to other impending harm, it seems to me to be improbable that GSKA's representations, as contained in its information sheet, would be likely to influence the deliberations of Federal Cabinet.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The risk that the PBAC might be influenced by those representations is significantly reduced by the fact that CERVARIX will not be approved by the TGA this year.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The PBAC is unlikely to make any final decisions regarding CERVARIX while TGA approval is still pending for that product.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: CSL's claims for final injunctive relief will have been determined long before the TGA has completed its review.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 102 GSKA's evidence as to the harm that it would suffer if it were temporarily restrained from repeating the representations that were made in its information sheet seems to me also to have been overstated.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: For one thing, CSL made it plain at the hearing, if it was not already clear, that it was not seeking to prevent GSKA from making whatever claims it wished to the TGA about CERVARIX, as part of GSKA's ongoing application for approval.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That made some of the evidence upon which GSKA relied redundant.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 103 In addition, the fact that GSKA might be forced, for a relatively short period, to refrain from engaging in comparisons between GARDASIL and CERVARIX of the type contained in the GSKA Information Sheet hardly seems to me to have the serious consequences for GSKA, and its marketing plans, that Mr Herd foreshadowed.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 104 Although, I accept that damages would not be an adequate remedy if CSL were to succeed in establishing the various breaches of s 52 of the Trade Practices Act that it alleges, the same is probably true for GSKA in relation to the utility of any undertaking as to damages given by CSL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 105 After weighing the evidence carefully, I am not persuaded that the balance of convenience favours the grant of interlocutory relief.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: I accept that the submissions on this issue are finely balanced.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: The fact that there will be a speedy trial and early resolution of CSL's claim for final relief seems to me to tilt the balance in favour of GSKA.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: If CSL's claim is accepted, GSKA will be enjoined from making representations of the kind impugned well before the TGA has completed its review of CERVARIX.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That means that neither the PBAC, nor the State tender bodies are likely to be influenced by those representations.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Any other harm that CSL might suffer between now and the trial is speculative, and not of sufficient gravity to warrant imposing restrictions upon GSKA's own marketing endeavours.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: That is particularly so given that any injunction would necessarily require GSKA, acting prudently, to adopt a conservative approach to what its many employees might say about its product, and effectively stymie legitimate competitive activity.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 106 Had it not been for the fact that there will be a speedy trial of this matter, which Stone J regarded as a relevant consideration in Hexal v Roche (at [78]), I might have been inclined to grant some, at least, of the orders sought by CSL.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: 107 I will give the parties an opportunity to be heard in relation to the matter of costs.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: I certify that the preceding one hundred and seven (107) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice Weinberg.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Associate:Dated: 3 October 2006 Counsel for the Applicant: Mr B.N.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Caine SC and Dr W.A.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Rothnie   Solicitor for the Applicant: Blake Dawson Waldron   Counsel for the Respondent: Mr P.W.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Collinson SC and Ms H.M.J.

Name: CSL Limited v GlaxoSmithKline Australia Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 1301 (3 October 2006)
text: Rofe   Solicitor for the Respondent: Deacons   Date of Hearing: 22 September 2006   Date of Judgment: 3 October 2006    AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2006/1301.html

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: creditor's petition

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: sequestration order

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: whether "other sufficient cause" so that a sequestration order ought not to be made within the meaning of s 52(2)(b) of the bankruptcy act 1966 (cth)

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: whether pending litigation against the creditor "other sufficient cause"

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: bankruptcy

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: BACKGROUND TO THE APPEAL  This is an appeal against orders of the Federal Magistrates Court of 10 June 2009 making a sequestration order against the estate of the appellant, Archer Phillip Field.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The issue is whether the Federal Magistrate erred in not being satisfied that that there was "other sufficient cause" so that a sequestration order ought not to be made within the meaning of s 52(2)(b) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The opening paragraph of the reasons for decision of the Federal Magistrates Court ( St George Bank Limited v Field [2009] FMCA 519) discloses the nature of the hearing before the Federal Magistrate:   [ 1 ] In this petition, the Bank relies upon a debt against Mr Field for $6,800,632.72 under a judgment of the Supreme Court of NSW made on 8 August 2007.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field does not challenge his indebtedness, nor an act of bankruptcy arising upon non-compliance with a bankruptcy notice which was served on 26 November 2007.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: He concedes that the Bank has established a prima facie entitlement to the making of a sequestration order.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: However, he invites the Court to exercise its discretion to decline to do this on the ground that it may be satisfied "that for other sufficient cause a sequestration order ought not to be made" within s.52(2)(b) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This is because he has commenced Federal Court and Supreme Court proceedings claiming damages and other relief against the Bank and other parties, which, if successful, will enable him to pay the Bank or avoid his liability to it.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: He submits that, if the Court is not satisfied that the litigation has sufficient prospects of success, he at least has real claims which would justify a lengthy adjournment of the petition until their prospects become clearer.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field does not dispute the accuracy of this description.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Nor does he contest certain primary facts on which the respondent, St George Bank Limited ( St George ), relied.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Hence, it was common ground that Mr Field was the sole director of Jenolan Caves Resort Pty Ltd ( JCR ).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: JCR's main business related to the revival of the Jenolan Caves Guest House as a tourist location.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: JCR had the benefit of a lease from the Jenolan Caves Reserve Trust ( the Trust ), an instrumentality of the New South Wales government.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: On 8 May 1997 Mr Field gave a guarantee to St George for all moneys owing by JCR to St George including a one year facility of $5.88 million advanced by St George in May 2004.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The terms of the guarantee describe it as unconditional and irrevocable, requiring payment on demand.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field must not delay payment for any reason, with payment to be made in full without any deduction.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The guarantee includes a waiver by Mr Field of "all rights of set off, combination or counterclaim in relation to payment" of the guaranteed moneys (cll 3.1 and 3.2).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The guarantee also provides that Mr Field's obligations and liabilities are not affected by such matters as laches, acquiescence, delay, acts or omissions by St George or another person (cl 5.2.1).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: JCR's operations reached a financial crisis point in 2005.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: On 9 December 2005 St George appointed managers and receivers to JCR.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The receivers purported to transfer the lease and assets of JCR to the Trust pursuant to a deed dated 30 June 2006 ( the Jenolan Deed ).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In the interim, St George had made a demand under the guarantee on 8 June 2006, after it determined that recovery from JCR would be insufficient to satisfy the debt.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: These events culminated in a judgment of the Supreme Court against Mr Field on 8 August 2007 for the sum of $6,800,632.72 ( St George Bank Limited v Archer Phillip Field [2007] NSWSC 902).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: On 26 November 2007 a bankruptcy notice was served on Mr Field.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: On 13 December 2007, Mr Field filed an application in the Federal Magistrate's Court to set aside the bankruptcy notice.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: However, an acknowledged act of bankruptcy occurred on 13 May 2008, when Mr Field consented to orders in the Federal Magistrates Court dismissing his application to set aside a bankruptcy notice served on him on 26 November 2007.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field remains indebted to St George under the guarantee in the sum of $6,800,632.72.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: On 5 November 2008 St George filed a creditor's petition in the Federal Magistrates Court seeking a sequestration order under s 43 of the Bankruptcy Act against Mr Field's estate.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field filed a notice opposing the grant of the petition on 31 March 2009.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrates Court granted the creditor's petition and dismissed Mr Field's notice of opposition in its decision published on 10 June 2009.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field filed a notice of an appeal in this Court against the decision of the Federal Magistrates Court on 17 June 2009.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: By his notice of appeal Mr Field contends that the Federal Magistrates Court erred in failing to dismiss or adjourn the creditor's petition until resolution of another proceeding, being proceeding no.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: NSD9/2009 in this Court ( the Federal Court proceeding ).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The notice of appeal puts this contention of error in various ways.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (1) Grounds 1 to 5, 8 to 11, 14 and 15 relate to the way in which the Federal Magistrates Court dealt with the substantive and procedural aspects of the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (2) Grounds 7, 12 and 13 relate to the way in which the Federal Magistrates Court dealt with aspects of proceedings no.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: 50053/2007 in the Supreme Court of New South Wales ( the Supreme Court proceedings ), that is the proceedings which resulted in the judgment against Mr Field of 8 August 2007, referred to at [6] above.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (3) Ground 16 relates to the Federal Magistrates Court's conclusions about the immateriality of the Jenolan Deed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (4) Ground 6 alleges an error by the Federal Magistrates Court in refusing to admit into evidence the appellant's affidavit sworn 20 May 2009.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (5) Ground 17 alleges an error by the Federal Magistrates Court in placing weight on evidence described as "self serving assertions and conclusions of the receivers and managers of [JCR]".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: REASONS OF THE FEDERAL MAGISTRATES COURT  As noted, the Federal Magistrates Court correctly said (at [1]) that the issue in dispute was limited to the question whether it was satisfied "that for other sufficient cause a sequestration order ought not to be made" as referred to in s 52(2)(b) of the Bankruptcy Act .

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In other words, Mr Field accepted (and continues to accept) that St George had proved each of the matters required by s 52(1) and thus established a prima facie entitlement to the sequestration order (being, the matters stated in the petition, service of the petition and the fact that the debt or debts on which the petitioning creditor relies is or are still owing).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrates Court summarised the background to the pending litigation in [2]-[20].

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In addition to the brief factual summary set out in these reasons for judgment at [4]-[6] above, the Federal Magistrate's summary referred to: (1) The judgment of McDougall J of 8 August 2007 in the Supreme Court proceedings ( St George Bank v Archer Phillip Field [2007] NSWSC 902) against Mr Field determining his indebtedness under the guarantee in the sum of $6,800,632.72.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrates Court, at [10], noted that McDougall J:   ...referred to provisions in the guarantee in which Mr Field waived "all rights of set-off, combination or counterclaim in relation to payment of Guaranteed Money" , and which denied Mr Field rights to rely upon various defences.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: He cited judgments in which courts give such clauses their full effect, at least where there is no challenge to the making of the guarantee.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: He noted at [18] of his judgment that none of Mr Field's contentions asserted that "the taking of the guarantee was itself affected by some vitiating circumstances" , and that Mr Field only sought to attack the exercise of rights under it.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: He said: "In my view that is the kind of exercise prohibited by the terms of the guarantee which terms, as I have said, are to be enforced according to their wording" .

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: He said that they also precluded claims for equitable waste in the exercise of mortgagee powers being relied upon by way of defence.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: However, he observed that "the giving of judgment in favour of St George would not create any estoppel preventing Mr Field from raising any cross-claim that might be maintainable".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (2) The refusal of leave to appeal against McDougall J's decision by the New South Wales Court of Appeal on 1 May 2008 (at [11]) on the basis that:   The judgment of McDougall J was clearly correct in concluding that the (second) commercial list response did not identify the nature of the dispute or the factual or legal bases of the ten issues raised.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Furthermore, the matters raised by way of "confession and avoidance" in response to the bank's application for summary judgment did not establish a defence to the claim having regard to (1) the terms of the Guarantee and (2) the incapacity of the facts alleged to constitute legal or equitable defences to the claim.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (3) Mr Field, on 13 May 2008, consenting to orders dismissing his application in the Federal Magistrates Court to set aside a bankruptcy notice by St George relying on the orders of McDougall J in the Supreme Court proceedings.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (4) Mr Field, on 23 October 2008, filing a summons in the Supreme Court (proceedings 30126/2008) supported by a statement of claim dated 23 December 2008 ( the administrative law proceedings ) which the Federal Magistrates Court described in [13]-[14] as follows:   [ 13 ]...It joins JCR, the Bank, and the Crown in the right of NSW as defendants.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Relief is sought by way of declarations that the Jenolan Deed "was invalid, null and void " due to an invalid appointment of the person who executed it on behalf of the Trust.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It seeks consequential orders for accounts and "re-transfer" to JCR of "the leasehold interest the subject" of the registered transfer.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I note that it does not clearly address Mr Field's locus standi to seek this relief, and the effect of JCR being under liquidation.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I also note that it does not attempt to litigate whether an agency of NSW was or is liable in damages to JCR or to Mr Field for the previously alleged defaults by the Trust in relation to the provision of services and amenities to the hotel.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 14 ] It was conceded before me, that the Supreme Court matter cannot proceed in relation to JCR without leave, since it is in liquidation, and leave has not yet been sought.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: There is no evidence before me as to the defences which have been or are expected to be filed by the defendants, and the proceedings appear at present to be awaiting directions as to their future case management.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The statement of claim requests an order for expedition of the hearing, but there is no evidence that this has been pressed by Mr Field, nor granted by the Supreme Court.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (5) Mr Field, on 7 January 2009, commencing the Federal Court proceeding, which the Federal Magistrates Court described in [15]-[16] as follows:   [ 15 ] ...The respondents are the Bank and the former receivers of JCR.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The pleading recites the asserted invalid appointment of the Trust administrator in 2004, and some of the events of 2005 and 2006.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It claims that the Bank is liable to Mr Field for relief under the Trade Practices Act and other legislation, for its failure to "use its influence and connections with the New South Wales government to facilitate a resolution of" a deadlock in JCR's negotiations with the government, and for the subsequent appointment of the receivers and their sale of JCR's assets at an undervalue.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It seeks a declaration discharging Mr Field from his obligations under the guarantee, without clearly revealing an answer to the points made by McDougall J as to the effect of the waiver provisions in a context where no challenge is made to its making.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It also seeks the same relief as is sought in the Supreme Court, setting aside the Jenolan Deed and the transfer, notwithstanding that it does not join any agency of NSW nor explain the duplication of claims, though this might appear oppressive to the Bank.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It also seeks damages for Mr Field from the Bank and the Receivers, apparently for their conduct in relation to JCR during 2005 and 2006.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 16 ] In effect, the Federal Court proceeding attempts better to present the facts and claims which were raised in the amended response before McDougall J.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: However, the legal foundations of the pleading remain obscure in many respects, and its prospects of surviving interlocutory examination unscathed are, in my opinion, not good.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Although it also seeks to stay enforcement on the Bank's judgment against Mr Field, there is no evidence that this has been pressed by Mr Field by any urgent interlocutory application.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: On the evidence before me, this proceeding is also awaiting case management, and there is no evidence as to what defences or interlocutory applications have been filed, or are expected to be filed, by the respondents.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (6) Mr Field's primary contention in the notice of opposition to the creditor's petition filed on 31 March 2009, namely, that (at 17]):   The pendency of the other proceedings in the Supreme Court and Federal Court of Australia demonstrates a substantial bona fide dispute which could ultimately lead to the respondent debtor receiving a substantial award of damages or other relief against the applicant creditor.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In those circumstances the petition should be dismissed or there should be a stay of proceedings until after the disposal of the other proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of New South Wales.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Following this review of the background to the creditor's petition and Mr Field's notice of opposition, the Federal Magistrates Court (at [21]-[23]) referred to the analysis of authorities by Allsop J in Totev v Sfar (2006) 230 ALR 236 ; [2006] FCA 470 at [37] - [44] as useful, particularly Allsop J's observation at [44] in these terms:   ...what is clear is that the fact that there has been an act of bankruptcy does not make the claim by the debtor against the petitioning creditor irrelevant.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It should be examined to assess whether it can be said that there is sufficient evidence to show that it is a real claim which is likely to succeed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Also relevant is the stage of the litigation, the length of time for its vindication and any other relevant matters.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It goes without saying that solvency is a relevant consideration.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In some circumstances, it may be difficult to assess the likelihood of success of the debtor's claim.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: All the authorities show that central to the showing of "other sufficient cause" for the purposes of s 52(2)(b) is the question of the prospects of success.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The case is not tried in the bankruptcy court, but the material is examined for the purpose alluded to by Gibbs J in [ Re Schmidt; Ex parte Anglewood Pty Ltd (1968) 13 FLC 111].

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As Olney J identified in [ Re James; Ex parte Carter Holt Harvey Roofing (Australia) Pty Ltd (No 2) (1994) 51 FCR 14] , if a likelihood of success can be demonstrated, that may justify a refusal of a sequestration order.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Alternatively, the circumstances may reveal a claim of a character and nature in which likelihood of success cannot be predicted with accuracy but in the circumstances the petition should be dismissed or an adjournment of the petition should granted: see the approach of Sundberg J in Ling v Commonwealth [1996] FCA 1646 ; (1996) 68 FCR 180 at 195---196, with which Wilcox J and Whitlam J agreed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: If the claim is one in which credit of witnesses will be involved, and a debtor sets out the nature and detail of the case and all his or her evidence the debtor may only be able to persuade the bankruptcy court that, if relevant criteria are believed, he or she has good prospects of success.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: What should be proved, or what is sufficient to be proved, in any given case will depend upon the circumstances.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The context in which the issue arises is also important.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The discretion involved in s 52(2)(b) is a broad one, and, importantly, it is informed by public interest considerations concerned with the dealing with insolvents.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrates Court then reasoned as follows: (1) Various considerations meant that neither the Federal Court proceeding nor the administrative law proceedings could be characterised as "'likely to succeed', or even as 'a real claim'" (at [24]).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (2) Both proceedings were "far from 'well advanced'".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This caused the Federal Magistrate to comment that "[c]ertainly, there is little present prospect that either of these very complex claims could be litigated to a successful completion within the life of this petition, which is due to expire on 7 November 2009".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Accordingly, his Honour could "see little prospect that additional merit in the claims will emerge before that date to justify further adjournment under an extension of the petition under s 52(5) ".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Further, his Honour noted that "[t]he present pleadings present obvious deficiencies, and will need to be cleaned up and properly particularised, even if an opportunity to improve them survives interlocutory challenges.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field's delay in bringing both sets of litigation until the brink of bankruptcy, and his failure to press for any stays, expedition or other interim orders which recognise the urgency of his predicament, leaves me doubtful of his capacity to achieve any improvement in his prospects of success within the lifetime of the petition, even if it is extended under s 52(5) " (at [25]).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (3) His Honour also was "not persuaded that this could be achieved by Mr Field gaining a preliminary hearing in one of the courts on the issue of the validity of the execution of the Jenolan Deed on behalf of the Trust".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His Honour observed that "there is no evidence that any application for a separate trial of this issue has been made, nor that it is likely to be granted.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Moreover, even if such a ruling were achieved it would not, in my opinion, significantly advance Mr Field's prospects of achieving relief which off-sets his liability to the Bank.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His claims for this relief face some major difficulties, and Mr Field's evidence and submissions have not explained to me reasonably arguable solutions" (at [26]).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His Honour described one of these difficulties in [27] in these terms:   ...even if the Jenolan Deed was held to be void of legal effect, it is not apparent that this would allow the return to JCR of any valuable rights of a lessee under the 99 year lease.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This is because they would appear to have expired by effluxion of time under cl 12.7.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (4) His Honour referred in [28] to other difficulties facing Mr Field including:   ...establishing standing to make claims which appear to be those of JCR only; in answering the contractual effects of the waiver provisions of the guarantee; in finding evidence of misleading or unconscionable conduct on the part of the Bank during 2005 and 2006; in explaining his delays in seeking equitable or other similar discretionary relief; and in winding back the legal effects of the liquidation of JCR.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (5) His Honour described the "clearest difficulty facing Mr Field" on the material presented as the lack of any likely material advantage to JCR or Mr Field flowing from the relief sought sufficient to off-set the debt to St George (at [29]).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His Honour, in [30], explained that the material he had in mind was the report dated 14 August 2006 from PPB chartered accountants, in their capacity as administrators of JCR.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His Honour said:   The evidence gives me no reason not to give weight to their opinions, particularly since their objectivity and competence to assess the value to JCR of litigation of the sort now contemplated by Mr Field was not challenged.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It is clear that they closely considered the foundations of Mr Field's claims of very substantial loss arising from the making of the Jenolan Deed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In particular, they examined a valuation report of Messrs Magin and Roberts obtained in 2001 by JCR for financing purposes, upon which Mr Field largely pins his claim that the true value of the lease in 2006 exceeded $11m, rather than the total consideration of $2.350m which reached the receivers.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The administrators pointed to substantial reasons for doubting the 2001 valuation, and its continuing weight.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The relevant passages in their report are too lengthy for me to extract, but I find their analysis of the various valuations and the history of JCR and its receivership to be strongly persuasive.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (6) Accordingly, his Honour concluded at [32]-[34] that:   [ 32 ] In the face of the JCR administrators' analysis, and on all the evidence before me, I am not persuaded that Mr Field has established any real prospects of gaining an outcome in his current litigation which would exceed the value of the Bank's debt upon which the petition is based.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Moreover, bringing into consideration the other difficulties facing this litigation, I am not persuaded that Mr Field has been able to raise a public interest in allowing the litigation to continue, which outweighs the public interest in allowing Mr Field's creditor to take his estate into bankruptcy administration.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 33 ] In reaching this conclusion, I have taken into account Mr Field's genuine desire to litigate so as to vindicate his contentions about the failure of his business and the losses he has suffered.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I am conscious that he contends that his incurring of the debt to the Bank occurred as a result of its conduct towards JCR during 2005 and 2006 which he is seeking to characterise as unlawful or improper.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: However, his pending litigation presents such a cloud of uncertainty as to its merits, value, and future progress, that I am unable to characterise it in the terms required under the authorities cited above, both in relation to dismissing a petition or adjourning it.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I am left with an impression that the relevant public interests support, rather than otherwise, the vesting in a trustee in bankruptcy of a power to decide, in the interests of all creditors, the future continuance of that litigation.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 34 ] I therefore am not persuaded by the ground of the notice of opposition, and consider that it is appropriate to proceed immediately to make a sequestration order.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In a part of the reasons described as a "postscript" the Federal Magistrate made the following observations in [35]-[36]:   [ 35 ] After completing the above judgment, my attention was drawn by the Bank's solicitor to the judgment of Barrett J given on 5 June 2009 in Field v Jenolan Caves Resort Pty Ltd [2009] NSWSC 491.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His Honour dismissed Mr Field's Supreme Court Administrative Law List proceeding against the Bank, and also refused to grant Mr Field leave to proceed against JCR in that proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: At [28] he concluded that summary dismissal was appropriate:      Because, first, the causes of action sought to be advanced by Mr Field's statement of claim are causes of action belonging exclusively to JCR and are in no sense available to Mr Field himself and, second, Mr Field has no authority or capacity to sue on behalf JCR, the statement of claim filed by Mr Field and by which he seeks declaratory and other relief must be regarded as disclosing no viable cause of action.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The appropriate course is therefore the first for which St George contends, namely, that the Administrative Law List proceedings as a whole be dismissed as against St George.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 36 ] The evidence before me made no mention of the interlocutory applications which were addressed by Barrett J, and their hearing on 26 May 2009 occurred subsequent to the hearing of the present petition.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In my opinion, the orders and reasons of Barrett J support the opinions I have explained above as to the lack of prospects attending both the Supreme Court and Federal Court proceedings.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: PRINCIPLES  As St George submitted, it is necessary to begin with an appreciation of the nature of an appeal from a decision of a Federal Magistrate under s 24(1)(d) of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 (Cth).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In a case also involving an appeal from a sequestration order made by a Federal Magistrate, Qun Xiong (Kenny) Yu v Todaytech Distribution Pty Ltd (ACN 059 027 250) (2006) 4 ABC(N) 133; [2006] FCA 131 , Young J explained the nature of such an appeal in these terms at [30]-[32]:   [ 30 ] Like appeals to the Full Court from a single judge of this Court, an appeal from a judgment of the Federal Magistrates Court is an appeal by way of re-hearing: see Abeyesinghe v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2004] FCA 1558 at [4] (" Abeyesinghe "); and Low v Commonwealth [2001] FCA 702 at [3] ; see also Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Jia Legeng [2001] HCA 17 ; (2001) 205 CLR 507 at 533 [75] ; and Sydneywide Distributors Pty Ltd v Red Bull Australia Pty Ltd [2002] FCAFC 157 ; (2002) 55 IPR 354 at [50] ---[54].

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 31 ] The expression 'appeal by way of re-hearing' is used in contradistinction to the expressions 'appeal in a strict sense', and 'appeal by way of hearing de novo '.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It is important to bear in mind what these expressions connote.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In the case of an appeal in the strict sense, the function of the appellate court is to determine whether the decision in question was right or wrong on the evidence and the law as it stood when the decision below was given.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Where an appellate tribunal can receive further evidence and its powers are not restricted to making the decision that should have been made at first instance, the appeal is usually described as an appeal by way of re-hearing.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: An appeal by way of hearing de novo is one in which the matter is heard afresh, and the decision is given on the evidence presented at the appellate hearing: see Coal and Allied Operations Pty Ltd v Australian Industrial Relations Commission [2000] HCA 47 ; (2000) 203 CLR 194 at 203 [12] - [13] (" Coal and Allied Operations ").

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 32 ] In Coal and Allied Operations , at [14], the High Court said that statutory provisions conferring appellate powers, even in the case of an appeal by way of re-hearing, are construed on the basis that, unless there is something to indicate otherwise, the power is to be exercised for the correction of error.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: A similar observation was made by the Full Court of this Court in Branir Pty Ltd v Owston Nominees (No 2) Pty Ltd [2001] FCA 1833 ; (2001) 117 FCR 424 at [21] .

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Thus, it has been said that this Court's appellate powers are only exercisable if the appellant can demonstrate that the orders under appeal are the result of some legal, factual or discretionary error: see Abeyesinghe at [4].

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Further, and again as St George submitted, it is important to appreciate that it is not the case that the mere existence of a pending cross-claim against the petitioning creditor constitutes a "sufficient cause" not to make a sequestration order within the meaning of s 52(2)(b) of the Bankruptcy Act .

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As Sundberg J said in St George Bank Ltd v Helfenbaum [1999] FCA 1337 at [13] :   The existence of a cross-claim may be a 'sufficient cause' within s 52(2)(b) for declining to make a sequestration order: Ling v Enrobook Pty Ltd (1997) 74 FCR 19 at 25.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It is for the debtor to establish the existence of 'sufficient cause': Cain v Whyte [1933] HCA 6 ; (1933) 48 CLR 639 at 645-646; Ling at 24.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: He must establish that he has a real claim against the creditor that is likely to succeed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: If the Court is satisfied that there is such a claim, and that its quantum is likely to equal or exceed the creditor's claim, it will not make a sequestration order.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: If the claim is likely to be less than the creditor's claim, the Court will require the debtor, if he is to avoid a sequestration order, to pay the difference between the judgment debt and the amount he is likely to recover on his claim.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: See Re Player (1962) 19 ABC 277 at 282; Re Schmidt; Ex parte Anglewood Pty Ltd (1968) 13 FLR 111 at 115---116; Ling at 25---26; Commonwealth Bank v McDonald ; [1999] FCA 984.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: A debtor does not establish a real claim that is likely to succeed merely by producing a statement of claim in an action against the creditor: Re Rivett; Ex parte Edward Fay Ltd (1932) 5 ABC 182 ; Player at 282, or by pointing to the existence of current litigation against the creditor: cf Re Douglas Griggs Engineering Ltd [1963] 1 Ch 19 at 23.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: While the Court does not try the cross-claim in advance, the debtor must adduce sufficient evidence to show that it is a real claim which is likely to succeed: cf Vogwell v Vogwell (1939) 11 ABC 83 at 88; Player at 282.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field's grounds of appeal must be assessed having regard to these principles.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: THE FEDERAL COURT PROCEEDING  As noted, grounds 1 to 5, 8 to 11, 14 and 15 relate to the way in which the Federal Magistrates Court dealt with the substantive and procedural aspects of the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field's submissions Mr Field made detailed submissions in support of these grounds which can be summarised as follows.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Court proceeding directly impugns and, if successful, would effect a discharge from and set aside the guarantee and, thereby, avoid the liability on which the creditor's petition is based.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Further, if successful, the Federal Court proceeding would set up a case which would result in a very substantial award of damages to Mr Field.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The claims in the Federal Court proceeding, Mr Field said, are based on issues of fact and law about "which there can be no real dispute".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: According to Mr Field, the Federal Magistrate both misconceived and gave no real or proper consideration to the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The statement of claim is not "obscure" (at [16]).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The conclusion that the statement of claim in the Federal Court proceeding did not have good prospects of "surviving interlocutory examination unscathed" (also at [16]) also is unfounded.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Contrary to the Federal Magistrate's apparent assumption that Mr Field would have difficulties establishing standing, Mr Field did not need to be a party to a transaction to maintain a claim for damages for misleading and deceptive conduct under either the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) or the Australian Securities and Investment Commission Act 2001 (Cth).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Nor can waivers in a guarantee prevent such a claim from being maintained as a person cannot contract out of these statutory protections.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In any event, difficulties that might arise in the resolution of a claim are an insufficient reason to prevent Mr Field from litigating the claim.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Discussion Given the terms of the application commencing the Federal Court proceeding and the accompanying statement of claim I am satisfied that the Federal Magistrate's conclusions cannot be impugned.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: First, the statement of claim does not identify any fact, matter or circumstance in existence at the time of entry into the guarantee which would support a claim that the guarantee is vitiated by reason of some legal, equitable or statutory source of invalidity.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Instead, the statement of claim records various events which occurred about eight years after the giving of the guarantee said to give rise to various causes of action.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Second, the relationship between the subsequent events about which complaint is made and Mr Field's liability under the guarantee is obscure.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The statement of claim does not disclose how the subsequent events are capable of leading to the relief claimed given the waivers in the guarantee.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Third, and as the Federal Magistrate observed at [28] and St George noted in its submissions, JCR is not a party to the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: But many, possibly most, of the matters about which complaint is made in the statement of claim are complaints which only JCR can make in circumstances where Mr Field has no right or standing to make a claim on JCR's behalf.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field sought to make good this difficulty by pointing to s 82 of the Trade Practices Act and s 12GF of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act that a person who has suffered loss or damage by reason of misleading and deceptive conduct need not be a party to the transaction.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: But this is at best an answer only in part (if at all) to the problems confronting the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Court proceeding seeks to set aside the Jenolan Deed and the transfer of the lease thereby affecting the rights of third parties.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field's oral submissions tried to address this problem by indicating that these claims are unnecessary and could be deleted and, in any event, the issue of invalidity of the administrator's appointment and its consequences could be determined as facts along the way without joining all interested parties.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: However, the fact is that these claims were in the application as before the Federal Magistrate and remained in the application as at the hearing of this appeal.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Moreover, these claims are relevant to the claims for damages for misleading and deceptive conduct.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Alleged knowledge on the part of St George of the supposed invalidity of the administrator's appointment, or facts that should have alerted St George to that effect, is an essential part of the factual matrix of the claims for damages.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Fourth, and consistent with St George's submissions, the facts of the present case do not readily appear to engage any principle about lack of capacity to contract out of statutory protections from misleading and deceptive conduct.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In May 1997 Mr Field gave a guarantee the key terms of which have been identified at [5] above.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Events many years later said to involve unconscionable and misleading or deceptive conduct are then relied upon to assert some right to escape liability under that guarantee and to found claims for damages.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: How claims to this effect are to be sustained is difficult to comprehend as the Federal Magistrate properly recognised.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Fifth, and as should be apparent from the discussion above, the facts asserted in the statement of claim and the propositions of law on which it depends are far from being "beyond real dispute".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The facts include alleged oral representations based on a meeting in November 2005 (para 22).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Oral representations from many years ago are notorious for generating disputes.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The propositions of law include the invalidity of the appointment of an administrator on the basis of an alleged procedural defect.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As St George submitted, the allegation of invalidity of the appointment of the administrator depends on an argument that s 58ZE of the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974 (NSW) only permitted appointment if there were members of the Trust at the time of appointment when, in this case, all memberships had expired.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The legal arguments to which this claim might give rise are numerous, as St George observed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: For example, s 58ZE would have to be construed purposively before the question of breach could be answered.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Further, even if breach occurred, the consequence is only invalidity if that purpose may be inferred in accordance with the canons of construction ( Project Blue Sky Inc v Australian Broadcasting Authority (1998) 194 CLR 355; [1998] HCA 28 at [91] - [93] ).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Finally, the Jenolan Deed has been carried into effect and, amongst other things, the transfer of the lease has been registered under the Real Property Act 1900 (NSW).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Each of these matters involves a substantial hurdle to Mr Field's claims of invalidity of the appointment of the administrator to the Trust.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: For present purposes, it is sufficient to make the following points.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In terms of a purposive construction, the effect of Mr Field's argument is that where the terms of appointment of each member of the Trust has expired, the Minister, if he or she wishes to appoint an administrator, must appoint members by a notice in the NSW Government Gazette, then remove those members by another (possibly even the same) notice in the NSW Government Gazette and finally appoint the administrator by notice in the NSW Government Gazette (again possibly by the same notice).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This is not an attractive construction of s 58ZE(1) of the National Parks and Wildlife Act .

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field's answer, that the National Parks and Wildlife Act evinces an intention that the Trusts control the reserved land, cannot stand in the face of s 58W(2) which makes the Trust subject to the control and direction of the Minister.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Even as a matter of language alone, and ignoring the wider context of the provision, there is little to support an argument that powers vested in the Minister to either "remove any or all members of the Trust board" or "remove all members of the Trust Board...and appoint a person as an administrator of the Trust" should be read as requiring the appointment and removal of Board members before the power of appointment of an administrator can be exercised.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In terms of the consequences of breach, invalidity can only result from a conclusion that the "the language of the statute, its subject matter and objects, and the consequences for the parties of holding void every act done in breach of the condition" evinces a legislative intention "to invalidate any act that fails to comply with the condition" ( Project Blue Sky at [91]).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Public inconvenience is a relevant factor in this process of construction.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The invalidating of every act of the administrator of the Trust merely because the Minister did not go through a charade of appointing members only to remove them and thereby (on Mr Field's argument) enliven the Minister's power to appoint an administrator would result in an extraordinary level of public inconvenience.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Even a finding of fact to that effect, without any consequential declarations, raises real issues of public inconvenience.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This is a formidable hurdle which Mr Field's submissions sought to circumvent by asserting that the condition in question determined the availability of the power so that the principles identified in Project Blue Sky did not apply.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: But the principles in Project Blue Sky assume and look to the consequences of breach of statutory conditions of all classes.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In terms of the registration of the transfer of the lease under the Real Property Act , the grant of relief to Mr Field may be affected by the indefeasibility of the title as registered either as a matter of law or discretion (see, by analogy, City of Canada Bay Council v F amp; D Bonaccorso Pty Ltd (2007) 71 NSWLR 424 ; [2007] NSWCA 351).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: For these reasons, I am satisfied that Mr Field's claim to the effect that the appointment of the administrator of the Trust was invalid with the consequence of invalidating the administrators subsequent transactions (including the giving of notices under the lease and the entry into the Jenolan Deed) has no real prospects of success.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Sixth, these matters affect many of Mr Field's claims in the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: For example, in oral submissions Mr Field advanced an argument that the report of JCR's administrators, PPB chartered accountants, dated 14 August 2006 was inaccurate in many respects including by reason of a statement that the receivers and managers had a limited timeframe to achieve a sale of the lease.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This was said to be incorrect because all notices issued by the Trust's administrator under the lease were invalid due to his invalid appointment.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Similarly, Mr Field contended that the Federal Magistrate erred by assuming the validity of that appointment for the purpose of his Honour's observation in [27] that JCR's rights appear to have expired by effluxion of time under cl 12.7 of the lease with the consequence that JCR's rights may not return any value in any event.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Given the observations above about the numerous difficulties confronting Mr Field's argument of invalidity of the appointment of the Trust's administrator it is difficult to accept that either the receivers and managers or the Federal Magistrate erred.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Further, and as these submissions disclose, the invalidity of the appointment of the Trust's administrator (and all of its associated problems) is a fact embedded in many of Mr Field's claims.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Finally, this is not a case of any mere difficulty in resolving Mr Field's claims.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field had to establish "other sufficient cause" so that a sequestration order ought not to be made within the meaning of s 52(2)(b) of the Bankruptcy Act .

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate was entitled and indeed bound to examine the cogency of the claims in the Federal Court proceeding and their likely prospects of success.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In so doing the Federal Magistrate was entitled also to take the proceeding as it stood at the time of the hearing.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His Honour was not obliged to hypothesise possible ways in which the proceeding could be recast to make more sense or improve its prospects.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
