text: In these circumstances the conclusions of the Federal Magistrate about the Federal Court proceeding were amply supported by the available evidence, namely, that: (i) the statement of claim is obscure, presents obvious difficulties, and is unlikely to survive interlocutory scrutiny, (ii) the proceeding could not be described as well advanced, and (iii) the proceeding could not be described as either likely to succeed or even as a real claim.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate also cogently explained his reasons for so concluding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It follows that I do not accept any of the grounds of appeal relating to the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I turn to each ground relevant to the Federal Court proceeding in the light of the conclusions above.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 1 is a general assertion of error which appears to depend on one or more of the other grounds being sustained.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As none are sustainable ground 1 falls away.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 2, insofar as the reference to "other considerations" outweighing the making or deferral of a sequestration order should be understood as a reference to the Federal Court proceeding, is a mere assertion that the Federal Magistrate should have reached a different conclusion without the exposure of any error in his Honour's reasoning process.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 3 depends on the Federal Court proceeding having a sufficient likelihood of success so as to warrant a finding of a sufficient cause not to make or to defer making a sequestration order.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: For the reasons given I am satisfied that the Federal Magistrate's conclusions about the lack of prospects of success of the Federal Court proceeding as pleaded were correct.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 4 depends on a finding that, irrespective of the prospects of success, the character and nature of the Federal Court proceeding warranted a finding of a sufficient cause not to make or to defer making a sequestration order.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I can see nothing in the evidence to support the making of such a finding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As noted, the statement of claim does not refer to any fact, matter or circumstance at the time of entry into the guarantee that would have had the effect of invalidating it.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The claim appears to depend on events some eight years after entry into the guarantee to absolve Mr Field from liability.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The statement of claim does not confront in any meaningful way the numerous difficulties identified above.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 5 cannot be sustained insofar as it alleges a failure by the Federal Magistrate to consider the prospects of success of the causes of action in the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate's reasons disclose the contrary.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As to the other errors alleged in ground 5: (1) I am satisfied that the Federal Magistrate's reasons disclose a correct understanding of the relief sought in the statement of claim.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The discharge from liability under the guarantee is based on events subsequent to its making by reason of alleged unconscionable conduct.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Yet the claim does not confront the terms of the guarantee.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (2) The complaint about the Federal Magistrate's description of the Federal Court proceeding as an attempt "to present the facts and claims which were raised in the amended response before McDougall J" (at [16]) is unfounded.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In the Supreme Court proceedings Mr Field did make the same allegations about the invalidity of the appointment of the administrator, the same complaints about the Trust's actions and the actions of St George.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It is true that the Supreme Court proceedings did not make the same express claims that, in consequence, St George had acted unconscionably in making its demands for payment.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: But the document filed by Mr Field in those proceedings did expressly claim that, by its actions, St George discharged the guarantee, breached s 52 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) and that it would be unjust and inequitable for St George to rely on the guarantee.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate's summary description of the Federal Court proceeding being equivalent to the Supreme Court proceeding in [16] was correct.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: (3) The complaint about the Federal Magistrate's reference to the obscurity of the statement of claim and the lack of a clear pleading, as reasoned at [21] above, is also unfounded.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His Honour's description was accurate.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 8 alleges an error by the Federal Magistrate in concluding that the Federal Court proceeding had little prospect of successful completion by 7 November 2009.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate, at [25], said that "there is little present prospect that either of these very complex claims could be litigated to a successful completion within the life of this petition, which is due to expire on 7 November 2009" and, at [26], that "I am not persuaded that this could be achieved by Mr Field gaining a preliminary hearing in one of the courts on the issue of the validity of the execution of the Jenolan Deed on behalf of the Trust.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I note that there is no evidence that any application for a separate trial of this issue has been made, nor that it is likely to be granted.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Moreover, even if such a ruling were achieved it would not, in my opinion, significantly advance Mr Field's prospects of achieving relief which off-sets his liability to the Bank.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His claims for this relief face some major difficulties, and Mr Field's evidence and submissions have not explained to me reasonably arguable solutions".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field's complaint appears to be based on a challenge to the latter proposition concerning a separate hearing about the validity of the Jenolan Deed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: But, as the Federal Magistrate may be taken to have understood, a separate hearing has to have utility for the resolution of the real issues in the proceeding as a whole.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field's claims about invalidity of the Jenolan Deed are confronted by numerous difficulties.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The legal link between the invalidity of the Jenolan Deed and a right in Mr Field to obtain a discharge from liability under the guarantee remains obscure.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Hence, the Federal Magistrate's characterisation of the position was justified on the evidence and, in my view, correct.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 9 is derivative and depends on one of the other grounds being upheld.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As such, the ground must fail.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 10 alleges that the Federal Magistrate failed to give weight or sufficient weight to the fact that many of the allegations in the statement of claim in the Federal Court proceeding are either substantiated or unlikely to raise a substantial dispute.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This ground seems to rise no higher than mere assertion.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It simply ignores the numerous factual and legal difficulties to which the statement of claim gives rise.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 11 repeats the allegation that the Federal Magistrate failed to give weight or sufficient weight to the fact that the validity of the Jenolan Deed could be determined quickly as a discrete legal issue at a separate hearing.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate dealt with this suggestion and rightly concluded that it was unlikely and of dubious utility given the essential issue of liability under a guarantee which contains waivers of the type in the guarantee in question.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 14 repeats the complaint about the Federal Magistrate's conclusion that the statement of claim in the Federal Court proceeding was obscure and unlikely to survive interlocutory scrutiny.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I am satisfied that the Federal Magistrate's conclusion was justified given my observations above.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 15 alleges that the Federal Magistrate failed to properly take into account the delay in the Federal Court proceeding by reason of St George's notice of motion filed 17 April 2009 seeking orders that the statement of claim be struck out.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Insofar as Mr Field said the Federal Magistrate erred by treating delays as relevant to the merits of the proceeding, I reject the submission.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate did no such thing.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His Honour referred to the lack of urgency apparent in Mr Field's actions (at [25]) as making it doubtful that Mr Field would have a capacity to improve his prospects of success within the lifetime of the petition.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This conclusion was open and able to be drawn on the evidence.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Insofar as Mr Field relied on St George's motion filed 17 April 2009, the fact is that the obvious problems with the statement of claim made such an application for strike out likely.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Contrary to Mr Field's submissions, it appears that St George was not required to file and serve a defence in the Federal Court proceeding if it filed and served a notice of motion to strike out the proceeding, as it has done.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: THE SUPREME COURT PROCEEDINGS  Grounds 7, 12 and 13 relate to the way in which the Federal Magistrates Court dealt with aspects of the Supreme Court proceedings.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field's submissions In support of these grounds Mr Field denied that the Federal Court proceeding attempted to present in better form the claims in the Supreme Court proceedings.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field also submitted that the amended commercial list response which he filed was struck out not for any failure to disclose a proper case with adequate prospects of success but because of its inadequacy as a response for the purpose of the Supreme Court's commercial list.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: According to Mr Field, the facts pleaded and relief claimed in the Federal Court proceeding go far beyond anything that could have been raised in the Supreme Court proceedings.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Discussion I have already concluded above that the Federal Magistrate's summary characterisation of the Federal Court proceeding was open to be made and, indeed, accurate.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Further, in the Supreme Court proceedings McDougall J did consider Mr Field's prospects of success in respect of the various claims made for discharge of liability under the guarantee.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: McDougall J, at [17] and [20] in St George Bank Limited v Archer Phillip Field [2007] NSWSC 902 , said:   [ 17 ] Against that background, it is therefore necessary to consider the issues that might be raised.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I have set them out above.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: A number of those issues refer to conduct of St George, by its servants and agents, which has the effect of discharging the guarantee, or of relieving Mr Field of liability under it, or of making it unjust for St George to seek to enforce the guarantee.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: On the face of things, they are all rights that Mr Field has bargained away by the clauses of the guarantee to which I have referred.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It is clear that the courts will give effect to such a bargain: see Mason CJ in The Commonwealth of Australia v Verwayen [1990] HCA 39 ; (1990) 170 CLR 394 at 407.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In the particular context of a guarantee, see the decision of Brennan J in Buckeridge v Mercantile Credits Limited [1981] HCA 62 ; (1981) 147 CLR 654 at 675.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: To the extent that Mr Field wishes to raise those issues, they are issues that are foreclosed by the terms to which I have referred.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: ...     [ 20 ] In those circumstances, I do not think that there is any utility in giving Mr Field yet a further opportunity to seek to articulate some defence.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Nothing has been put, either supported by evidence or even based on submissions from the bar table, that would indicate a defence that can stand in the face of the contractual provisions to which I have referred, explained as they are by the authorities to which I have referred.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The facts pleaded and relief sought in the Federal Court proceeding do go further than that of the Supreme Court proceedings (specifically, in terms of the claims for damages by reason of misleading and deceptive conduct), but the essence is the same: invalidity of the Jenolan Deed and a discharge of Mr Field's liability under the guarantee.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 7 alleges error in the Federal Magistrate failing to find or consider that Mr Field could not have raised the same matters in the Supreme Court proceedings as now raised in the Federal Court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In answer, I have already noted in [50] above that the essence of the two proceedings is largely the same.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Further, apart from bare assertion, Mr Field's submissions provided no meaningful explanation of the reasons precluding the seeking of similar relief in the Supreme Court proceedings, other than the obvious difficulties presented by the terms of the guarantee itself, which is no more addressed in the Federal Court proceeding than it was in the Supreme Court proceedings.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 12 is bordering on the meaningless.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Insofar as it alleges that the Federal Magistrate should not or could not have taken into account McDougall J's conclusions that the waiver provisions in the guarantee presented insuperable difficulties for Mr Field in the Supreme Court proceedings, I disagree.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate was entitled to have regard to the fact that, in the Supreme Court proceedings, Mr Field also claimed a discharge from any liability under the guarantee but was unable to formulate an arguable defence in support of that claim.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Ground 13 also seems to be repetitive of the substance of grounds 7 and 11 in that it alleges that Mr Field could not raise certain matters in the Supreme Court proceedings by reason of the waiver provisions in the guarantee but is not subject to the same constraint in the Federal court proceeding.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: But, as noted, the statement of claim in the Federal Court proceeding discloses no fact, matter or circumstance relevant to the validity of the guarantee at the time of its making.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field relies on events years later as matters disentitling St George from enforcing the guarantee and discharging Mr Field from any liability under it.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Yet the terms of the guarantee, including the waivers, remain.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As noted, the fact that the Federal Court proceeding involves claims based on statutes for unconscionable and misleading and deceptive conduct, and consequential damages, does not undermine the Federal Magistrate's conclusions about the ultimate prospect of the proceeding or the difficulties that Mr Field would have to confront in the event of interlocutory challenge.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: THE JENOLAN DEED  Ground 16 relates to the Federal Magistrates Court's conclusions about the immateriality of the validity of the Jenolan Deed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate, at [27], said that "[o]ne of the difficulties is, as was pointed out by counsel for the Bank, that even if the Jenolan Deed was held to be void of legal effect, it is not apparent that this would allow the return to JCR of any valuable rights of a lessee under the 99 year lease.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: This is because they would appear to have expired by effluxion of time under cl 12.7".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: For the reasons given above I am unable to see how this observation involves an error given the numerous problems that Mr Field would have to confront in his claim that the Trust administrator's appointment was invalid and the consequential lack of prospects of that claim.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: REJECTION OF EVIDENCE  Ground 6 relates to the Federal Magistrate's refusal to admit into evidence the appellant's affidavit sworn 20 May 2009.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: At [19]-[20] the Federal Magistrate said:   [ 19 ] In an affidavit filed two days before the hearing of the petition, Mr Field attempted to add to his grounds of opposition a contention that the Bank has failed to "provide me with a report of its investigations" in response to a complaint to it under the Code of Banking Practice.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: His complaint was made by letter dated 16 June 2006 to the chairman of the Bank, and made numerous detailed criticisms of how officers of the Bank had responded to correspondence and events during 2005 and 2006.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Although this letter was in a very large bundle of documents exhibited to his affidavit, it received no mention in the affidavit and had no apparent relevance to the grounds of opposition except as background of dubious relevance.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Bank's responses to the complaint were not in the bundle, nor, understandably, in its evidence in reply to the notice of opposition.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 20 ] It is not apparent to me how the evidence of this complaint could substantially advance Mr Field's grounds of opposition.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The raising of the additional issues at a late stage, and outside the time-tables previously directed by the Court, was opposed by counsel for the Bank.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: He pointed to prejudice facing the Bank's legal representatives in attempting to take instructions on short notice about the issues raised by the 2006 complaint and the attack on its handling.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Taking into account both that prejudice, and my difficulty in discerning how the matter materially advances Mr Field's opposition to the petition, I refused leave to rely upon these parts of the affidavit and upon the new contention.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I can see no error in the Federal Magistrate's decision to refuse to admit this material into evidence.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The material was rejected on a discretionary ground (delay and the late raising of additional issues).

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Nothing suggests any error of principle in the Federal Magistrate's rejection of this material.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The fact that the material had potential relevance to para 45(f) of the statement of claim does not invalidate the Federal Magistrate's conclusion that it was difficult to discern how it advanced Mr Field's position.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Paragraph 45(f) alleges as a particular of the claim for unconscionable conduct that St George failed to apply the Code of Banking Practice to various complaints Mr Field had made.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The observations of the Federal Magistrate about the difficulties this evidence involved in terms of form and substance and its lateness justified the decision to reject it.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: WRONGFUL ATTRIBUTION OF WEIGHT TO EVIDENCE  Ground 17 alleges an error by the Federal Magistrate in placing weight on evidence described as "self serving assertions and conclusions of the receivers and managers of Jenolan Caves Resort Pty Limited".

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The difficulty with this ground is that the evidence in question comprised a report to the creditors of JCR by the administrators, not the receivers and managers.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: As the Federal Magistrate rightly said at [30]-[31]:   [ 30 ]...The evidence gives me no reason not to give weight to [the administrators'] opinions, particularly since their objectivity and competence to assess the value to JCR of litigation of the sort now contemplated by Mr Field was not challenged.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: It is clear that they closely considered the foundations of Mr Field's claims of very substantial loss arising from the making of the Jenolan Deed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In particular, they examined a valuation report of Messrs Magin and Roberts obtained in 2001 by JCR for financing purposes, upon which Mr Field largely pins his claim that the true value of the lease in 2006 exceeded $11m, rather than the total consideration of $2.350m which reached the receivers.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The administrators pointed to substantial reasons for doubting the 2001 valuation, and its continuing weight.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The relevant passages in their report are too lengthy for me to extract, but I find their analysis of the various valuations and the history of JCR and its receivership to be strongly persuasive.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: They summarised some significant conclusions at p 26:     Summary     For there to be a successful claim against St George or the Receivers and Managers under s 420A of the Act, it would have to be proven that the above transaction was either below market value or if there was no market for the asset, it was realised for below the best price possible.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: We are of the opinion that this would be a difficult action to pursue for the following reasons:     #8226; The Receivers and Managers obtained formal advice that the asset was unsaleable in its current form;  #8226; The trust was required to consent to the assignment;  #8226; A major factor in ensuring the assets were saleable was negotiating a reduction in the rent payable under the lease.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: While the Receivers and Managers attempted to obtain such a reduction, they were unsuccessful in this regard;  #8226; Major rectification works were required to be undertaken or committed to before any assignment could take place;  #8226; There was a limited timeframe in which to sell the leasehold;  #8226; No co-operative marketing and management structure existed between the cave operator and the resort operator;  #8226; No commitment had been provided by the Trust to upgrade the existing infrastructure and/or services provided under the lease; and  #8226; The Receivers and Managers had undertaken negotiations with three (3) parties, all of which were unsuccessful.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: We note that the following additional factors also need to be considered in respect of any potential legal action:     #8226; Due to the inherent uncertainty and cost involved in pursuing litigation, a detailed legal opinion would be required as to the merits or otherwise of this claim;  #8226; We currently do not have any funds in the Administration to obtain a legal opinion or become involved in a potentially lengthy or costly litigation; and  #8226; In discussions with the Receivers and Managers, it has been indicated that in the event that any such claim was brought, it would be vigorously defended.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: [ 31 ] Mr Field's evidence and submissions have not demonstrated to me any real prospect of his being able to overcome the factual or legal foundations of these opinions.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: In my opinion, the administrator's opinions in this summary and elsewhere in their report to creditors, and the evidence to which they point, suggest that there is little prospect that Mr Field will be able to establish that the true value of JCR's business at the time of the Jenolan Deed exceeded the consideration provided in that Deed, whether it was validly or invalidly entered into, and whether or not it was attended by challengeable behaviour by the Bank.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: The Federal Magistrate was entitled to give weight, including substantial weight, to these matters.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: No error in so doing is disclosed.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: CONCLUSIONS  I am satisfied that none of Mr Field's grounds of appeal are sustainable.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Mr Field has not demonstrated that the Federal Magistrate's conclusions and orders were the result of any legal, factual or discretionary error.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Having reviewed the available material I am convinced that the Federal Magistrate's conclusions were not only justifiable but correct.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Accordingly, the appeal must be dismissed with costs.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: I certify that the preceding sixty (60) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice Jagot.

Name: Field v St George Bank Limited [2009] FCA 1042 (17 September 2009)
text: Associate:  Dated: 17 September 2009  Counsel for the Appellant: Mr J Garnsey QC and Mr R Newton   Counsel for the Respondent: Mr P Dowdy   Solicitor for the Appellant: The People's Solicitors Pty Ltd   Solicitor for the Respondent: Henry Davis York  Date of Hearing: 13 August 2009   Date of Judgment: 17 September 2009     AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2009/1042.html

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: winding up

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: neglect to pay debt after statutory demand

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: acceptance of bank cheque in payment of debt subject to condition that winding up application be adjourned for one week so as to confirm its clearance

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: continuation of proceedings by creditor in the interim

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: whether applicant continued to have standing

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: whether court obliged to dismiss application

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: applicant held to continue to have standing

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: no obligation to dismiss application

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: application adjourned as a matter of discretion

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: corporations

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 1 This matter came on for hearing before me yesterday on referral from the District Registrar's Corporations List on 13 November 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 2 The Applicant, a Deputy Commissioner of Taxation (the Deputy Commissioner), has applied to the Court for the winding up of the Respondent Company, BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd ACN 088 472 066 (Ganter).

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 3 The proceeding commenced upon the filing of the application for the winding up of Ganter on 20 August 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Prior to that date, the Deputy Commissioner had served a statutory demand upon Ganter with which that company failed to comply.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The application first came on for hearing before the Court in the Registrar's list on 18 September 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Since then, it has been twice adjourned by Registrars; firstly on 18 September 2008 when it was adjourned until 30 October 2008 and then, secondly, on that date when it was further adjourned until 13 November 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: It suffices to note that the occasion for each of the adjournments appears to have been correspondence directed by or on behalf of Ganter to the Deputy Commissioner indicating that the company was in the process of obtaining finance to enable it to pay the debt due in full and a corresponding request to the Registrar by the Deputy Commissioner to adjourn the application.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 4 Earlier this month and prior to 13 November 2008, like correspondence was directed to the Deputy Commissioner by the solicitors acting for Ganter.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: An adjournment of the proceeding for a further four weeks "so that finance can be secured" was proposed.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: On this occasion, the Deputy Commissioner signified that he would not agree to an adjournment.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Instead, on 4 November 2008, the Deputy Commissioner advised the solicitors for Ganter that an order for the winding up of the company would be sought on 13 November 2008 "unless payment in full in cleared funds is received on or before 13 November 2008".

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The preceding day Ganter had made a payment of $150,000 to the Deputy Commissioner in reduction of the amount then due to the Commonwealth of Australia and payable to the Commissioner of Taxation in respect of a revenue debt.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That left a balance of $149,762.09 outstanding.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 5 On 5 November 2008, having confirmed that the amount owed as at that date was $149,762.09, the Deputy Commissioner advised the solicitors acting for Ganter that, if that sum was paid prior to the hearing of the application on 13 November 2008, the Deputy Commissioner would seek the adjournment of the proceedings "until all funds have been cleared and then dismiss the wind up application at the next return date".

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 6 Thereafter, an endeavour was made by Ganter to transfer the advised outstanding amount to the credit of an account maintained by the Deputy Commissioner on behalf of the Commonwealth.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That endeavour failed, not through any fault on the part of the Ganter, but apparently because of an inability on the part of the banking system to annotate the transfer with all of the identification details specified by the Deputy Commissioner.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: If nothing else, the course of subsequent events in this case might be thought to highlight the desirability of the Commissioner's settling with the major trading banks a means by which such transfers might be facilitated in a mutually satisfactory way.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That though is a matter for the Commissioner, not the judiciary, for it is the Commissioner who has the responsibility for the general administration of the taxation laws.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 7 Upon ascertaining that it was not possible to effect payment by direct transfer, Ganter procured from the National Australia Bank Limited (NAB) a bank cheque in favour of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in the sum of $149,762.09.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: This cheque was delivered to the Brisbane Office of the ATO by Ganter's solicitors under cover of a letter from those solicitors which accurately recited the effect of a conversation which had occurred earlier that day between a solicitor in the employ of that firm and an officer in the Legal Services Branch of the ATO.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The letter recited that "you [the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation] intend to adjourn the application, which is presently listed for Thursday 13 November 2008, for one week to allow for the cheque to clear, and that the matter will be dismissed at the next return date upon clearance of the bank cheque".

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 8 On 11 November 2008, the Deputy Commissioner agreed to this proposed course.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Later that same day an alternative was proposed on behalf of Ganter by its solicitors.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That was that the winding up application ought to be dismissed on its next return date, ie 13 November 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That course was not agreed to by the Deputy Commissioner.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Instead, on 12 November 2008, the Deputy Commissioner signified a disposition to seek a one week adjournment the following day.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Ganter's solicitors replied later on 12 November 2008, indicating that they intended to appear on 13 November 2008 so as to seek the dismissal of the winding up application.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 9 When, on 13 November 2008, the application for winding up was called on in the Registrar's list, the solicitors for Ganter sought the dismissal of the application.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: This course was opposed on the part of the Deputy Commissioner who sought adjournment of the application for a further week.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Apprehending, with respect correctly, that a point of general practical utility was raised by the circumstances of the case, the District Registrar then referred the hearing of the application to a Judge, adjourning accordingly for that purpose.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 10 It appears from the evidence that the Deputy Commissioner's nomination of a period of one week for the proposed adjournment of the winding up application was not coincidental.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: It seems that the experience of the ATO in dealing with Australian banks is that, in the ordinary course of events, Australian banks take five working days following the electronic reporting by the ATO to the relevant bank of the receipt of a cheque.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That electronic reporting seems to be the equivalent of the presentation of the cheque to the bank for payment.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The inference necessarily arises that the Deputy Commissioner's nomination of one week as the length of the proposed adjournment was informed by a knowledge of this experience with the banks.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 11 In this case, the electronic reporting by the ATO occurred on 11 November 2008 via the Penrith, NSW office of the ATO.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: In the course of his general administration of the taxation laws the Commissioner has determined that the ATO should centralise its processing of payments.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That task has fallen to the Penrith office.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: It was to there that the Brisbane office forwarded the bank cheque received on 10 November 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 12 Investigations by the ATO of the NAB have disclosed that the bank's position in relation to bank cheques is informed by its membership of the Australian Bankers' Association.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The NAB's policy in relation to its bank cheques is expressed as follows: The term 'bank cheque' describes a cheque that is issued by a bank.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Bank cheques are generally treated by the law in the same manner as ordinary cheques.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Although some people regard bank cheques as equivalent to cash, there are certain circumstances where a bank cheque may not be paid.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: To clarify the position, NAB, as a member of the Australian Bankers' Association, adopts the following policy in relation to NAB bank cheques.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Forged or unauthorised If the signature of an officer of NAB is forged or placed on a bank cheque without NAB's authority, NAB is not legally liable for the cheque concerned.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Materially altered NAB will dishonour a bank cheque that has been fraudulently and materially altered.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: NAB will co-operate with any holder of a cheque, or person who is about to receive it, who may want to verify that the cheque is a valid cheque.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Reported stolen or lost If NAB is told that a bank cheque is stolen or lost and is satisfied that this is the case, NAB will not pay the cheque if it is presented for payment by a person who has no right to it.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: NAB may provide a replacement cheque for a fee.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Court order restraining payment NAB must observe an order of a court restraining NAB from paying a bank cheque which is presented for payment while the order is in force.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Failure of consideration for the issue of a bank cheque Where NAB has not received payment for issuing a bank cheque to a customer (e.g.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: your cheque to NAB in payment for the bank cheque is dishonoured), NAB may refuse to pay the bank cheque only if the person presenting the bank cheque for payment: has not given value for it (e.g.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: the bank cheque is stolen); or has given value for it but at the time of doing so he or she knew NAB had not been paid for the cheque (e.g.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: that the cheque in favour of NAB had been dishonoured).

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 13 It was not suggested in this proceeding that, so far as a Commonwealth revenue debt is concerned, there is any express statutory provision which alters the usual position which prevails as between creditor and debtor when a cheque is given in payment of a debt.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That usual position was expressed by Mason CJ, Brennan, Deane, Dawson and Toohey JJ in National Australia Bank v KDS Construction Services Pty Ltd [1987] HCA 65 ; (1987) 163 CLR 668 , at 676 to be as follows: Generally speaking, when a cheque is given in payment of a debt, it operates as a conditional payment.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The payment is subject to a condition that the cheque be paid on presentation.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: If it is dishonoured the debt revives.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Although it is sometimes said that the remedy for the primary debt is suspended, the suspension is no more than a consequence of the conditional nature of the payment: Tilley v Official Receiver in Bankruptcy [1960] HCA 86 ; (1960) 103 CLR 529 , at pp 532-533, 535-536, 537.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The condition is a condition subsequent so that, if the cheque is met, it ranks as an actual payment from the time it was given.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Subject to non-fulfilment of the condition subsequent, the payment is complete at the time when the cheque is accepted by the creditor: Thomson v Moyse (1961) AC 967 , at p 1004.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 14 It was submitted for the Deputy Commissioner that, in the events which had transpired in this case, that usual position had been altered by the signification by the Deputy Commissioner that he would agree to the dismissal of the winding up application once the proceeds of the cheque had been cleared.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: It seems to me though that the evidence is more consistent with the Deputy Commissioner's adopting a position which was in accordance with the general position when a cheque is given in payment of a debt.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: It has been accepted subject to a condition that the cheque would be paid on presentation.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Subject to the fulfilment of that condition, payment of the then outstanding amount of the debt due to the Commonwealth and payable to the Commissioner was complete upon the acceptance by the Deputy Commissioner on 10 November 2008 of the cheque then proffered on behalf of Ganter.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: In this regard, the fact that the proffered cheque was a bank cheque may well have provided a degree of comfort to the Deputy Commissioner in deciding to accept it, but the position would have been the same in law so far as the relationship of debtor and creditor was concerned had the cheque concerned been one where the drawer was other than a bank.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 15 Strictly speaking, a cheque, even a bank cheque, is not a form of legal tender.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Subject to some particular contractual or statutory provision, the only forms of legal tender remain Australian notes or, subject to the limits specified, Australian coins --- see s 36 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959 and s 16 of the Currency Act 1965 respectively.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: However, in general trade and commerce, as Mason J observed in George v Cluning (1979) 53 ALJR 767 (note) by reference to Canadian authority, a payment by cheque can amount to sufficient payment if not objected to on that account.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: In this case there was no objection made by the Deputy Commissioner on account of Ganter's endeavouring to settle its indebtedness by the tendering of a cheque only, as I have noted a signification that it was accepted subject to a condition that the cheque would be paid on presentation 16 None of this is to suggest that the Deputy Commissioner was under any obligation to accept the proffered cheque.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: When the history of Ganter's endeavours to pay the debt after the filing of the winding up application is recalled and that the company was, by operation of s 459C(2)(a) the Corporations Act 2001 presumed to be insolvent the Deputy Commissioner would have been entitled not to accept the cheque.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: A refusal to accept the cheque would not have eliminated the debt in question: Australian Mid-Eastern Club Ltd v Yassim (1989) 1 ACSR 399 , at 403 (NSWCA); Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Visidet Pty Ltd [2005] FCA 830 at [3] per Gyles J.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 17 The accounts of the ATO in respect of Ganter record a credit to its account on 11 November 2008 in the amount of $149,762.09.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That does no more than recognise what will be the effect of the acceptance of the cheque if the condition subsequent as to the clearance of the cheque is met.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Were the cheque for some reason to be dishonoured the creation in the accounts of the ATO of an entry reversing the credit recorded on 11 November 2008 would be appropriate.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: I note that the account concerned is made accessible to the company's tax agent by the Commissioner in the ordinary course of his administration of the taxation laws.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 18 As it happens, though the period within which, in accordance with the NAB's usual practice, a notice of dishonour might be given to the ATO has yet to elapse, other evidence from the NAB, which was not available at the time when the application came on before the District Registrar on 13 November 2008, suggests that the bank does now have cleared funds available to meet the cheque.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: As at 13 November 2008 the prevailing position, so far as advice to the ATO from the NAB was concerned, was that, even were a special clearance to be sought, it would not be possible to clear the cheque until after 11:00 am on 18 November 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: I am not satisfied on present materials that the condition subsequent has been met.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 19 For Ganter reliance was placed on the following observation made by Barrett J in Bidald Consulting Pty Ltd v Miles Special Builders Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 397 at [11] : [A] plaintiff whose debt has been paid after the time for challenging a s.459E demand based on the debt has expired and before the hearing of the winding up application is no longer able to maintain and pursue that application.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 20 Assuming that the Deputy Commissioner ought presently to be regarded as an applicant whose debt has been paid, it does not, with respect, seem to me to follow that the application must therefore necessarily be dismissed.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: In his judgment in Motor Terms Co Pty Ltd v Liberty Insurance Ltd [1967] HCA 9 ; (1967) 116 CLR 177 , at 194-195, Menzies J, in what is strictly an obiter dictum , opined: In the course of argument upon this appeal, reference was made to the consequence of a petitioning creditor being paid off between the presentation of the petition and the making of an order.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That circumstance would not, in my opinion, put an end to the petition nor would it affect the jurisdiction of the court to hear and determine the petition although, of course, in such circumstances proceedings might not be continued and, if they were, the court could, in the exercise of its discretion, refuse to make a winding up order upon the petition of a person not then a creditor.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: In that same case, Barwick CJ (at 179) also seems to have been of the view that, under the then statutory regime for the winding up of a company, the date for the determination of whether a petitioner was a creditor was the date of presentation of the winding up petition.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 21 In my opinion, the date for the determination of standing to apply for the winding up of a company is the date when the application is made.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: As it was when Motor Terms v Liberty Insurance (supra) was decided, the process for the winding up of a company remains today entirely statutory.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: By s 459A(1)(b) of the Corporations Act a creditor is one of the persons who may apply for the winding up of a company.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The application for the winding up of Ganter was made by the Deputy Commissioner upon the filing of the application in this Court on 20 August 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: At that time, the Deputy Commissioner was, on any view, a creditor.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Like Gyles J in Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Visidet Pty Ltd (at [5]), I am not persuaded that there is any requirement flowing from the Corporations Act that the applicant must continue to be a creditor at the time when the winding up application is heard.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: As his Honour there states (ibid), and though it is cited in a number of cases which he notes, the passage from the judgement of Menzies J in Motor Terms v Liberty Insurance (supra) does not support the existence of any such requirement.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 22 The true position is that the applicant's status as a creditor at the time when the application was made and the presumption flowing from the company's failure to comply with the terms of a statutory demand are sufficient to give the Court jurisdiction to order the winding up of the company.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That was the conclusion reached by Zeeman J in Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Guy Holdings Pty Ltd (1994) 116 FLR 314 at 318.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: As did Gyles J in Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Visidet Pty Ltd (at [6]), I agree with that conclusion.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: As Zeeman J observed in the Guy Holdings Case (at 320), "in the case of an application under s 459P where the debt the subject of the statutory demand has been paid after the filing of the application, the application ought to be dismissed unless there is established some positive reason that a winding up order ought to be made".

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: His Honour is there referring to the way in which, in those circumstances, the discretion vested in the Court on the hearing of a winding up application by s 467 of the Corporations Act would ordinarily be exercised.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 23 How should that discretion be exercised as matters presently stand in this case?

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: There is no proof that the company owes any other amount either to the Commissioner or to any other creditor.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Perhaps in testimony to the latter, no other creditor of the company has sought to be substituted as an applicant.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 24 In their submissions the solicitors for the company pointed to the observation made by Gyles J in Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v Visidet Pty Ltd (at [8]), "With trading companies the existence of a winding up proceeding is a very serious inhibition and has very serious impacts".

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: I respectfully agree.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: That is one reason why it behoves a company which wishes to keep trading to pay its debts as they fall due or at least later to comply with the terms of a statutory demand.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: It is also a reason why, all other things being equal, a Court would be disposed, as a matter of discretion, to dismiss a winding up application if satisfied that the debt owed to the applicant creditor had been paid.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Another consideration not to be ignored is the protection of the revenue.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Yet another consideration is that Ganter, by its solicitors, initially agreed with the Deputy Commissioner's proposal that on 13 November 2008 the adjournment of the application for one week ought to be sought.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: A further consideration is the public interest in whether a company which is presumed to be insolvent ought to be permitted to continue to trade or whether it ought to be wound up.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 25 Ganter's change of heart as to the course which ought to be taken on 13 November 2008 seems to have been multi-factorial in origin.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Inferentially from the submissions made to me and to the District Registrar it was founded upon what I regard as the misapprehension that the payment of an applicant creditor's debt obliged the Court to dismiss a winding up application, as opposed to that being a factor going to discretion.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Likewise, it seems to have been grounded on the belief that the acceptance of the bank cheque by the Deputy Commissioner extinguished the debt then and there, as opposed to so doing upon the fulfilment of the condition subsequent of the cheque's being cleared.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Further, it seems to have been grounded upon the belief that, the cheque payment having been recorded as a credit on 11 November 2008 in its accounts, the Deputy Commissioner was obliged, as a "model litigant" to agree to the dismissal of the winding up application on 13 November 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 26 This, with respect, misapprehends the obligation that falls on those representing the interests of the Crown in civil litigation.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: One of those interests, and it is a vital interest, is the protection of the revenue.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The Deputy Commissioner would certainly have failed in his duty to the Court as a model litigant had the acceptance of the cheque and the terms upon which it had been accepted not been drawn to the Court's attention on 13 November 2008.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: It was.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Especially as matters then stood as to the clearing of the bank cheque and the Deputy Commissioner's knowledge as to the practice of the NAB in relation to the circumstances in which it would not meet a bank cheque and the time within which any such disposition on the part of the bank would usually be signified, it was not unreasonable for the Deputy Commissioner to resist the dismissal of the application that day.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The position then to take was a matter for the value judgement of the Deputy Commissioner in the circumstances in the administration of the taxation laws.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The entry in the accounts of the ATO had no more than a provisional quality about it.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 27 As at 13 November 2008 there was no obligation on the part of the Court then to dismiss the application.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: The disposal of the application then called for the exercise of a discretion.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: It still does.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Though there is more confidence now that the condition subsequent will be met, it seems to me in the circumstances of this case that Ganter ought to be held to the terms upon which it asked and the Deputy Commissioner agreed to accept the cheque and to seek the adjournment of the winding up application.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: I therefore adjourn the hearing of the application until 19 November 2008 at 9:30 am, the date requested by the Deputy Commissioner.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Even assuming that there is power so to do, I do not believe that it would be appropriate to make a conditional order of dismissal, which was an alternative suggested on behalf of the Deputy Commissioner.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: 28 I shall hear the parties as to costs.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: I certify that the preceding twenty-eight (28) numbered paragraph is a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice Logan.

Name: Deputy Commissioner of Taxation v BK Ganter Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] FCA 1730 (18 November 2008)
text: Associate:Dated: 18 November 2008 Counsel for the Applicant: Mr P Looney   Solicitor for the Applicant: Australian Taxation Office   Solicitor for the Respondent: Morgan Conley Solicitors  Date of Hearing: 17 November 2008   Date of Judgment: 18 November 2008     AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2008/1730.html

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: whether the decision of the refugee review tribunal was made in bad faith and breached procedural fairness

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: appellants had been through lengthy litigation

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: original tribunal had made a finding of fact that appellants were in a homosexual relationship

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: relationship was not disputed in federal court and high court proceedings

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: third tribunal found that appellants were not in a homosexual relationship

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: tribunal made findings seeking to give effect to preordained result

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: decision of the tribunal manifests "an apprehension of predisposition, tendency or propensity towards a given result"

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: tribunal's decision was not made in good faith and was unreasonable

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: appeal allowed.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: migration

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: migration act 1958 (cth)

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The appellants claim to be Bangladeshi homosexuals, who would face a real risk of persecution should they be returned to Bangladesh.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: After long and extensive litigation, the Refugee Review Tribunal (the Tribunal), on the third occasion it had to consider the claims of the appellants, found that the appellants had fabricated their claims, and that they were not truthful or credible witnesses.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal also found that the appellants' witness lacked credibility and did not accept his evidence.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal found that the appellants were not homosexual and that they had not lived in a homosexual relationship.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal therefore found that neither would face persecution should they be forced to return to Bangladesh.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal rejected all of the appellants' claims.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: This appeal by the appellants to this Court will be allowed.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: I am satisfied that the decision by the Tribunal on the third occasion the matter was before it was not made in good faith.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Such a finding is one that is not reached lightly, and unsurprisingly is one that is very rare.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: I am satisfied that the finding of the third Tribunal that the two appellants are not, and were not, homosexuals was not made in the exercise of honest fact finding, but was deliberately calculated to "get around" difficulties in the factual circumstances of the appellants' case, thrown up by the judgment of the High Court in Appellant S395/2002 v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Appellant S396/2002 v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2003] HCA 71 ; (2003) 216 CLR 473 ( Appellant S395/2002 ).

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The appellants are Bangladeshi nationals.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: They came to Australia, arriving on 19 February 1999.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: They sought protection visas on 4 March 1999, claiming that they were homosexuals who had lived together as a couple since 1994, and that they had been subjected to persecution in Bangladesh because of their homosexuality.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: A delegate of the Minister for Immigration and Citizenship found, on 23 April 1999, that the applicant born on 1 July 1973 (NAOX, or the younger Bangladeshi), was a "citizen of Bangladesh", accepted "as plausible the applicant's claim that he is a homosexual", but was "unable to accept there is a real chance that he will be persecuted on that ground in Bangladesh".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The delegate said:   In his circumstances, if he believes that his homosexuality, and his relationship, would not be acceptable to the community in which he is living, it is only reasonable to believe that he should be discreet about such matters.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The same delegate of the Minister found, on the same day, 23 April 1999, and in reasons almost identical to the reasons given in the matter of NAOX, that the applicant born 1 July 1953 (SZFSG, or the older Bangladeshi), was a citizen of Bangladesh, accepted "as plausible the applicant's claim that he is a homosexual" but was "unable to accept there is a real chance he will be persecuted on that ground in Bangladesh".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The delegate also said, concerning SZFSG:   In his circumstances, if he believes that his homosexuality, and his relationship, would not be acceptable to the community in which he is living, it is only reasonable to believe that he should be discreet about such matters.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: On 22 February 2001, the first Tribunal affirmed the decision not to grant visas.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It found that they appellants were homosexuals; found that homosexuals cannot live openly in Bangladesh, and imposed the "discretion test".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: On 26 July 2001, Lindgren J rejected an application under s 476(1) of the Migration Act 1958 (Cth) (the Act).

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: His Honour said, at [17]:   It is only if a homosexual couple force Bangladeshi society to confront their homosexual identity that they will encounter problems.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: His Honour later said, at [19]:   The applicants did not complain that they had to modify their behaviour so as not to attract attention.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Apparently, therefore, they lived together in the way they wished to do.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In sum, in living together in the way in which they did, they were naturally "discreet" and not "open", according to the meanings those words had for the [Tribunal].

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (case references omitted).

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: On 22 February 2002, the appellants' appeal to the Full Court of the Federal Court (Black CJ, Tamberlin and Allsop JJ) was dismissed.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: On 11 October 2002, the appellants were granted special leave to appeal to the High Court of Australia.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: On 9 December 2003, the High Court allowed the appeal, rejecting the "discretion" test, and remitted the matter to the Tribunal for re-determination.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The matter had proceeded, from the decision of the delegate, to the Tribunal, the Federal Court, the Full Court of the Federal Court and to the High Court on the basis that the appellants were Bangladeshi homosexuals.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The only live issue was whether they faced a real risk of persecution, a matter which involved considerations of whether there was a requirement for "discretion", and an enquiry as to why the appellants chose to live "discreetly" and not "openly".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
