text: Confronted by this judgment in the High Court, the second Tribunal found the only way out to justify the refusal of the protection visas.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It found that they were not homosexuals after all.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The second Tribunal found that the appellants were "close relatives", who have been "married to women", which is "at odds with their being a homosexual couple who met by chance in 1994 ..." I interpolate to observe that the third Tribunal disagreed with the second Tribunal as to the basis of the crucial finding of homosexuality.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The third Tribunal said:   ... the Tribunal finds that the applicants were not married, and the reason that the various applications indicated they were married was that this would facilitate the granting of the visas sought.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It is important to have regard to the issues before the High Court in Appellant S395/2002 :   The [first] Tribunal accepted that the appellants were homosexual, and that homosexual men in Bangladesh are a particular social group for the purposes of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees , as amended by the Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees , as amended by the Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees 1967.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: However, the Tribunal rejected most of the claims made by the appellants as to the persecution they had suffered in Bangladesh, including claims that they had experienced threats and violence over many years.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It found that they had not in the past suffered serious harm by reason of their homosexuality, observing that they had "clearly conducted themselves in a discreet manner and there is no reason to suppose that they would not continue to do so if they returned home now".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Further:   The [Tribunal] rejected their claim to have a well-founded fear of persecution in Bangladesh by reason of their homosexuality.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal rejected most of their individual claims, but accepted that it was not possible to live openly as a homosexual in Bangladesh.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It found, however, that the applicants had "clearly conducted themselves in a discreet manner and there is no reason to suppose that they would not continue to do so if they returned home now".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The applicants contended that the Tribunal had erred in law by imposing upon them a requirement that they live discreetly in order to avoid persecution.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: All the members of the High Court held that the (first) Tribunal:   ... had not imposed a requirement that the applicants live discreetly if they returned to Bangladesh.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It had made a finding of fact that they would live discreetly.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: That finding did not itself involve error.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: However, in the view of McHugh and Kirby JJ, and of Gummow and Hayne JJ, in their respective joint judgments, held:   Asylum seekers are not required to take reasonable steps to avoid persecutory harm.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal must determine how an asylum seeker is likely to live on return to his or her country of origin and assess the chance of persecution on that basis.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It is not relevant to consider whether the asylum seeker could live in the country of origin without attracting adverse consequences.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Senior Counsel for the Minister, Mr S J Gageler SC had submitted to the High Court:   The Tribunal was correct in reasoning that, because the appellants would face physical harm only if they were not discreet, and because there was no reason to expect that they would not be discreet in the future, they were not at real risk of physical harm.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: If on the facts there is a real chance that a person's homosexuality may be discovered despite living discreetly, and if discovery would lead to serious harm, the person is a refugee.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The homosexuality of the appellants was at the core of the proceeding in the High Court.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: As McHugh and Kirby JJ noted under the heading, "The material findings of the Tribunal", at [25]:   The Tribunal found that the appellants were homosexual males who had lived together at various places in Bangladesh from 1994 to 1996.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal accepted that "homosexual men in Bangladesh constitute a particular social group under the Convention".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal found:      "[H]omosexuality is not accepted or condoned by society in Bangladesh and it is not possible to live openly as a homosexual in Bangladesh.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: To attempt to do so would mean to face problems ranging from being disowned by one's family and shunned by friends and neighbours to more serious forms of harm, for example the possibility of being bashed by the police.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: However, Bangladeshi men can have homosexual affairs or relationships, provided they are discreet.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Bangladeshis generally prefer to deny the existence of homosexuality in their society and, if possible, will ignore rather than confront it.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It is also clear that the mere fact that two young men held hands or hugged in the street would not cause them to be seen as homosexuals, and that being caught engaging in sexual activity on one occasion would be most unlikely to cause a young single man to be labelled a homosexual.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: "    Gummow and Hayne JJ emphasised, at [85] and [86], some of the observations of the Tribunal: Of more concern is the Tribunal's statement that "it is not possible to live openly as a homosexual in Bangladesh".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It went on to say that: "To attempt to do so would mean to face problems ranging from being disowned by one's family and shunned by friends and neighbours to more serious forms of harm, for example the possibility of being bashed by the police.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: " (Emphasis added.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: ) The Tribunal further found that "Bangladeshi men can have homosexual affairs or relationships, provided they are discreet ".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (Emphasis added).

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Nowhere in the reasons of the Tribunal is any consideration given explicitly to whether there was a real chance that the appellants would be subjected to any of the "more serious forms of harm" to which the Tribunal alluded.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Nowhere in the reasons is any consideration given explicitly to whether the appellants would be subjected to ill-treatment by police.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Nowhere is there consideration of whether subjection to any of these "more serious forms of harm" would amount to persecution.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: By order of the High Court, the matter was remitted to the Tribunal for re-determination.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: What occurred on the remitter by the High Court to the second Tribunal is recorded in the judgment of Federal Magistrate Smith of 13 April 2006, on the occasion of the appeal from the decision of the second Tribunal to the Federal Magistrates Court.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Amongst other matters, it was submitted to the second Tribunal by counsel for the appellants that:   ... it was not open to the Tribunal to reconsider whether the applicants "are in a homosexual relationship" nor whether "homosexuals face discrimination or harm" in Bangladesh.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Counsel for the appellants argued:   ... these facts were " immutable matters that stand and which were not disturbed in the court above ".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The member constituting the second Tribunal said:   I will consider that argument.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: I will share the job of considering that argument with other minds in the Tribunal.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: That is to say I will take legal advice from our legal section on that matter.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: There were complaints about forcing the hearing on in the absence of counsel's availability, and before Smith FM, that the second Tribunal was "biased against the [appellants]", or there was a reasonable apprehension of such bias.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Those grounds were particularised.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The central finding of the second Tribunal was:   The Tribunal finds that the Applicants are close relatives who are, or have been married to women.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal's finding is based on evidence provided by them and by [SZFSG's] brother.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal does not rely on the evidence of the anonymous caller to DIMIA in relation to these or, in fact, any adverse factors in the Applicants' respective cases.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: However, the Tribunal is also of the view that the anonymous caller's evidence does not help their cases.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal considers that it is important to make this clear because the Applicants have made unsupported claims about the caller having acted on behalf of either a homophobic section of the Bangladeshi community or DIMIA or both.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal does not accept those suggestions.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: For the reasons stated, the Applicants' being close and married relatives is at odds with their being a homosexual couple who met by chance in 1994 and lived exclusively with each other in Bangladesh for four years until coming to Australia together.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The fact that they are married knocks out their claims about their aversion to heterosexual marriage.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It is plain that, where an order is set aside, and a matter is remitted to the Tribunal for reconsideration, there is nothing on which any issue estoppel can be founded: Morales v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [1998] FCA 334 ; (1998) 82 FCR 374 ; Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Wang (2003) 215 CLR 518.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It is perhaps understandable, in the light of the history of the proceedings from the decision of the delegate all the way to the High Court, but very unfortunate, that counsel for the appellants should have sought to argue issue estoppel.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: On 13 April 2006, Smith FM dismissed the application by the appellants for orders by way of judicial review of the decision of the second Tribunal handed down on 14 January 2005.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: That decision affirmed the decisions of the delegate of the Minister made on 23 April 1999, but on quite different factual findings.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The first Tribunal found that the appellants were homosexual; the second Tribunal found "the Applicants are close relatives who are, or have been married to women", and "for the reasons stated, the Applicants' being close and married relatives is at odds with their being a homosexual couple who met by chance in 1994 and lived exclusively with each other in Bangladesh for four years until coming to Australia together.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The fact that they are married knocks out their claims about their aversion to heterosexual marriage".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: An appeal from the judgment of Smith FM to the Federal Court (Emmett J) was allowed by consent, and the matter was remitted to the third Tribunal.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The findings of the third Tribunal were the subject of an unsuccessful appeal to the Federal Magistrates Court, and are now before this Court.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The appellants rely on four grounds before this Court.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Grounds 5 and 6 were not pressed.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The four grounds are: That Her Honour [Federal Magistrate Orchiston] erred in failing to find that the following findings of the Tribunal were procedurally unfair to the extent of jurisdictional error   (a) That the applicants are cousins once removed, such finding     (i) being contrary to unchallenged expert DNA evidence that the applicants were "unlikely to be related"; and (ii) being based in part on a finding ("the sub finding") that DNA evidence and in particular the cousins index was probative that the applicants are cousins once removed, the sub finding not being supported by or consistent with the unchallenged DNA evidence, and not being supported by any other evidence before the Tribunal.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (iii) being contrary to the evidence of each of the applicants and of the witness; and (iv) being otherwise based wholly on anonymous information     (b) That weight be given to anonymous "dob-in" information     (c) That the applicants are not homosexual or in a homosexual relationship   That her Honour erred in failing to find that the following findings of the Tribunal were "unreasonable" as that term is defined in Associated Provincial Picture Houses Ltd v Wednesbury Corp [1948] 1 KB 223, and that such unreasonableness amounts to jurisdictional error:-   (a) That the applicants are cousins once removed, such finding     (i) being contrary to unchallenged expert DNA evidence that the applicants were "unlikely to be related"; and (ii) being based in part on a finding ("the sub finding") that DNA evidence and in particular the cousins index was probative that the applicants are cousins once removed, the sub finding not being supported by or consistent with the unchallenged DNA evidence, and not being supported by any other evidence before the Tribunal.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (iii) being contrary to the evidence of each of the applicants and of the witness; and (iv) being otherwise based wholly on anonymous information     (b) That weight be given to anonymous "dob-in" information     (c) That the applicants are not homosexual or in a homosexual relationship   That her Honour erred in failing to find that the following findings of the Tribunal jointly and severally demonstrate bias on the part of the Tribunal amounting to jurisdictional error:-   (a) That the applicants are cousins once removed, such finding     (i) being contrary to unchallenged expert DNA evidence that the applicants were "unlikely to be related"; and  (ii) being based in part on a finding ("the sub finding") that DNA evidence and in particular the cousins index was probative that the applicants are cousins once removed, the sub finding not being supported by or consistent with the unchallenged DNA evidence, and not being supported by any other evidence before the Tribunal.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (iii) being contrary to the evidence of each of the applicants and of the witness; and (iv) being otherwise based wholly on anonymous information     (b) That weight be given to anonymous "dob-in" information     (c) That the applicants are not homosexual or in a homosexual relationship.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: That Her Honour erred in failing to find that the decision of the Tribunal taken as a whole is demonstrative of bias on the part of the Tribunal amounting to jurisdictional error; In my judgment, the decision of the third Tribunal was made in the teeth of the evidence.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Having regard to the legality/merits dichotomy of judicial review, this may, arguably, not be a sufficient basis for the Court to interfere.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: However, I find that the decision was perverse to such an extent as to exhibit a serious failure in the decision making process, with the consequences that the decision was so unreasonable that it was beyond power: see TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd v Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (1992) 28 ALD 829 at 861.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The decision of the third Tribunal manifests "an apprehension of predisposition, tendency or propensity towards a given result": NADH v Minister for Immigration amp; Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2004] FCAFC 328 ; (2004) 214 ALR 264 at [16] .

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: That apprehension is, in my judgment, well founded.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In NADH , Allsop J, with whom Moore and Tamberlin JJ agreed, said, at [16]:   Criticisms were ... made of how the tribunal reached a large body of factual findings.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It was said that the approach to finding the facts, and the facts as found, demonstrated a lack of impartiality.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: No particular interest, affection, enmity or prejudice was identified which might have occasioned or contributed to the impugned conduct or approach.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Thus formulated, the criticism of lack of impartiality is one which amounts to a complaint of an apprehension of predisposition, tendency or propensity towards a given result: cf Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Jia (2001) 205 CLR 507 ; 178 ALR 421 ; [2001] HCA 17 at [183] per Hayne J.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: I am satisfied that the decision of the third Tribunal has been moulded to support a particular conclusion, namely, that the appellants were not homosexual.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: I am satisfied that this was done, not as a genuine exercise of administrative fact finding to which Courts, and in particular this Court, should, and must, defer, but in an attempt to insulate the finding from judicial examination, because it was expressed as being based on credibility.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: While the facts were quite different, Lee, Hill and Marshall JJ in WAEJ v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (2003) 76 ALD 597, said, at [55]:    ... To make a bare assertion that the document was not genuine, that is to say, a forgery, would have been an arbitrary and unreasoned conclusion by the RRT unsupported by a scintilla of material.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: If the RRT had acted in such a manner it would have raised the perception that the findings made by the RRT in that regard had been moulded to support a particular conclusion: (see: Corporation of the City of Enfield v Development Assessment Commission [2000] HCA 5 ; (2000) 199 CLR 135 at 152, [42] .

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It is a temptation, into which, in my opinion, the third Tribunal fell, to state a finding (however improbable or extraordinary) as based on an assessment of credibility, as a means of attempting to "bullet proof" the administrative decision from judicial review.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: McHugh J in Re Minister for Immigration amp; Multicultural Affairs; Ex parte Durairajasingham [2000] HCA 1 ; (2000) 168 ALR 407 said, at [67]:   ... a finding as to whether the prosecutor should be believed in his claim --- a finding on credibility ... [is] the function of the primary decision-maker par excellence.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: If the primary decision-maker has stated that he or she does not believe a particular witness, no detailed reasons need to be given as to why that particular witness was not believed.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The tribunal must give the reasons for its decision, not the sub-set of reasons why it accepted or rejected individual pieces of evidence.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Brennan J, as he then was, said in Waterford v Commonwealth [1987] HCA 25 ; (1987) 163 CLR 54 , at 77:   There is no error of law simply in making a wrong finding of fact.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: A finding, which purports to be a finding of fact, is not rendered immune from judicial examination, if it is not made in good faith, but for an ulterior purpose: in this case, in the light of the remittal to the Tribunal by the High Court, to "get around" the factual findings that had earlier been made, in the enquiry as to whether the appellants were entitled to the issue of protection visas.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Whether the decision of the third Tribunal be regarded as unreasonable in the Wednesbury corporation sense, or on the basis that the decision was not made in good faith, or on the basis that there was a lack of impartiality in the fact-finding process, the decision of the third Tribunal has to be set aside.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Concerning Wednesbury unreasonableness, Weinberg J in Australian Retailers Association v Reserve Bank of Australia [2005] FCA 1707 ; (2005) 148 FCR 446 at [555] , referred to Aronson, Dyer and Groves', in Judicial Review of Administrative Decisions, 4 th Ed, view that the courts "regard this ground as representing a safety net, designed to catch the rare and totally absurd decision which has somehow managed to survive the application of all other grounds of review".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: His Honour quoted comments by Aronson, Dyer and Groves, at [565], that:   Confined to extreme cases ... [ Wednesbury unreasonableness] amounts to the sort of low-level quality control which most management systems should maintain in any event ... there would be serious credibility costs to the system if demonstrably absurd decisions were allowed to go unchecked.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: So too, in my judgment, would there be serious credibility costs to the system if decisions, not made bona fide, but contrived to reach a preordained result, were allowed to go unchecked.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It is now necessary to say with some particularity why, in my view, the judgment of the third Tribunal was not made bona fide.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: There are, in particular, two aspects of the evidence which were relied on by the Tribunal which lead me to conclude the Tribunal was concerned, not to find the facts truly, but to arrive at a predetermined conclusion, namely that the appellants were not homosexuals.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The third Tribunal had before it the evidence before the three Tribunals.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: A very large volume of material had been sought from the appellants by way of letters written pursuant to s 424A of the Act.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Much of the information sought has the flavour of interrogation directed at disproving the appellants' primary contention that they were homosexuals.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: There was a s 424A letter dated 5 November 2004 sent to the second appellant, the response of which was considered by the second Tribunal.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Further letters of invitation were sent by fax on 17 October 2007.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: As the third Tribunal noted:   These letters have not been reproduced in this decision record, because of the length of the invitations.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In question 8 of the letter, an officer of the Tribunal asked (with necessary changes to ensure anonymity):   In [SZFSG's] Application for a Protection visa, lodged on 4 March 1999, there is a reference to [a named person], who is noted as his brother.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Further, in the Application for Migration to Australia, by [SZFSG's] sister, she also notes [the same named person] as her brother.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Please provide proof that this person, who has exactly the same name as you, is not you.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: That is, that you [NAOX] are not [SZFSG's] brother.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In response to this request , the appellants went to the trouble and expense of securing DNA evidence.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The DNA testing report from DNA Laboratories Sydney was carried out on each appellant.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In the light of question 8, the report says:   Y chromosome analysis was also conducted on the samples from [each appellant] to try and establish if a common male lineage exists.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The report states that the result of the testing "excludes common paternal relationship".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The report further states:   The relationship testing results and mismatches on the Y chromosome do not support evidence of any genetic relationship between [NAOX] and [SZFSG].

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The report further stated:   We consider this evidence that [NAOX] and [SZFSG] are not likely to be related.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: There could, in my opinion, be no more comprehensive proof to the contrary of what was asserted in Question 8 of the letter of 17 October 2007.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The DNA analysis taken at the initiative of the appellants was done in order to establish that they are not brothers.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal, however, dissected the DNA analysis and focuses on a statement that there was "inconclusive evidence of a cousins relationship".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal, quite irrationally and indefensibly in my opinion:   ... finds that the DNA test was designed to provide (inter alia) an index showing evidence of a cousins relationship, limited to first cousins.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Further, having regard to a "dob-in" claim that the appellants are cousins once removed, the Tribunal said:   ... the Tribunal finds that there is a strong likelihood that the DNA results supports the dob-in information, in the context that the (first) cousins index was 0.63.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The treatment by the Tribunal of the information requested by the Tribunal, and the DNA analysis that was supplied in response to that question, which appears at pages 68 to 70 of the Tribunal's reasons, is not only wrong, but, in my judgment, contrived to support a predetermined result.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: There were further invitations sent by fax on 14 December 2007, as well as further invitations on 16 January 2008.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: On 16 January 2008 there was a complaint of inadequate transmission of 22 pages of the 52 page fax dated 16 January 2008.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: There was a request for an extension of time.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal responded:   In all the circumstances the Tribunal has considered the request for an extension to respond to the letters dated 16 January 2008 carefully, but have decided not to grant an extension of time for both matters.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The response by both appellants, received on 30 January 2008, made the point:   At the outset, we make the point that this tribunal ("the Third Tribunal") should disqualify itself on the grounds that its conduct gives rise to a reasonable apprehension of bias.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal is acting in a partisan manner to bring about a particular result.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In addition to the voluminous material already held by the RRT in respect of the hearings of the First and Second Tribunals, the Third Tribunal already has received answers to the following:-     (a) Letter dated 25 June 2007 from the Tribunal of two pages inviting comment on material which it was said might be the reason for affirming the decision under review.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (NB.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: This was responded to);     (b) Answers to questions asked of the applicants and their witness at the hearing of 2 nd August 2007;     (c) Twelve page letter from the Tribunal dated 17 October 2007 inviting comment on further material which it was said might be the reason for affirming the decision under review.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (NB.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: This was responded to);     (d) Seven page letter from the Tribunal dated 14 December 2007 inviting comment on further material which it was said might be the reason for affirming the decision under review.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (NB.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: This was responded to);     You now invite comment on your letters of 10 January (4 pages plus annexures) and your letter of 16 January (5 pages plus annexures).

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In the context of an application that has been before two previous Tribunals (the decision of the First Tribunal being overturned by the High Court and the decision of the Second Tribunal being overturned by consent by the Full Court of the Federal Court) the Third Tribunal's conduct to date does not look like that of a fair and impartial tribunal of fact.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Rather it has all the hallmarks of a decision maker attempting to find some justification for a decision it has already decided to make.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In the reasons of the third Tribunal, the Tribunal said:   Before proceeding to the findings and reasons, the Tribunal will turn to the requests for the Tribunal to disqualify itself for reasons of bias which are not discussed elsewhere in the decision record.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal is very concerned about claims relating to bias.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: As a result, the Tribunal has carefully considered the issues identified by the applicants' adviser regarding possible apprehended and/or actual bias ...   A fair reading of the third Tribunal's reasons and comments in this respect are highly argumentative and self-justifying.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In particular, the third Tribunal said:   ... in this case at the hearing before the third Tribunal, the Tribunal became aware of possible inconsistencies between parts of the applicants' evidence, possible internal contradictions in each of the applicant's evidence, and the first applicant's refusal to answer a question.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: These matters raised possible issues of truthfulness and credibility.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal also became aware at the hearing before the third Tribunal of possible inconsistencies and unreliability in the witness' evidence.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (Emphasis added)   I have already referred to the Tribunal's treatment of the DNA evidence.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The second discrete body of evidence, which in my judgment demonstrates the Tribunal did not approach its task bona fide, relates to the "first applicant's refusal to answer a question".

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: This evidence in my view, indicates that the Tribunal was not concerned with genuine fact finding, but was seeking to give effect to a preordained result.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In a letter dated 11 July 2007 signed and dated by both appellants, the following offer was made to the Tribunal:   Should you require it (although such a step would cause us significant embarrassment) we are prepared to have an adult witness view us engaged in an act of homosexual intercourse and then attest before you to that fact.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It would be illogical were you to refuse such an offer and then go on to find, as did Member Hardy, that we are not homosexual.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal in its reasons said:   At the hearing held before the Tribunal on 2 August 2007, the first applicant stated that he and the second applicant have sex in the morning.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal asked if they used a lubricant.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The first applicant stated that he did not wish to answer.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal said later in its reasons:   The Tribunal, with respect, has difficulty understanding how viewing an act of homosexual intercourse, where a lubricant may or may not be used, is less offensive to the applicants than answering a question as to whether a lubricant is used.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Because of the refusal to answer the Tribunal's question, and the lack of a cogent response, the Tribunal finds that the first applicant is not a truthful or credible witness.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: (Emphasis added)   The evidence concerning the "first respondent's refusal to answer a question" is as follows:   [THE TRIBUNAL]: Do you have sex in the morning?

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: THE INTERPRETER: This is a personal question.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: [THE TRIBUNAL]: You don't want to answer?

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: THE INTERPRETER: No.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: ...     [THE TRIBUNAL]: Do you have sex with him though?

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: THE INTERPRETER: Yes.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: ...     [THE TRIBUNAL]: Now you may not want to answer this question but when you do have sex do you use a lubricant?

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: [NAOX]: I don't want to.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: [THE TRIBUNAL]: Don't want to answer ... (Emphasis added)   It is one thing for the Tribunal to say that the first appellant refused to answer a question, and that this was the basis for finding that the first appellant was not a truthful or credible witness.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: It is quite another thing when the Tribunal prefaces the question "Now you may not want to answer this question, but when you do have sex, do you use a lubricant" to which the first appellant replied, "I don't want to.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: " And the Tribunal noted "Don't want to answer", and to use the first appellant's refusal to answer that question as the basis for a finding that the first appellant was not a truthful or credible witness.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: In my judgment, the decision of the third Tribunal was not made in good faith, and was unreasonable in the Wednesbury Corporation sense.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The Tribunal was guilty of bias, in the sense that it was predisposed to making its ultimate finding that the appellants were not in a homosexual relationship.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The appeal must be allowed, and the matter remitted, yet again, to the Tribunal, differently constituted, for consideration.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: The first respondent must pay the costs of the appellants, to be taxed if not agreed.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: I certify that the preceding eighty-two (82) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice Spender.

Name: NAOX v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCA 1056 (18 September 2009)
text: Associate:   Dated: 18 September 2009  Counsel for the Appellants: Mr B Levet   Counsel for the Respondents: Mr DH Godwin   Solicitor for the Respondents: Australian Government Solicitor  Date of Hearing: 12 May 2009   Date of Judgment: 18 September 2009    AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2009/1056.html

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: appeal from sequestration order of federal magistrate

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: construction and effect of undertaking given by appellant in form of consent orders

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: whether appellant's undertaking to not take proceedings to set aside bankruptcy notice covers opposition to creditor's petition

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: whether "sufficient cause" exists under s 52(2)(b) of the bankruptcy act 1966 (cth) to warrant dismissal of creditor's petition

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: whether there exists reasonable doubt as to the identity of creditor.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: bankruptcy

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 1 This appeal is from a judgment of Federal Magistrate Raphael of 8 March 2005 making a sequestration order against the appellant.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: There are four issues outlined in the Amended Notice of Appeal.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The first two concern the construction and effect of an undertaking given by consent and an order made by his Honour on 10 August 2005.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The third issue is whether his Honour erred in law in failing to dismiss the creditor's petition on the basis that there was sufficient cause for so doing under s 52(2)(b) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) ("the Act ").

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Fourthly, the issue is whether the bankruptcy notice is a nullity because there was reasonable doubt as to the identity of the creditor.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: OVERVIEW  2 This appeal arises in the context of a long complex history of nationwide litigation concerning recovery of solicitors' fees found to be due and owing to the respondent firm, Leonard Cohen amp; Co, based on costs taxed in the Western Australian District Court in an amount of $7,771.55.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The bankruptcy notice was issued by Leonard Cohen amp; Co on 13 January 2005 in relation to the above judgment debt.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The judgment debt was based on a judgment in the District Court of Western Australia in Matter No.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 3 On 30 June 2005, Registrar Tesoriero dismissed the appellant's application to set aside the bankruptcy notice.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: An application was then made to review that decision.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: On 10 August 2005, Federal Magistrate Raphael made orders by consent extending time for compliance with the bankruptcy notice until three working days after the decision was made on a strike out application then pending in the District Court brought by the respondent in respect of the appellant's cross-claim.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 4 On 24 August 2005, the District Court Registrar made orders in Matter No.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 2520 of 2003, dismissing the appellant's application to strike out the writ of summons and statement of claim.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 5 The orders of the consent orders and undertaking given and made on 10 August 2005 were in the following terms:  'Upon hearing Mr Gracie for the applicant and Mr Forbes for the respondent and upon the applicant undertaking that in the event that his joint application to the District Court of Western Australia to strike out proceedings No 2520 of 2003 is unsuccessful he will forthwith pay the amount claimed in bankruptcy Notice No 22 of 2005 and will take no further proceedings seeking to set aside the said notice and by consent:   THE COURT ORDERS THAT:    1.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Time for compliance with the Bankruptcy Notice 22 of 2005 extended until 3 working days after the decision of the Registrar District court in the strike out application is handed down or the strike out application is otherwise dismissed whichever is the earlier.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: In the event the strike out proceedings are decided in favour of the applicant and the proceedings 2520 of 2003 are struck out with costs the bankruptcy notice is set aside upon the making of such orders.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Costs of these proceedings will be reserved for decision and the parties are required to file with my associate and serve submissions thereon on or before 1 December 2005.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: '    6 The relief sought in the proceedings before the District Court Registrar as outlined on the Chamber Summons for Summary Judgment and strike out of the respondent's Writ of Summons and Statement Of Claim dated 14 April 2005 was stated as follows:  '(1) The time for bringing this application be extended.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: (2) Summary judgment be entered against the Plaintiff.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: (3) In the alternative to 2 the Plaintiff's claim be struck out in its entirety as vexatious and/or an abuse of the process of the court.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: (4) The Plaintiff's claim be dismissed.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: (5) Alternatively this matter be stayed.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: (6) Such further alternative relief as the court deems fit.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: (7) [An application for costs.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: ]' 7 The orders made on that application by the Deputy Registrar on 24 August 2005 were as follows:  (1) 'Paragraph 3 of the application be dismissed.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: (2) The balance of the application be adjourned sine dine .

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: (3) Costs be reserved.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: '    8 The respondent filed its creditor's petition dated 15 December 2005 and the Federal Magistrate made the Sequestration Order on 8 March 2006 after hearing the parties.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: ISSUE 1 --- TIME FOR COMPLIANCE  9 The appellant submits that on a proper construction of the Court Order of 24 August 2005 there was no decision on the strike out application because the expression "strike out application" was intended to refer to a decision which disposed of every prayer for relief in the summons and application to strike out heard by the District Court Deputy Registrar.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: This application, it is said, sought additional orders to the strike out, including an application that there be summary judgment against Leonard Cohen amp; Co and that the proceedings be dismissed.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 10 Order 16 of the District Court Rules gives the power to grant summary judgment.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The language of the Court Order is clear, and it refers specifically to the strike out application and not to the disposition of the application before the Deputy Registrar.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Separate relief was sought based on two different orders.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The strike out application was dismissed.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The strike out application was therefore the subject of "a decision".

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: There is no reference in the Chamber Summons to the disposition of all relief sought in the summons, including summary judgment and other prayers in the summons.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: On the contrary, the reference was, by consent, limited specifically to the application for a strike out.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: One must assume that when orders of this nature are consented to, careful thought has been given to the precise wording.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Accordingly, for these reasons, the "three working days" as referred to in the Consent Orders, ran from the making of the Court Order dismissing the strike out application on 24 August 2005.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The fact that there is a reference to the balance of the application being adjourned and costs reserved does not affect this conclusion.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 11 Accordingly, I do not accept the appellant's submission on the first issue.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: ISSUE TWO --- UNDERTAKING  12 The application to strike out was unsuccessful.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The undertaking given in terms committed the appellant to forthwith pay the amount claimed in the bankruptcy action and to take no further proceedings seeking to set aside the notice.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: This undertaking was enlivened on and after dismissal of the strike out.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 13 It must also be kept in mind that in the judgment under appeal, the learned Magistrate was construing the consent undertaking and not a statutory instrument.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The undertaking is a consensual document and it is the common intent of the parties in giving and accepting the obligations therein, as reasonably construed in the light of the context, which determines its effect.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The appellant submits that the undertaking does not cover an opposition to a creditor's petition on the ground that the bankruptcy notice should be set aside.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: It is said that opposition to a sequestration order under s 52 of the Act raises some different considerations to those relevant to an application to set aside a bankruptcy notice under s 40.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: This can be accepted.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 14 However, in the context of this litigation, the Consent Orders were intended to and in terms require the appellant to refrain from any further challenges to the bankruptcy notice in whatever form and at whatever stage such challenge is made.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The procedure to oppose the petition involves filing a Notice of Opposition and an Affidavit: see O 77 r 11 of the Federal Court (Bankruptcy) Rules .

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The purpose of the undertaking is that no steps will be taken to challenge the notice as a condition of the respondent's agreement to extend the time for compliance until a decision is made on the strike out application.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: There is an inconsistency between an undertaking not to take proceedings to set aside the bankruptcy notice yet to reserve a right to achieve the same result under the discretionary power given in s 52(2).

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The undertaking does not limit the expression 'proceedings' to one under s 40 of the Act .

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: It commits the appellant not to take any proceedings which produce the result of effectively setting aside the notice for this reason.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: I do not accept the submission of the appellant on this second issue.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: ISSUE 3 --- S 52 --- SUFFICIENT CAUSE  15 Under s 52(2) of the Act , if the Court is not satisfied with proof of any of the matters specified in the creditor's petition, or is satisfied by the debtor that for other sufficient cause a sequestration order ought not be made, the Court has a discretion to dismiss the petition.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: This discretionary power is broad.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 16 The onus is on the appellant to establish "sufficient cause".

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The appellant relies on outstanding costs orders against the respondent which have been made but which have not been taxed.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The appellant relies on the evidence of a costs expert that the total amount will exceed the debt in the bankruptcy notice.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 17 A similar argument was not successful on the application to set aside the bankruptcy notice before Registrar Tesoriero.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The respondent refers to judgments and orders for costs untaxed in other proceedings, which are said to exceed the costs referred to by the appellant.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The potential claim of the appellant for costs is said to be in the order of an amount less than $20,000.00, whereas there is an outstanding judgment in favour of the respondent for $240,512.51 exclusive of costs.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 18 Having regard to the consent undertaking, the judgments referred to in submissions, and the relative costs awards together with the outstanding judgment sum of $240,512.51, the appellant has not satisfied me that there is "other sufficient cause" which would warrant dismissal of the petition.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: It is not necessary for me to consider, as a matter of law, whether the undertaking precludes the appellant from raising this issue, but it clearly is an important matter for consideration when contemplating the exercise of the statutory discretion.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: ISSUE 4 --- IDENTITY OF CREDITORS  19 The appellant submits that the bankruptcy notice should be set aside because there is uncertainty as to the identity of the judgment creditor.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Counsel does not submit that there is any direct evidence from the appellant that he was misled as to the creditor.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Nor is there any suggestion that the appellant made any attempt to pay the outstanding monies as required by the bankruptcy notice.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Nevertheless, it is contended by the appellant that the judgment debtor must not be left in any reasonable doubt as to the identity of the judgment creditor.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 20 Counsel for the appellant submits that there was reasonable doubt in this case having regard to the following circumstances.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The respondent says that the agreements it sues on were on entered into on 21 September 1995 and 1 October 1995, at a time when Mr Leonard Cohen was a sole trader carrying on business under the name "Leonard Cohen amp; Co." On 1 November 2005, Messrs Georgiou and Vertannes joined the partnership.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 21 The evidence of Mr Georgiou in an affidavit signed on 17 May 2005 is that it was a term of the partnership agreement that the partnership assumed all rights and obligations of Mr Cohen's existing practice as from 1 November 1995, excluding debtors to whom accounts had been rendered prior to 1 November 1995.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Mr Georgiou notes that included in the rights and obligations were all the rights and obligations pursuant to the agreement entered into on 21 September 1995 between Leonard Cohen amp; Co and the appellant.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: He states that on 1 November 1995, the respondent further assumed all rights and obligations in relation to the written retainer agreement entered into on that day.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: On 8 December 1995, a Statement of Change in Registered Particulars was registered reflecting the change as to owners of the business name.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 22 The work which is the subject of the relevant claim was carried out by the firm from September 1995 and ceased in February 1998, when instructions were withdrawn.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: When the first writ was issued on 17 March 2000, the three above named persons traded as "Leonard Cohen amp; Co." The writ in respect of which the relevant costs order was made was issued when Messrs Georgiou and Vertannes owned the company name.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 23 On 30 June 2003, Mr Cohen ceased to be a co-proprietor of the business name, but there is evidence that the partnership with Messrs Georgiou and Vertannes was continued for limited purposes, presumably in order to wind up all the affairs of the partnership, including collection of all debts.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 24 The appellant says that there was reasonable doubt in his mind as to the identity of the creditor, and that therefore the notice is a nullity.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The question is whether a reasonable person in the position of the appellant would have been misled.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 25 It is common ground that a firm can bring bankruptcy proceedings in the firm name under s 307 of the Act , and that a change in the composition of the firm does not invalidate the bankruptcy notice: Anderson Rice v Bride (1995) 61 FCR 529 and 542.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The Full Court in Anderson Rice noted that it is the duty of the debtor to seek out and to pay the judgment creditor, if the creditor is in Australia: James v Federal Commissioner for Taxation [1955] HCA 75 ; (1955) 93 CLR 631 at 639.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: This reasoning is applicable in the present case.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 26 I am not persuaded that there was any basis on which it could be established that the appellant had any reasonable ground to doubt that those parties constituting the firm under the name Leonard Cohen amp; Co obtained the rights to remuneration and obligations in respect of work during September 1995 through February 1998, or that they were the proprietors of the firm entitled to recover the fees.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: At all relevant times in this period, the partnership was constituted by Mr Cohen and as from 1 November 2005, with retrospective effect, the firm included Messrs Cohen, Georgiou and Vertannes.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 27 I note that the bankruptcy notice of 13 January 2005 referred to "Leonard Cohen amp; Co" and gave the address of that firm.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: It also stated that payment could be made to Stewart Forbes, Barrister and Solicitor at 16 Irwin Street, Perth and the evidence indicates that no attempt was made to proffer any such payment.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: The Notice also specifies that Mr Forbes, who issued the notice, was the agent of the creditors.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 28 The evidence does not establish that the appellant was misled as to the persons to whom he should pay the debt, nor that he had any reasonable doubt as to when the work was done or that such work included work up to February 1998.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: He could have made payment to Stewart Forbes and this would have satisfied the Notice.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Accounting between the parties as to the allocation of the payment was a matter for them.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 29 This case is in no way comparable the facts in McWilliam v Jackson [2000] FCA 175 ; (2000) 96 FCR 561 where the creditor was identified in the notice as "Anthony Jackson amp; Others.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: " The reference to "others" in that case was open-ended and uncertain on its face.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 30 I do not accept this final ground.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Furthermore, I consider that it is contrary to the undertaking given by the appellant.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: 31 For the above reasons this appeal is dismissed with costs.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: I certify that the preceding thirty-one (31) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice Tamberlin.

Name: Paligorov v Cohen [2006] FCA 1473 (10 November 2006)
text: Associate:Dated: 10 November 2006 Counsel for the Appellant: J C Giles   Solicitor for the Appellant: George M Livaditis   Counsel for the Respondent: B W Ashdown   Solicitor for the Respondent: Stewart Forbes   Date of Hearing: 14 September 2006   Date of Judgment: 10 November     AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2006/1473.html

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: appeal from decision of administrative appeals tribunal affirming decision of social security appeals tribunal (ssat)

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: ssat upheld decision of centrelink review officer to cancel the applicant's newstart allowance

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: applicant was required to sign a newstart activity agreement but did not do so

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: whether denial of natural justice

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: whether delegation of decision-making powers valid

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: whether matter should be adjourned further to enable the applicant to obtain legal assistance

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: social security

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: INTRODUCTION  The applicant (Mr Zoia) 'appeals' pursuant to s 44(1) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 (Cth) (the AAT).

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: On 4 September 2008, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (the AAT) affirmed a decision of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) of 23 November 2007.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The SSAT found that the decision of the authorised review officer of Centrelink of 27 September 2007 to cancel Mr Zoia's Newstart allowance from 24 July 2007 was correct.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The AAT affirmed that decision.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: In that hearing, Mr Zoia had sought an adjournment of his hearing on the basis that he did not want the AAT to make a decision in the matter but that he wanted the Minister for Centrelink to do so.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The AAT declined that application for an adjournment on the basis that it had a duty to make a decision.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The relevant issues before the AAT were: Section 605(2) and (3) of the Social Security Act 1991 (Cth) (the SS Act) provides that the Secretary can require a person who has entered into a Newstart Activity Agreement to enter a new agreement by giving a person notice of the requirement and the place and time the agreement is to be negotiated.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Such notices were sent to Mr Zoia.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Mr Zoia acknowledged that in response he had attended at Centrelink offices several times but that he did not sign the Agreement despite a number of requests to do so.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: He was also warned of the consequences of failing to sign the Agreement but declined to do so.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The AAT concluded that Mr Zoia by his own admissions made at the AAT acknowledged that he had no reasonable excuse pursuant to s 626 of the SS Act for not entering into the Newstart Activity Agreement.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: At the heart of Mr Zoia's appeal as best one can discern it is the argument that his Newstart allowance should not have been cancelled as there was no power to compel him to sign the new Newstart Activity Agreement.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: APPLICATIONS TO ADJOURN  Shortly prior to the hearing of this appeal on 5 August 2009, Mr Zoia wrote to the Western Australia District Registry of this Court requesting an opportunity to read the transcript of a hearing to which the reasons in Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations [2009] FCA 661 relate.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: On the occasion of that hearing (which was to be the hearing of the appeal) it had been necessary to adjourn the substantive hearing of the appeal in order to consider Mr Zoia's argument that the appeal was a nullity.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: While the discussion which ensued at that hearing could have no possible bearing on the substantive appeal, the starting time of the appeal was nevertheless deferred to permit Mr Zoia the opportunity to read the transcript.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: At the re-listed hearing of the appeal on 5 August 2009 Mr Zoia sought to re-agitate the issues dealt with in that interlocutory hearing.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: I did not permit that course.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Mr Zoia sought a further adjournment of the hearing of the appeal on two grounds.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The respondent opposed the application.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The first ground was that he has sought access to a transcript of a directions hearing in which orders had been made pursuant to O 53 of the Federal Court Rules dealing with the procedural aspects of the appeal.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: In particular, he complained that he did not know what was involved in the settling of an appeal book index.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: To the extent that access to that transcript was required, it would inevitably have occasioned an adjournment because no transcript had been produced.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: I will assume that there is a recording in existence of that directions hearing which was conducted in October 2008.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: A further adjournment would not have been in the interests of justice.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Mr Zoia apparently did not attend on the adjourned appointment for the settling of his appeal book index.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: I was informed by counsel for the respondent, and accept, that in light of his non-attendance, the respondent ensured that all of the material that had been before the AAT was made available in the appeal book for this hearing.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: In those circumstances, Mr Zoia was unable to identify and I was unable to discern any prejudice which would have been occasioned to him by proceeding with the hearing of the appeal.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: I also note, as submitted by counsel for the respondent, that Mr Zoia is no stranger to litigation and, in particular, has previously been involved in at least one appeal from the AAT and has some familiarity with the process.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The second ground on which Mr Zoia sought an adjournment was in order to obtain legal advice.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: I accept Mr Zoia's argument that he is not well versed in the law.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: But I also concluded that the interests of justice did not support the granting of a further adjournment for the following grounds and I declined to permit it.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Mr Zoia made a further application for legal assistance to the Attorney-General's Department which was rejected in March this year on the basis that the view was formed that his appeal did not appear to have sufficient prospects of success.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: As late as July this year following the adjournment of the first return date for the hearing of the appeal (too late in my opinion) he pursued a further application knowing, however, that the matter was listed for hearing on 5 August 2009.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
