text: There is little reason to think that that late application would have met with success, that is to say, that the Attorney-General would have formed a contrary view to that expressed some months ago as to the prospects of success of the appeal.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Steps were taken last year to endeavour to find a pro bono legal practitioner to advise Mr Zoia in relation to his appeal.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Those steps were unsuccessful.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: As will be evident from the reasons which follow, the grounds of appeal on their face are barely intelligible and Mr Zoia's argument in support of them which has been raised at previous interlocutory hearings is equally lacking in clarity.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: On the other hand, Mr Zoia has raised similar points to those which he seemingly wishes to raise in this appeal in an appeal which is the subject of a decision by Siopis J in Zoia v Secretary, Department of Employment and Workplace Relations [2008] FCA 988.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Mr Zoia was self-represented and argued that appeal himself apparently with sufficient ability to at least convey to his Honour part of the nature of his complaint.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: His Honour having ruled against him on that complaint already, it is not particularly surprising that Mr Zoia's attempts to obtain legal assistance have not met with success.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: On the basis therefore of delay in bringing the oral application, or the repetition of earlier argument which had been rejected and that a reasonable opportunity had been given already to attempt to obtain legal representation, the request for a further adjournment for that purpose was declined.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The appeal therefore proceeded.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: On a number of occasions in the course of argument on the appeal, Mr Zoia indicated that he would like leave to appeal to the High Court to ventilate both the need for legal counsel and certain constitutional arguments.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: I made it clear to Mr Zoia that if his appeal before me was unsuccessful, he would have the opportunity to appeal to the Full Federal Court and a further opportunity from there if he was unsuccessful again, to seek leave to appeal to the High Court.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: It was made clear to Mr Zoia that it was not within my power to grant him leave to appeal to the High Court.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: AN UNREPRESENTED LITIGANT  I have endeavoured to be mindful of special considerations applicable when a litigant is unrepresented ( Minogue v Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission [1999] FCA 85 ; (1999) 84 FCR 438 , Sahtout v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2002] FCAFC 16 at [42]; Rogers v Law Coast Mortgages Pty Ltd [2002] FCA 181).

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: In Platcher v Joseph [2004] FCAFC 68 , the Full Court (at [104]-[106]) addressed the several authorities on this topic.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: In a civil case, the balance between affording assistance to an unrepresented party and not conferring an advantage on that party is to be observed.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The degree of assistance necessary will vary according to the circumstances (at [105]).

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Consistently with the approach suggested by these authorities, the notice and grounds of appeal needed a deal of interpretation to be understood.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The pursuit of that course has been attempted.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: THE APPEAL  For convenience, I again set out the notice of appeal, the orders sought and the grounds in support of the notice of appeal in this matter:  1.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: TAKE NOTICE that the applicant appeals from the decision of  constituted by Ms G Ettinger  given on 4 September 2008 at Perth  whereby the Tribunal decided affirms the decision of the SSAT dated 23 November 2007   2.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: THE QUESTIONS OF LAW raised on the appeal are  1.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The High Court Judgment --- Huddart, Parker amp; Co Pty Ltd v Moorehead [1909] HCA 36 ; (1909) 8 CLR 330.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Failed Justice.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Failed Natural Justice.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Failed Magna Carta, any charter guaranteeing liberty, any fundamental constitution or law guaranteeing rights.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Failed Liberty, freedom to do as one please: power of free choice: privileges, rights, etc. "CATCHWORDS", "Applicant refused to sign new Agreement", where is Peter Langley affidavit saying that.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: My Unemployment Benefits was cancel on Peter Langley information.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: I said to Peter, could you make the date after the hearing.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Set the decision aside and substitute a new decision, that is despot justice, and also make them judge and jury.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Set the decision aside, cancel, and substitute a new decision, that new decision can not be cancel.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: ARO, Brenda Parker can not correct a deception.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Centrelink was trying to collect a debt from me.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Constitution 64. can not be delegated.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: This month at Max Employment, I was told, a Lawyer can get it but I can't.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: About Peter Langley information or notes.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: ORDERS SOUGHT  My Unemployment Benefits to be fully restored plus compensation or ex gratia.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Federal Court Rules --- Pro Bono Publico.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The Hon Court to summon Peter Langley to give his information.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Secretary, Department of Employment and Workplace Relations to be changed to Minister, for Centrelink, under Constitution 64.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: GROUNDS:  1.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The High Court Judgment --- Huddart, Parker amp; Co Pty Ltd v Moorehead [1909] HCA 36 ; (1909) 8 CLR 330.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Magna Carta  4.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Peter Langley information and notes.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Justice and Natural Justice.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: There is no obvious question of law disclosed in this notice of appeal filed.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Although the notice and grounds of appeal together with the oral argument were difficult to comprehend, the main thrust of the complaint raised by Mr Zoia was that there was no power on the part of the respondent or anyone else to compel him to sign an agreement before paying him a Newstart allowance.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: This appears to be similar to one of the arguments that was advanced without success before Siopis J in Zoia [2008] FCA 988.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: There has been no appeal from that decision although Mr Zoia did contend before me that it was incorrect.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The second aspect of the argument appears to be that, in fact, Mr Zoia had indicated that he was prepared to sign the agreement notwithstanding his primary position that he was not obliged to do so and that his willingness to sign the agreement was not taken into account.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: As to this argument, there was no evidence in support of this suggestion but, in any event, it could not constitute any reviewable error of law on the part of the AAT.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: There were subsidiary issues which I have also endeavoured to address.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: CONSTITUTIONAL POINTS  Although reference is made to the Constitution in the grounds of appeal in this matter, s 78B of the Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth) does not apply in circumstances where the constitutional question is manifestly unarguable ( Australian Competition amp; Consumer Commission v CG Berbatis Holdings Pty Ltd [1999] FCA 1151 ; (1999) 95 FCR 292 at 297 per French J and Daniels v Deputy Commissioner of Taxation [2007] SASC 431 at [17] - [19] ).

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: That is so in this instance.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: RESTRICTION OF PERSONAL FREEDOMS AND PRIVILEGES  Paragraphs 5 and 6 of the notice of appeal appear to assert that personal freedoms and privileges guaranteed by the Magna Carta and the Constitution have been breached.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: There is no freedom 'to do as one please(s)' to be found in the Constitution .

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Nor is there a charter guaranteeing a subject's liberty.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The High Court in Kruger v Commonwealth [1997] HCA 27 ; (1997) 190 CLR 1 held (at 61) (footnotes omitted):  In a number of recent cases it has been pointed out that the Australian Constitution , with few exceptions and in contrast with its American model, does not seek to establish personal liberty by placing restrictions upon the exercise of governmental power.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Those who framed the Australian Constitution accepted the view that individual rights were on the whole best left to the protection of the common law and the supremacy of parliament.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Thus the Constitution deals, almost without exception, with the structure and relationship of government rather than with individual rights.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The fetters which are placed upon legislative action are, for the most part, for the purpose of distributing power between the federal government on the one hand and State governments on the other, rather than for the purpose of placing certain matters beyond the reach of any parliament.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The Constitution does not contain a Bill of Rights .

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Indeed, the 1898 Constitutional Convention rejected a proposal to include an express guarantee of individual rights based largely upon the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution and including a right to due process of law and the equal protection of laws.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The framers preferred to place their faith in the democratic process for the protection of individual rights and saw constitutional guarantees as restricting that process .

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: (emphasis added)  The Courts have previously considered the Commonwealth's power to impose conditions on the grant and payment of Newstart allowance.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: In Higgins v Commonwealth (1998) 79 FCR 528 , Finn J considered the scope of the power of the Commonwealth to provide unemployment benefits.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: His Honour said (at 532):  As a matter of characterisation, it is not open to serious argument that s 634 is a law with respect to the provision of unemployment benefits.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The "sufficiency of [s 634's] connection" with the head of power - cf Leask v Commonwealth [1996] HCA 29 ; (1996) 140 ALR 1 at 33 - is incontrovertible.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The power to provide such benefits must, I consider, include at its "core" ... powers (a) to stipulate qualifications for entitlement to, and for continuing entitlement to, unemployment benefits; and (b) to impose disqualifications (temporary or permanent) on entitlement to ... or continuing entitlement to ... unemployment benefits.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Provided the criteria adopted do not otherwise offend a constitutional provision or limitation, the "justice and wisdom" of the criteria so selected are matters for the legislature not the courts ... (emphasis added)  A person does not have a right to receive a social security payment, benefit or allowance.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The requirements prescribed by the SS Act are to be satisfied before such support is given.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: As found in Higgins 79 FCR 528 , it is within the Parliament's legislative power to impose conditions for the qualification and payability of social security payments.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: NATURAL JUSTICE  The applicant appears to claim he has been denied natural justice in relation to this matter.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: There is no support for that contention on the evidence.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The applicant was afforded the opportunity to put material before the decision-maker as part of the internal review processes, to present his case to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and to present his case to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (the AAT).

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The argument as to a lack of natural justice is rejected.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: DELEGATION OF DECISION-MAKING POWERS  The applicant also appears to assert that s 64 of the Constitution cannot be delegated.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Section 64 of the Constitution provides as follows:  64 Ministers of State  The Governor-General may appoint officers to administer such departments of State of the Commonwealth as the Governor-General in Council may establish.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Such officers shall hold office during the pleasure of the Governor-General.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: They shall be members of the Federal Executive Council, and shall be the Queen's Ministers of State for the Commonwealth.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Ministers to sit in Parliament   After the first general election no Minister of State shall hold office for a longer period than three months unless he is or becomes a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: As best it can be understood, the applicant's argument appears to be that only the relevant Minister can make a valid decision to cancel a person's Newstart allowance under the SS Act.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: This argument is incorrect.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: One of the functions of a Minister of State of the Commonwealth as specified in s 64 of the Constitution is to administer such departments of the Commonwealth as the Governor-General in Council may establish.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: From time to time administrative arrangement orders (AAO) are issued to specify matters for which a department is responsible, namely:  (a) the matters referred to in the Part of the Schedule relating to that Department; and (b) matters arising under the legislation administered by a Minister of State administering the Department.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: (emphasis added)  The following table sets out the department which was responsible for 'matters arising' under the SS Act with respect to Newstart allowance at the time of various key events in relation to these proceedings: Date Event AAO in Force Responsible Department 07/08/2007 Applicant's Newstart allowance cancelled AAO issued on 21/09/2006, covering the period 30/01/2007 to 21/12/2007 Department of Employment and Workplace Relations 27/09/2007 Authorised review officer reviewed and affirmed the cancellation decision AAO issued on 29/09/2006, covering the period 30/01/2007 to 21/12/2007 Department of Employment and Workplace Relations 23/11/2007 Social Security Appeals Tribunal reviewed and affirmed the cancellation decision AAO issued on 21/09/2006, covering the period 31/01/2007 to 21/12/2007 Department of Employment and Workplace Relations 10/12/2007 Application filed with the AAT AAO issued on 03/12/2007, covering the period 03/12/2007 to 24/01/2008 Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations 04/09/2008 AAT's decision issued AAO issued on 25/01/2008 (as amended on 01/05/2008), which commenced on 25/01/2008 and which continues in force Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations 24/09/2008 Notice of Appeal filed AAO issued on 25/01/2008 (as amended on 01/05/2008), which commenced on 25/01/2008 and continues in force Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations DELEGATION OF DECISION-MAKING/REVIEW POWERS TO OFFICERS AND AAT  Paragraphs 8-10 of the notice of appeal appear to assert that the power to make a decision as to the qualification of a person for the Newstart allowance cannot be delegated.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: This is not correct.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The broad power of delegation granted to the Secretary in s 234 of the Social Security (Administration) Act 1999 makes this clear.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: See also s 126(3) and s 149 of that Act and s 43(1) of the AAT Act which permits review of decisions made under the social security law and to affirm, vary, set aside, substitute a new decision or remit the matter to the Secretary for reconsideration.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: INTELLIGIBILITY OF NOTICE OF APPEAL  Although the Court and the respondent have endeavoured to interpret what it is that Mr Zoia was seeking to contend in his notice of appeal, shortly put, most of the notice of appeal is almost unintelligible.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Mr Zoia is a reasonably frequent litigant in this Court and may recall the decision of French J (as his Honour then was) in Zoia v Secretary, Department of Family and Community Services [2004] FCA 863 where his Honour said (at [5]):  On the face of the notice of appeal there is no intelligible appeal or matter put before the Court.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: In my opinion the notice of appeal should be struck out without any further delay and the application dismissed.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: The time of the Court and of the respondent is not to be taken up by responding to matters which do not contain any intelligible basis upon which the dispute or matter in question can be identified.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: To the extent I have not already rejected Mr Zoia's apparent contentions, I adopt his Honour's approach to the matter.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: For the same additional reasons, this application will be dismissed.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: I certify that the preceding thirty-five (35) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice McKerracher.

Name: Zoia v Secretary, Department of Education, Employment and Workplace Relations (No 2) [2009] FCA 924 (21 August 2009)
text: Associate:  Dated: 21 August 2009  The Applicant represented himself   Counsel for the Respondent: S Oliver   Solicitor for the Respondent: Australian Government Solicitor  Date of Hearing: 5 August 2009   Date of Judgment: 21 August 2009    AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2009/924.html

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: extension of times fixed by class order

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: whether permissible under s 1322(4)(d)

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: corporations

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 1 Section 1322(4)(d) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) confers power upon the court to extend or abridge the period for doing any act "in relation to a corporation".

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The section does not, however, identify the instrument or authority that has prescribed the period which the court is able to extend or abridge.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: This has been left for the court to work out having regard to the purpose of the provision.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: In this case I held that s 1322(4)(d) permitted the court to extend the time for doing certain acts fixed by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission in a class order made under s 341.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The times were then extended after I had satisfied myself, as required by s 1322(6)(c) , that no substantial injustice would be caused by the order.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: I indicated that in due course I would give reasons for my decision because the application of s 1322(4)(d) to a class order gave rise to nice questions of construction that had not previously been considered by a court.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 2 The Corporations Act contains (and prior Company Acts contained) strict requirements for the preparation, content and auditing of a company's annual financial report, for the distribution of that report to members for their consideration at an annual general meeting and for the lodging of the report with the appropriate regulatory authority.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The current provisions are to be found in Part 2M.3.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 3 In the case of group companies the reporting obligations can be unduly burdensome.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Accordingly ASIC has (and under former legislation its predecessors had) power to relieve a company from the requirement to comply with the provisions.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Presently the power is found in s 341.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Pursuant to that section ASIC may make an order relieving a wholly owned subsidiary of a body corporate from complying with the reporting obligations.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: ASIC has made an order under the section which provides that relief but only if certain conditions are satisfied.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The most important condition is that the holding company prepare consolidated financial statements that cover the subsidiary.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Other conditions are that (1) the holding company lodges its annual report as required by the legislation (s 319(3) provides that the report is to be lodged four months after the end of the financial year); (2) the notes to the financial statements include a short description of the deed of cross guarantee to which the members of the group are required to be a party, and also include a list of the parties to the guarantee; (3) within four months of the end of the financial year the subsidiary lodge a notice that the directors have resolved that the subsidiary remain party to the cross guarantee and take advantage of the order; (4) supplemental financial data be consolidated and filed that does not include data from group members that are not party to the deed of cross guarantee; (5) the holding company state that the members of the group will be able to meet any liabilities arising by virtue of the deed of cross guarantee; and (6) three years before and at all times after the subsidiary takes advantage of the relief given by the order, the subsidiary satisfies each of the obligations under Chapters 2M and 2N of the Corporations Act .

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 4 The plaintiffs are members of the Dana Australia group of companies.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The first plaintiff is the holding company and the other plaintiffs are its wholly owned subsidiaries.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The group assembles and distributes drive train products for the automotive industry.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: On any view it is a sizeable operation.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The group's annual operating profit before tax is more than $40 million; its total net equity exceeds $150 million.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 5 Since 1993 the subsidiaries have taken advantage of the class orders and have not prepared or lodged any financial reports.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Following a recent internal review it has been discovered that the first plaintiff and its subsidiaries have not, however, complied fully with the conditions in the class orders.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: In particular, annual reports have been filed later than required; notices that the subsidiary has taken advantage of the class order were not filed at all; the directors have not filed resolutions of their intent to remain party to the deed of cross guarantee; there have been no statements ensuring the ability of members of the group to meet any obligations or liabilities arising under the deed of cross guarantee; separate filings have not been submitted which only include financial information from parties to the deed of cross guarantee; there have been no descriptions of the deed of cross guarantee nor lists of its parties that are members of the group.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The conditions were not satisfied partly by reason of mistake, partly because of oversight and, to some extent, as a result of neglect.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Nonetheless as soon as the problem was discovered the plaintiffs took steps to rectify the position.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The appropriate documents were prepared and filed.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: But the filings were late.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The question was whether the prescribed periods could be extended and so validate the filings.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: To this end the plaintiffs turned to s 1322(4)(d).

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: They said that under this section the court can extend the times fixed by the class order.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 6 In considering whether s 1322(4)(d) confers that power it is necessary to distinguish between a period that is fixed by ASIC directly in the class order (for example the obligation to lodge a notice within a set period) and a period that is fixed by the Corporations Act itself but which is picked up by the class order (such as the obligation to lodge an annual report within the time fixed by the legislation).

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: In the latter case the view I take is that if the period fixed by the Corporations Act is extended by an order made under s 1322(4)(d) and the relevant act is then performed within the extended period, the condition of the class order will have been satisfied.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Put another way, when a time fixed by the Corporations Act is incorporated into the class order then the incorporation is of that time as may be extended under s 1322(4)(d).

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: That approach does no damage to the language of the existing class order and in any event is, I think, what was intended.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: On this aspect it must be remembered that ASIC does not have power to extend times prescribed by the class order.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 7 The more difficult question is whether the section permits an extension of a period fixed directly by ASIC in the class order itself.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Section 1322(4) derives from s 366(4) of the Uniform Companies Acts of 1961.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Section 366(4) provided:  "The Court (whether the company is in process of being wound up or not) may enlarge or abridge any time for doing any act or taking any proceeding allowed or limited by this Act or any rules or regulations thereunder upon such terms (if any) as the justice of the case may require and any such enlargement may be ordered although the application for the same is not made until after the time originally allowed or limited.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: "  It will be noticed immediately that the power of the court to enlarge or abridge time was confined to times that were fixed by the Companies Act or by the rules or regulations made under the Companies Act.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The court did not have power to extend the time fixed by any other instrument, for example a class order.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 8 Although it is derived from s 366(4), s 1322(4)(d) is cast in different terms.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Relevantly it provides that: "the Court may ... make ... (d) an order extending the period for doing any act, matter or thing or instituting or taking any proceeding under this Act or in relation to a corporation".

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: No longer is there a reference to the period that may be extended or abridged as being a period that is fixed by the Act or by the rules or regulations made under the Act.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The reason for the change is not clear.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: It is not discussed in the Explanatory Paper for the State legislation or the Explanatory Memorandum for the Commonwealth Bill.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Nevertheless, one thing is certain: Parliament did not intend to narrow the operation of the section.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: On this basis it is easy to conclude that s 1322(4)(d) allows the court to extend or abridge periods prescribed not only by the Corporations Act and any rules or regulations made under the Act, but also periods prescribed by some other instrument or authority.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 9 In Elderslie Finance Corporation Ltd v Australian Securities Commission (1993) 11 ACSR 157 a somewhat similar problem arose.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: A company had filed a prospectus for the purposes of a capital raising.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Under the legislation then in force the company could not issue the securities following the expiration of six months from the date of issue of the prospectus.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: By s 1084(2) of the Corporations Law the Australian Securities Commission was permitted to "exempt a particular person or persons ... either unconditionally or subject to such conditions (if any) as are specified in the exemption" from compliance with provisions regulating securities offerings and from compliance with regulations made in furtherance of those provisions.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: ASC made a declaration under the section subject to certain conditions.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: One condition was that within a certain period the directors of the company should submit a report (the content of which is not particularly relevant) to the Commission.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The report was not lodged within time and an application for an extension was sought under s 1322(4)(d).

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Owen J found that he had power to grant the extension.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: He reasoned (at 160) that the section "is a remedial remedy and should be given a liberal construction".

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: He did not, however, state how the section should be read when given a "liberal construction".

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Thus, while the case stands as authority for the proposition that the periods fixed by an exemption granted under s 1084 are covered by s 1322(4)(d) , it is not clear what other instruments would be covered.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 10 What, then, is the ambit of the section?

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: The power which the court is relevantly given is to "make an order extending the period for doing any act ... in relation to a corporation.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: " Although poorly drafted I think it is clear that the power cannot be read literally.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: If read literally it would apply to every period within which a corporation is required to do an act whether that period is prescribed by a public authority (including Parliament) or by private treaty (for example, a contract of sale).

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: That could hardly have been Parliament's intention.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: 11 Accordingly it is necessary to find some criteria by which to define the instrument or authority that has fixed a period for the doing of an act "in relation to a corporation" to which the section can have application.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: I have already indicated that the provision will operate in respect of periods fixed by the Corporations Act and by the rules or regulations made under the Corporations Act .

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: It would not be going much further to read the provision as also having application to instruments made under the Corporations Act by a regulatory authority, such as a class order.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: This is only a small step to take.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Whether the section has a wider operation may be left for another day.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: I certify that the preceding eleven (11) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice Finkelstein.

Name: Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd, in the matter of Dana Australia (Holdings) Pty Ltd [2006] FCA 355 (11 April 2006)
text: Associate: Dated: 11 April 2006 Counsel for the Plaintiffs: I Jones   Solicitor for the Plaintiffs: Hunt amp; Hunt   Date of Hearing: 14 February 2006   Date of Judgment: 11 April 2006      AustLII: Copyright Policy | Disclaimers | Privacy Policy | Feedback  URL: http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/FCA/2006/355.html

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: second extension of convening period for second meeting of creditors of companies in administration

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: parliamentary intention of maintaining tight time limits

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: purpose of company administration

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: corporations

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 1 On 15 June 2007 I made orders extending the convening period for the meeting of creditors required to be held under s 439A of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) (the Act) to midnight 23 July 2007 in relation to a number of companies, being the members of what is known as the Estate Property Group (the Group), together with some ancillary orders on the application of the administrators of the companies in the Group (the Administrators) ( Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 935).

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: In a related application concerning Australian Capital Reserve Limited (Administrators Appointed) (ACR), on 12 June 2007 orders were made extending the "decision period" provided for by s 441A(1)(b) of the Act to the last day of the convening period for a number of companies in the Group ( Australian Capital Reserve Limited (Administrators Appointed) v High Tower Investments Pty Limited (Administrators Appointed); in the matter of High Tower Investments Pty Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1028).

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: On 13 July 2007 the convening period for the second meeting of creditors of those companies was further extended to midnight on 31 August 2007 utilising the provisions of s 447A(1) of the Act to achieve that result and certain ancillary orders were made.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: I indicated then that I would give reasons for those orders in due course.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: These are those reasons.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: These reasons should be read with those in Hall, in the matter of Australian Capital Reserve Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1328 to be delivered contemporaneously.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: The background to these reasons is set out in the various judgments to which I have referred and need not be repeated.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 2 The Administrator of the Group with principal responsibility gave evidence as to what had occurred following the orders made on the last occasion and summarised the then current situation of the companies in the Group.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: He also dealt with the probable form of advice to creditors.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: I am satisfied that the task of investigating the position of each company and project, undertaking operational restructuring and taking advice as to the future, both generally and as to particular properties, was a major exercise that was approached diligently.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 3 The Administrators have taken advice from a property agent on a property by property basis as to the current status of each property and the options available for realisation of them.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: Development of a strategy has involved negotiations with each of the first mortgagee lenders and the Administrators of ACR, who have taken their own property advice.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: A strategy has now been agreed on a property by property basis.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: Interim funding has been arranged in relation to major project construction work.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: There had been a confidential initial approach to the Administrators by a substantial company prior to the hearing that had the potential to affect the recommendation to creditors.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 4 The Administrators have concentrated upon preparation of proposals in relation to the various companies which have been divided into three groups: Estate Constructions of Australia Pty Limited ACN 083 789 137 (Administrators Appointed), GC Condo Pty Limited (Administrators Appointed) ACN 123 133 013 --- which are the construction companies; secondly, Mayshine Pty Limited (Administrators Appointed) ACN 065 856 144, Sam Pogson Constructions Pty Limited (Administrators Appointed) ACN 050 288 394 and Seajazz Pty Limited (Administrators Appointed) ACN 069 288 204 --- known as the Mayshine companies; and thirdly, the remaining 21 companies within the Group known as the EPG subsidiaries.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 5 Within the EPG subsidiaries there are 15 entities which have developments which are either completed, in the process of being developed or own properties which have not yet been developed.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: There are six entities which do not carry on business, have no external creditors and are classified as dormant.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: It was proposed that there would be a eeed of company arrangement put forward to cover the EPG subsidiaries, including both the active and dormant companies and it was envisaged that there would be a pooling arrangement.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 6 The objective in relation to the construction companies is to formulate a proposal for a deed of company arrangement that would enable the construction companies to come out of voluntary administration and be sold to a third party and, thus, maintain a builder's licences.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 7 The Mayshine companies are the ultimate holding companies for the EPG subsidiaries and the construction companies and are not borrowers from ACR.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: These companies are owned by the directors of the Group.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: At the time of the hearing the Administrators had not had an opportunity to properly investigate those companies to determine a recommendation to creditors.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 8 The amount owed to external trade creditors of the Group is quite small compared with the amounts outstanding to secured lenders, including ACR.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 9 The evidence of the Administrators in favour of the extension is entitled to considerable weight.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: However, an extension of the convening period of what, in total, amounts to approximately three months after appointment of the Administrators is considerable.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: The Parliamentary intention of maintaining tight time limits for this stage of voluntary administration has recently been reaffirmed.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 10 The Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services Report, Corporate Insolvency Laws: a Stocktake, Canberra, June 2004, devoted attention to voluntary administration.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: In Ch 5 it considered, amongst other things, a comparison between voluntary administration and the United States Ch 11 procedure.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: It preferred voluntary administration and did not consider that wholesale amendments to the voluntary administration procedure were required (Ch 5.75).

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: Amongst the factors referred to by the Joint Committee were as follows:  "#8226; Whilst both regimes impose a moratorium on creditors' claims, the voluntary administration regime places tighter timeframes to minimise the inconvenience and prejudice to creditors through the abridgement of their propriety rights and rights accrued under freedom of contract.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: ...  #8226; Quite lengthy timeframes apply to proposed plans for reorganisation that would see a company under Chapter 11 administration having no certainty of future direction for over 6 months and in practice much longer.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: Under voluntary administration decisions are undertaken more quickly and under the supervision of a qualified independent administrator.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: "   It noted that the Corporations and Markets Advisory Committee (CAMAC) was then enquiring into the rehabilitation of large and complex enterprises and would also be considering the suitability of Ch 11 in such cases.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 11 In Ch 6 the Joint Committee gave attention to the rights of creditors including the provisions concerning creditors' meetings.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: The Joint Committee considered submissions that the timeframe for the second meeting limited the ability of the administrator to carry out a proper investigation of the company's affairs, having noted the Court's power to extend the convening period under s 439A(6) and pursuant to s 447A.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: The recommendation (6.37) was that:  "the period for holding the second meeting of creditors be extended to 25 business days with a new convening period of 20 business days.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: The adjournment period is to remain at 60 days.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: "  12 The CAMAC Report, Rehabilitating large and complex enterprises in financial difficulties, Sydney, October 2004, recommended that voluntary administration should be retained, there being no clear case for introducing a debtor in possession regime based on Ch 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code, either as a substitute for, or as an additional procedure to, voluntary administration (Recommendation 1).

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: CAMAC then considered whether a business turnaround model, as proposed by some insolvency practitioners, should be adopted and recommended against it.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: That had been one of the variations also considered by the Joint Committee and rejected (5.50).

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: CAMAC then considered a number of detailed matters, including the timing of first and major meetings (2.6).

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: The recommendation was:  "#8226; the periods for holding the first and major meetings of creditors should be incrementally increased (namely, for the first meeting within 8 business days, and for the major meeting within 25 business days, of the appointment of the administrator), and   #8226; the administrator should be permitted to hold the major meeting before the end of the convening period.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: In addition, the court should have a specific power, on application by the administrator, to override the statutory timetable and to substitute a specific and comprehensive timetable for a particular administration.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: Administrators should have the power to adjourn a creditors' meeting either to a specific date or a date to be notified within the specified statutory period.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: "  13 The Explanatory Memorandum to the Corporations Amendment (Insolvency) Bill 2007 contained a section entitled "Finetuning voluntary administration" which considered the question of time limits involved with meetings.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: It was said (at 7.114---7.115):  "The setting of tight time frames and milestones for completion of the various tasks in an administration is an important feature of the voluntary administration procedure.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: On the one hand it is beneficial for stakeholders that the process be conducted without delay.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: It avoids the delays, abuses and expense that may occur if a much longer or unrestricted time frame is allowed.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: On the other hand a limited extension of the period of time for holding the statutory meetings may increase creditors' opportunities to participate, and allow administrators more time to conduct an examination of the company's financial circumstances and consider the best options for its future.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: "  14 The proposed reforms in relation to the second meeting are as follows:  "Second meeting   Current   New   Convening of meeting   21 of 28 days   20 or 25 business days   Notice of meeting   5 business days   No change   Timing of meeting   Within 5 business days after the end of the convening period   Within 5 business days before or after the end of the convening period   Adjournment period   60 days   45 business days "   That bill has now passed and is awaiting assent.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 15 It needs to be borne in mind that administration of a company pursuant to Pt 5.3A is correctly headed as "Administration of a company's affairs with a view to executing a deed of company arrangement".

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: Section 435C(2) provides that:  "(2) The normal outcome of the administration of a company is that:     (a) a deed of company arrangement is executed by both the company and the deed's administrator; or  (b) the company's creditors resolve under paragraph 439C(b) that the administration should end; or  (c) the company's creditors resolve under paragraph 439C(c) that the company be wound up.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: "     A deed of company arrangement is the form of administration by which the chances of a company continuing in existence are maximised, not indefinite company administration (cf s 435A).

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: A regime of the latter kind has clearly been rejected by the recent reviews of the topic as a form of external administration as such.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: 16 However, the flexibility provided by s 447A has been noted in those reviews.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: The factors that weighed in favour of the order for further extension that was made in the present case --- in addition to the opinion of the Administrators that more time was needed --- included the amount of work that had been done, the real possibility of deeds of company arrangement being proposed, the support of secured lenders including the administrators of ACR and the lack of opposition following wide dissemination of what was proposed.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: All in all, I was satisfied that this was a case for a further extension.

Name: Hayes, in the matter of Estate Property Group Limited (Administrators Appointed) [2007] FCA 1329 (29 August 2007)
text: I certify that the preceding sixteen (16) numbered paragraphs are a true copy of the Reasons for Judgment herein of the Honourable Justice Gyles.
